fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Lawrence Prittipaul might be Shivnarine Chanderpaul's cousin but at this early stage his batting would seem to bear greater resemblance to another West Indian left-hander. The 20-year-old from Portsmouth yesterday hammered his maiden first-class century, lifting his career average to a Lara-like 90.33, as Hampshire kept alive their minuscule hopes of avoiding championship relegation.
fields.body:
Lawrence Prittipaul might be Shivnarine Chanderpaul's cousin but at this early stage his batting would seem to bear greater resemblance to another West Indian left-hander. The 20-year-old from Portsmouth yesterday hammered his maiden first-class century, lifting his career average to a Lara-like 90.33, as Hampshire kept alive their minuscule hopes of avoiding championship relegation.

By the close of play at Southampton the hosts had plundered a weakened Derbyshire attack for 368 for four. It is unlikely to be enough to keep the south coast big spenders out of the Second Division next summer, but Prittipaul showed what might have been had Hampshire showed faith in his nerveless strokeplay a little earlier in the season.

He was 149 not out from 212 balls at stumps, in only his third first-class match, having shared a rapid 248-run stand for the fourth wicket with Will Kendall, whose 143 was his second hundred in four days.

Glamorgan 's promotion hopes nose-dived as they were frustrated by Nottinghamshire 's Australian connection at Trent Bridge. Jason Gallian hit an unbeaten 127, his second successive hundred, and the Victorian seamer Paul Reiffel smashed 50 from 67 balls as the home side finished on 309 for seven.

Middlesex , increasingly certain of finishing bottom of the Second Division, looked on as David Hemp (129) helped Warwickshire rack up 416 on the second day at Lord's. The hapless hosts were 82 without loss in reply.

webTitle: Somerset slump hands treble to Gloucestershire

fields.headline: Somerset slump hands treble to Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: It has been quite a week for breaking 31-year hoodoos. Two days after England exacted long-overdue retribution against West Indies, Gloucestershire - the undisputed masters of the domestic one-day game - last night righted their own three decades of hurt by winning the National League title for the first time.
fields.body:
It has been quite a week for breaking 31-year hoodoos. Two days after England exacted long-overdue retribution against West Indies, Gloucestershire - the undisputed masters of the domestic one-day game - last night righted their own three decades of hurt by winning the National League title for the first time.

The circumstances could hardly have been more different: a packed, sunny Oval compared to a near-empty, grey Old Trafford. If that was not anti-climactic enough, the new champions were not even present.

But as Somerset - the final obstacle to Gloucestershire's title hopes - lurched towards defeat against Lancashire, Bristol-based fans edged ever closer to their TV sets. A fighting 110 under the much-maligned Old Trafford lights by Jamie Cox was not enough, and Somerset fell 10 runs short, handing Gloucestershire their first triumph in the competition since the old Sunday League began in 1969.

Their victory also secured them an unprecedented one-day treble - to go with their NatWest Trophy and B&H Cup successes - an incredible feat for a county starved of glory for more than a century.

But before anyone likens them to the treble-trotting Manchester United side of 1999, it should be noted that Gloucestershire lie second-from-last in the championship's Second Division. And Mark Alleyne, their most charismatic player, is no David Beckham. Not that anyone is complaining.

"My pulse is still beating," admitted Alleyne, the captain. "We still have one game left so we might have a toast today, but the real celebration will come at the end of the season."

fields.headline: Silvinho strike stuns Chelsea
fields.trailText: What promised to be a heartening win for Chelsea last night turned into a nasty case of déjà vu as Arsenal denied Gianluca Vialli's team victory much as they had done here last season, again wiping out a two-goal deficit in the final quarter of an hour.
fields.body:
What promised to be a heartening win for Chelsea last night turned into a nasty case of déjà vu as Arsenal denied Gianluca Vialli's team victory much as they had done here last season, again wiping out a two-goal deficit in the final quarter of an hour.

On the last occasion Arsenal won 3-2 with a memorable hat-trick from Nwankwo Kanu, but although last night's recovery only brought them a draw, Arséne Wenger was entitled to take almost as much satisfaction from a result achieved with Tony Adams injured, Patrick Vieira suspended and Dennis Bergkamp just about fit enough to come off the bench for the last 20 minutes - decisively as it turned out.

In the match programme the Chelsea manager described that earlier result as "one of the worst experiences of my managerial career". Had Thierry Henry not wafted over the bar a chance set up by Bergkamp in stoppage time Vialli would have relived his torment in full.

Overall Chelsea were entitled to be pleased with the levels of passing and movement which until those last 15 minutes promised to bring them a distinguished victory after a less than distinguished start to the season. As Vialli pointed out: "For 75 minutes we were excellent and playing some very good football."

He put his team's failure again to hold their lead down to fatigue. "We started to defend too deep and allow them possession almost on the edge of our box. Arsenal have players of high quality and we couldn't hold them, but I think tiredness was the reason for it."

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink put it more succinctly. "Stupid", he called it. The Dutch striker was entitled to feel piqued, since he had put his team ahead and then hit a post with a shot which would have given Chelsea a 3-1 lead.

In the end the sheer class of Hasselbaink's compatriot, Bergkamp, left Chelsea almost grateful for a point. When he replaced Ray Parlour with 20 minutes remaining it was as if a landscape artist had come on for a painter and decorator. No disrespect to Parlour but he would never have helped set up the goal for Henry which gave Arsenal renewed hope.

A fixture which in recent seasons has had the stability of nitro-glycerine challenged each team to last the 90 minutes with a full compliment of players and one or two Anglo-French tempers were still simmering after last Saturday's international in Paris.

The match, however, remained refreshingly free of rancour, the only unpleasant incident occurring when Graeme Le Saux caught Lee Dixon with a tackle late and high early in the second half. The rest was fast, open and highly entertaining.

From Arsenal's point of view much depended on how well Wenger's makeshift midfield pairing of Parlour and Gilles Grimandi coped with the task of containing Dennis Wise, Roberto Di Matteo, Gustavo Poyet and, when he went deep, Zola. Henry's pace was always likely to threaten Chelsea's central defenders but the way the game was developing it was no surprise when Arsenal fell behind.

Panic is not usually a word associated with Wenger's defence but when Di Matteo found Poyet in space just outside the penalty area this was what happened as Martin Keown, Oleg Luzhny and Silvinho all lunged towards the tall Uruguayan. Calm as you like, Poyet laid the ball off to Hasselbaink who briskly made space before beating David Seaman with a shot inside the near post.

As the second half began Chelsea were quickly reminded of the fragility of one-goal leads and Arsenal comebacks. Lauren surprised their defenders with an oblique run across the penalty area before turning the ball back low for Kanu to turn, shoot and hit the bar.

A shudder ran through the stands but just before the hour Stamford Bridge relaxed as Chelsea increased their lead. This time the response of Arsenal's defenders was sluggish rather than panic-stricken as Poyet chested a free-kick from Leboeuf into the path of Zola, who despite an awkward bounce still directed a low shot inside the left-hand post.

webTitle: Shearer's 200th goal puts Magpies on top

fields.headline: Shearer's 200th goal puts Magpies on top
fields.trailText: What a difference a year makes. Twelve months ago, when Bobby Robson succeeded Ruud Gullit, Newcastle were second from bottom of the Premiership and Alan Shearer was adjusting to life on the bench. This morning, with the help of Shearer's 200th league goal, they are at the top.
fields.body:
What a difference a year makes. Twelve months ago, when Bobby Robson succeeded Ruud Gullit, Newcastle were second from bottom of the Premiership and Alan Shearer was adjusting to life on the bench. This morning, with the help of Shearer's 200th league goal, they are at the top.

Robson will not be staking his pension on his side staying there until May; they do not look capable of that. But there was much to admire in Newcastle's resilience and counter-attacking after a shaky start. Once the half-time substitute Kevin Gallagher had added to Shearer's penalty, the outcome was rarely in doubt.

"We are top of the table at the wrong time," Robson said with a smile. "We are not getting excited." But even if it remains milk rather than champagne that he pours on his Corn Flakes, there is no mistaking the pride he takes from the turnaround.

"This time last year we had one [point] from seven [matches]," he recalled. "Now we have nine from four. It's a marked improvement and we are heading in the right direction. There's a bit more to go to be up with Manchester United and Arsenal and Chelsea. We got left behind but we are making our way back bit by bit."

For sure the squad is too slim and a little lacking in quality but there is no mistaking the passion, and Robson is still using title talk to gee them up: "I said to them 'If this was the last match of the season and you needed to win it to win the championship, could you do it?' We were really motivated in that respect and they responded."

Shearer's penalty on the half-hour, against the run of play, changed the match. The 30-year-old striker comfortably tucked away his 200th league goal from 375 appearances and will doubtless dedicate it to his new-born son Will. Coventry still had the will but gradually lost their way.

Robson described Shearer's milestone as a "phenomenal effort" and admitted that the former England captain's retirement from international football is already benefiting the club. "Twenty goals a year for 10 years at the highest level," the manager said admiringly, "and remember he missed two seasons because of a cruciate injury and a broken ankle."

The performance of Newcastle's back line once Shearer had scored gave Robson almost equal pleasure. Coventry, for all their possession, rarely unsettled a determined defence and created next to no clear chances.

Gordon Strachan was dubious about the penalty, the Coventry manager saying everyone who had seen a replay of Marcus Hall's challenge on Laurent Charvet insisted there was no contact.

And his feeling that his team "got no breaks" was reinforced by the lead-up to Gallagher's goal. Hall's attempted clearance bounced off the impressive Kieron Dyer and deflected into the path of Gallagher, who could not miss from close range.

If the table did not already tell of what Robson has achieved, he needed only remember his side were beaten here 4-1 last season.

webTitle: Robson fumes after Derby's latest escape

fields.headline: Robson fumes after Derby's latest escape
fields.trailText: Never write off Derby. For the third time this season Jim Smith's team recovered from a seemingly irretrievable deficit to salvage something just as their fans were reaching for the anti-depressants on a highly contentious night.
fields.body:
Never write off Derby. For the third time this season Jim Smith's team recovered from a seemingly irretrievable deficit to salvage something just as their fans were reaching for the anti-depressants on a highly contentious night.

Having trailed by three goals, the fog of discontent rapidly descending over Pride Park was dissipated by a remarkable comeback from the home side in the final 22 minutes.

Malcolm Christie sparked the revival four minutes after stepping off the bench and, after Branko Strupar had scored with a header seven minutes from time, the substitute striker provided the pièce de résistance in the 87th minute.

But the night was tinged with controversy. Bryan Robson, the Boro manager, made no attempt to conceal his anger at the illicit way in which Derby had crafted their second goal - a throwback to Marc Overmars's infamous FA Cup "goal" against Sheffield United two seasons ago.

His fury was understandable. Paul Ince had kicked the ball into touch so the Boro physiotherapist could tend to Phil Stamp, but Dean Sturridge broke with protocol by declining to return it from the resultant throw.

Instead he threw the ball to Deon Burton who broke up field and forced a corner from which Strupar scored with a header. "They cheated to get a point, as simple as that," spat Robson. "It's not the fault of the referee, it's the two players I blame." Asked if he had confronted the Derby players, Robson said: "I don't want to get into that. But everyone knows what's right or wrong."

Ince certainly should. The finger-wagging manner in which he remonstrated with the officials after the final whistle, appearing to manhandle one of the linesmen, suggests he should expect an invitation to Lancaster Gate to drop through his letterbox in the next few days.

Just to add to the bad feeling, Smith claimed Stamp was pretending to be injured and Ince had been time-wasting. "We were justified doing what we did," he said. "Stamp just sat down."

Robson's real anger should have been directed at his players after coasting for the opening three-quarters against opponents who must be considering making late comebacks their own copyright.

Alen Boksic, the game's outstanding player, set them away when he won and converted a 12th-minute penalty from a challenge by Stefano Eranio and, after the traumas of their previous three matches, the half-time team talk from Smith must have seemed like a scene from Groundhog Day to his players.

They set about their task willingly but when the next goal arrived it was Boro's again, with Boksic's toe-poke blocked by Poom and the rebound falling conveniently for Joseph-Desire Job.

When Brian Deane shot between Poom's legs shortly before the hour Derby looked well beaten. But the game turned when Smith introduced Christie in the 64th minute.

His first was a header from Seth Johnson's centre and the equaliser a close-range prod. A few weeks ago he was recovering in hospital from viral meningitis. Last night he was the toast of Pride Park.

webTitle: Owen hat-trick hits Voller and Villa

fields.headline: Owen hat-trick hits Voller and Villa
fields.trailText: Until Rudi Völler left his seat in the directors' box just before the final whistle he had been little more than a face in the crowd. But, as he made his way through dark and unfamiliar streetshe may well have found himself on the sharp end of some typical scouse joshing.
fields.body:
Until Rudi Völler left his seat in the directors' box just before the final whistle he had been little more than a face in the crowd. But, as he made his way through dark and unfamiliar streetshe may well have found himself on the sharp end of some typical scouse joshing.

If the caretaker manager of Germany, who play England in a World Cup qualifier next month, had come to Anfield to assess the form of Dietmar Hamman and Markus Babbel, he will, presumably, have departed mulling over the possible consequences for his country of the startling renaissance of Michael Owen.

As Voller looked on impassively, Owen single-handedly took Aston Villa apart with a fine hat-trick to take his tally to six goals in his last three games for club and country.

"Michael is coming back to what he was before all his injury problems; he is beginning to menace, to scare, defences again," said Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier.

After the trauma which had unfolded 11 days earlier at the Dell - three sloppy goals conceded without so much as a hint of collective defiance - there was a real sense of urgency about Owen and his team-mates last night.

Had the Villa defence been able to boast a similar degree of defiance, they would not have been undone quite so early for barely five minutes had elapsed when Liverpool made a memorable breakthrough.

It was a goal constructed at great speed and beautifully executed, Owen stabbing in powerfully from no great distance after Emile Heskey had outmanoeuvred and outpaced George Boateng and Gareth Barry before crossing exquisitely from the by-line.

It was to get worse for Villa and quickly. John Gregory's boys were actually starting to play well when they succumbed for a second time. Both Luc Nilis and Dion Dublin had gone close but success away from home is built on defensive resilience and there was little of that as the red tide rolled ever forward.

It was Owen again, this time arriving unannounced at the far post to head in a Vladimir Smicer corner after the Villa goalkeeper David James had reminded supporters of his former club that his fondness for flapping at anything above waist height has in no way been diminished by his relocation in the Midlands.

Although Villa continued to attack with panache and enthusiasm, Villa had come apart at the back and there was an air of inevitability about Owen's third goal after 33 minutes, a text-book finish after Alpay Ozalan's composure had deserted him.

Had Villa folded in the traditional manner they would, of course, have been forgiven but, commendably, they opted to carry the fight to their tormentors, swamping midfield in the forlorn belief that Liverpool would eventually be undone either by complacency or, more probably, boredom.

But, by attempting to re trieve the night, Villa did leave open the prospect of yet more punishment and, as legs began to tire, Owen's ceaseless running did serve as a timely reminder that gifted goal-scorers are likely to prosper when those charged with containing them are otherwise engaged.

But, as it turned out, Villa scored the only other goal, Steve Stone's late strike giving them something to reflect on - well, that and a season which has still to yield a victory.

webTitle: Johansson limits Hoddle to what he came for

fields.headline: Johansson limits Hoddle to what he came for
fields.trailText: The name is Jonatan Johansson and England have been warned. The Finnish international striker, a £3.75m summer signing from Rangers, saved Charlton's blushes last night with the sort of finishing that could leave Kevin Keegan's team with red faces when they meet Finland in a World Cup qualifier next month.
fields.body:
The name is Jonatan Johansson and England have been warned. The Finnish international striker, a £3.75m summer signing from Rangers, saved Charlton's blushes last night with the sort of finishing that could leave Kevin Keegan's team with red faces when they meet Finland in a World Cup qualifier next month.

With Charlton reduced to 10 men by Steve Brown's second-half sending-off, and a goal behind after Marian Pahars's strike 11 minutes from time, Johansson, a substitute making only his second Charlton appearance, popped up to save the day. Receiving the ball from Andy Hunt's flick-on, he brilliantly turned Claus Lun dekvam before firing a deadly low shot past Neil Moss.

Southampton could not believe it. After surviving all that Charlton had to throw at them in the first half, they had bounced back in the second, taken advantage of the home side's loss of Brown by stealing the lead and looked on course for their first win of the season.

But they let a 2-0 lead slip on the opening day of the season at Derby and could not hold on last night. They even managed to squander a glut of late chances that could have won them the game. Glenn Hoddle was not a happy bunny afterwards.

Neither was Alan Curbishley, who was particularly scathing about Brown's sending-off - the second time in three games that Charlton had finished with 10 men.

"I thought the game was decided by a referee's decision," said the manager. "They've just got no feeling or compassion regarding the importance of the game to everyone.

"The first challenge was so innocuous. I've got no complaints about the second challenge [a lunge from behind on Uwe Rösler] but it's only the second challenge the player's made the whole evening. You can't have two challenges in the game and go off."

At least it ended a run of two successive defeats for the newly promoted side. But they should have capitalised on the chances they created in the first half.

Southampton started on the back foot, fielding five defenders in the hope of soaking up the pressure and hitting on the break.

It proved a dangerous policy as the home side swept forward. Moss twice saved from John Robinson, Dean Richards pulled off a couple of vital tackles in the area before clearing Claus Jensen's free-kick off the line and just before half-time Graham Stuart fired an inviting chance straight at the keeper.

Southampton, whose only true first-half chance had seen Pahars shoot wide from close range, reshuffled to 4-3-3 in the second half and took a greater share of the game. Rösler saw a shot cleared off the line by Mark Kinsella before the balance of power shifted further away from Charlton with Brown's dismissal.

Southampton deservedly took the lead after Charlton failed to clear the ball properly and a cross from the substitute Hassan Kachloul was turned in at the far post by Pahars.

But up popped Johansson to equalise. Charlton defended doggedly towards the end to keep the scores level and, in the circumstances, were perhaps happier with the point.

fields.headline: Collymore the Leicester catalyst
fields.trailText: Leicester are often cited as a role model for Nationwide League teams - the last club to come from the play-offs and establish themselves in the Premiership. Ipswich are the latest to try to emulate that feat and last night they were taught a harsh lesson in the realities of Premiership survival.
fields.body:
Leicester are often cited as a role model for Nationwide League teams - the last club to come from the play-offs and establish themselves in the Premiership. Ipswich are the latest to try to emulate that feat and last night they were taught a harsh lesson in the realities of Premiership survival.

There is no doubting Ipswich's ability nor their capacity to pass the ball but, Jim Magilton's late penalty apart, they created very little. Even that goal, the first conceded by Leicester this season, owed a lot to a terrible loss of concentration in the home defence as David Johnson ran clear before being felled by Matt Elliott. "It was a definite penalty," said Elliott. "I'm just happy I didn't get a yellow card."

It was an unfortunate end to what had been a professional performance by the home side. Having being given an awkward draw against Red Star Belgrade in the Uefa Cup first round, Leicester wanted this game and Saturday's home fixture against Southampton to act as a morale-boosting springboard into Europe ahead of the first leg a week today.

The Leicester chairman John Elsom had returned to England just in time for the game after meeting Uefa in Geneva to discuss the away leg, which he is trying to move from Belgrade. It was, it seemed, a successful trip, with Uefa's hard-line refusal to move the game apparently softening.

"I've got a gut feeling that we won't be playing in Belgrade on September 28," he said. Po tentially volatile elections are scheduled for September 24, four days before the game. The results are due to be announced on match day.

"Whatever decision Uefa makes we will abide by that," Elsom said, but fans are still warned against travelling. "The Foreign Office advice is that it is inadvisable to travel to Yugoslavia on anything but unavoidable business. I'm afraid supporting football doesn't fall into that definition."

A straw poll of the players revealed that most would prefer the game to be moved. "If they can't guarantee the fans' safety, I don't see how they can guarantee the players'," said Gerry Taggart. "We would prefer it to be played in a neutral country," added Elliott with typical honesty, "because of all the advantages it will give us. But, if I were a fan, I'd probably watch it on the box."

Elsom could ideally have taken a little longer over his return from Switzerland, and there was little in the first half to justify his hassle. The turning point was the half-time arrival of Stan Collymore in place of Muzzy Izzet, who was "not feeling well" according to Peter Taylor.

Within 10 minutes his flick-on found Darren Eadie, who ran into the box before squaring the ball for Ade Akinbiyi to slide in his first goal for the club. Ipswich are the latest to try to emulate that feat and last night they were taught a harsh lesson in the realities of Premiership survival. There is no doubting Ipswich's ability nor their capacity to pass the ball but, Jim Magilton's late penalty apart, they created very little. Even that goal, the first conceded by Leicester this season, owed a lot to a terrible loss of concentration in the home defence as David Johnson ran clear before being felled by Matt Elliott. "It was a definite penalty," said Elliott. "I'm just happy I didn't get a yellow card." It was an unfortunate end to what had been a professional performance by the home side. fields.headline: Life in the dinosaur
fields.standfirst:
J Mascis
Underworld, London
***
fields.trailText: Acoustic guitars conjure a certain folksy image, and for a brief, strange moment it seems as though J Mascis is going to fit gently into it. Sitting in the middle of a bare stage, guitar perched on his lap, long, straight brown hair tucked neatly behind his ears, he looks just like Neil from the Young Ones.
fields.body:
Acoustic guitars conjure a certain folksy image, and for a brief, strange moment it seems as though J Mascis is going to fit gently into it. Sitting in the middle of a bare stage, guitar perched on his lap, long, straight brown hair tucked neatly behind his ears, he looks just like Neil from the Young Ones.

He opens with Thumb, and his guitar sounds sweet and jangly, while his gnarled vocals call to mind Neil Young with a blocked nose and in tender mood. This is not what you expect from the man who, with his band Dinosaur Jr, practically invented grunge in the late 1980s, injecting each potentially placid tune with violent, reverberating effects that made your ears sore.

The crowd are clearly bemused by this softened Mascis. So when he launches into Same Day, from his new album J Mascis and the Fog, and slams his foot on an effects pedal designed for electric guitar to conjure a weird gurgle of crackling fuzz, the relief is palpable. From then on, every squealing solo and random spurt of revving, roaring noise is greeted with a joyful cheer. That folk image is ritually murdered and Mascis the gentle giant of rock is back in business.

Although Mascis performs alone, his songs never sound stripped or lacking: with a few buzzing chords and a bright, neat five-note melody he can fill the room. He has based his career on the same four or five song patterns, within which heartfelt emotion is a constant and the only variable is the grizzliness of the tone; and yet he repeats each with a gusto and warmth that keeps potential boredom at bay. Even a song as old as The Wagon, from 1991's Dinosaur Jr album Green Mind, sounds fresh and sprightly.

Most of the songs are wrapped around guitar solos. These are usually pernicious things, yet his frantic fingerwork doesn't irritate and, more exceptionally still, they don't sound stranded in a blank space at the heart of a song, but sparky, sharp and invigorating. There's life in the old guitar dinosaur yet.

fields.headline: Pop.com offline before it starts
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Pop.com, the online entertainment site backed by some of the biggest names in Hollywood, has decided to lay off almost all its employees before the end of this week. The company will retain a small staff to support "creative endeavours".
fields.body:
Pop.com, the online entertainment site backed by some of the biggest names in Hollywood, has decided to lay off almost all its employees before the end of this week. The company will retain a small staff to support "creative endeavours".

Eighty staff at the headquarters in Glendale, California, will leave tomorrow. The redundancies come before the launch of the much-anticipated site and after takeover talks with iFilm, a rival internet company, collapsed last week.

The failure of the company after 11 months is a blow to Hollywood's efforts to capitalise on the demand for online entertainment.

Pop.com's backers, which included the Dreamworks team of Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg as well as Ron Howard, the film director who played Richie Cunningham in the television series Happy Days, decided to close the site this week.

Talks with iFilm broke down last Friday. Pop.com, which has spent millions of dollars in its short life, also tried to interest other entertainment websites in a merger but with little success.

Analysts said the collapse of the venture, which was expected to focus on netcasting entertainment, reflected the changed market dynamics for internet companies.

Mr Howard, the head of Imagine Entertainment, said in a recent interview: "The whole business climate changed. It used to be you staked a claim, went out with an IPO and the public would back you. That's not the case any more."

webTitle: Lower prices likely to keep interest rate steady

fields.headline: Lower prices likely to keep interest rate steady
fields.trailText: News that retailers are slashing prices at a record rate to shift goods and that manufacturers are once again cutting output raised hopes yesterday that the Bank of England will keep interest rates on hold when its rate setting committee announces its decision today.
fields.body:
News that retailers are slashing prices at a record rate to shift goods and that manufacturers are once again cutting output raised hopes yesterday that the Bank of England will keep interest rates on hold when its rate setting committee announces its decision today.

Intense competition on the high streets is keeping a tight lid on inflation, according to the Confederation of British Industry. Their latest snapshot of the distributive trade sector revealed that August saw the biggest falls in retail prices since the survey began 17 years ago.

"Pricing pressures remain intense as retailers aggressively compete to offer value at every level," said Alastair Eperon, chairman of the CBI's distributive trades panel. "The survey highlights the pressures that retailers are under and adds weight to the case for interest rates to stay on hold."

Sales growth slowed more than expected, according to the CBI. "Only modest improvements are forecast for next month," said Mr Eperon.

The CBI data came after official government figures showed that manufacturing output fell by 0.3% in July, the sharpest month-on-month decline since April. Analysts had expected a rise after recent upbeat business surveys.

"The modest weakening of the pound during the summer is revealed as having offered the manufacturing sector little relief," said Daniel Kaye, UK economist at Capital Economics. "Indeed, any benign impact on profit margins is likely to have been offset by the impact of continuing strong oil prices over the same period."

Most economists are expecting the Bank's monetary policy committee to keep borrowing costs on hold at 6% for the seventh month in a row when its meeting concludes today.

"These figures add weight to our view that the Bank of England will refrain from raising rates at this month's policy meeting," said Ciaran Barr, UK economist at Deutsche Bank. "For the time being the data seems to be supporting the dovish stance on rates, or at worst, a 'wait and see' approach."

Last month's meeting was finely balanced with the MPC voting 5-4 to keep rates on hold.

webTitle: £6,000 windfalls as Scottish Provident deal goes ahead

fields.headline: £6,000 windfalls as Scottish Provident deal goes ahead
fields.trailText: Members of mutual insurer Scottish Provident have learned they are in line for windfalls averaging £6,000 following the £1.8 billion takeover by Abbey National.
fields.body:
Members of mutual insurer Scottish Provident have learned they are in line for windfalls averaging £6,000 following the £1.8 billion takeover by Abbey National.

Scottish Provident's 325,000 qualifying with profits policyholders will receive an average payment of £4,500 for loss of their mutual status plus additional policy benefits averaging £1,500.

Another 100,000 members who are not qualifying with profits policyholders will receive a flat payment of £500 while the remaining 325,000 policyholders will receive nothing.

The acquisition brings to an end five months of speculation about Scottish Provident's future, following its announcement in April that it was reviewing its mutual status.

For Abbey, the deal will add to its existing insurer Scottish Mutual, based in Glasgow, which it bought in 1992.

Ian Harley, chief executive of Abbey National, said: "This transaction delivers on our stated strategy of significantly diversifying our business and is a major step in changing the shape of our business."

Abbey will retain the Scottish Provident name.

The deal however has raised fears of job cuts among the 4,000 staff employed by Scottish Mutual and Scottish Provident.

Mr Harley said: "Hopefully we will keep redundancies to a minimum."

Scottish Provident said there would be some "rationalisation" of the combined operations but it was intended this would be achieved through "business growth, natural wastage and redeployment elsewhere in the group where possible".

The mutual added there were no plans for wholesale redundancies.

fields.headline: Sensible simplicity
fields.standfirst:
The Rape of Lucretia
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText: Whether by design or not, Benjamin Britten and his librettist Ronald Duncan gave directors very little room for manoeuvre with The Rape of Lucretia.
fields.body:
Whether by design or not, Benjamin Britten and his librettist Ronald Duncan gave directors very little room for manoeuvre with The Rape of Lucretia. By building in the device of the Male and Female Chorus, who mediate between the audience and the bleak, unpleasant events they unfold, the perspectives are all fixed; a staging cannot introduce any kind of alienation because that is already a given, while the story of Lucretia herself has to be presented in a direct and literal way just as the Choruses describe. Of all Britten's operas, it's the one that loses least in a concert performance.

In his direct and very effective production for the British Youth Opera, Jamie Hayes has sensibly kept things simple. The main action is played out straightforwardly within a minimal set (by Will Bowen), and in correct Roman costume; the Choruses wear modern dress, narrating and commenting with understated humanity, enhanced by the use of sign language for crucial passages. It's all of a piece with Peter Robinson's urgent and dramatically acute conducting of this problematic score, which for all its musical beauties can never quite rise above the deathly prosody of Duncan's text and the contrivance of its Christian cop-out ending.

The young cast work hard to impressive effect. The standard is set by the tenor Christopher Steele as the Male Chorus, delivering every word as if it mattered (too many of them in this piece don't, sadly) with admirably even, compassionate tone; his female equivalent, Caroline Childe, is equally lucid, equally caring. Lucretia is sung by Catherine Carby, graciously and touchingly, without quite the grave sumptuousness of tone that a more experienced singer might bring to the role in the final scene. Her servants are carefully portrayed by Anna Sollerman and Lauren Francis; Christopher Dixon makes a striking, impulsive Tarquinius; Rodney Clarke a forthright Junius and Barry Martin a powerfully dark-toned Collatinus. A fine achievement and recommended, if you can get on with the piece itself.

Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

fields.headline: Perfect for an ironic era
fields.standfirst:
Hamlet
Lyttelton Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Simon Russell Beale's National Theatre Hamlet is everything one could hope for: witty, ironic, intelligent - a Henry James who is also a swordsman - to borrow Harold Bloom's phrase.
fields.body:
Simon Russell Beale's National Theatre Hamlet is everything one could hope for: witty, ironic, intelligent - a Henry James who is also a swordsman - to borrow Harold Bloom's phrase. My one regret is that John Caird's production strips the play of its public context. This is Hamlet with the prince but without the vital politics.

But first Russell Beale. Like all Hamlets, he accommodates the character to his own nature. He is not athletically built: indeed he mockingly pats his stomach when announcing he has "forgone all custom of exercises". But our first glimpse of him is scribbling notes while still mourning his father's loss. Instantly one feels this is a Hamlet who is bookish, inward, reflective and intensely capable of self-scrutiny.

Russell Beale's great quality is his capacity for surprise. He registers genuine moral disgust at the depravity he encounters within the court: there are prolonged pauses first at the revelation that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern have been sent for and then at the realisation that Ophelia is being used as a tactical decoy. But Russell Beale, for all his moral sensitivity and parodic wit, also conveys the paralysis of the intellectual caught up in a world of realpolitik: there's a defining moment, after Polonius's death, when he has the chance to stab Peter McEnery's taunting Claudius and slowly allows himself to be disarmed. This is a first-rate, deeply intellectual Hamlet whose weapons are primarily verbal and who understands that revenge cannot offer meaningful redress.

Caird deserves credit for Russell Beale's interpretation. But it seems typical of the times that he strips the text of all its political resonances. There is no sense of a Denmark on a war-footing, no urgent diplomatic missions, no Fortinbras, so that we lose Hamlet's crucial soliloquy "How all occasions do inform against me" and a character who is a practical counterpoise to the meditative hero. In that sense, this is an old-fashioned production that focuses exclusively on Hamlet's tortured sensibility.

Where Shakespeare offers variety, the production also offers a glittering sameness. Tim Hatley's set is a candle-lit mausoleum filled with upended trunks and John Cameron's insistent score swaths the play in choral religiosity. Few of the surrounding characters also have a detailed inner life although McEnery's Claudius displays conspicuous bravery, Sara Kestelman's Gertrude decisively bungs her husband's portrait in a case at the end of the closet-scene and Cathryn Bradshaw's Ophelia for once goes mad in her daytime clothes. But the glory of the evening lies in Russell Beale's performance, which is a perfect Hamlet for the age of irony.

In rep. Box office: 020-7452 3000. This review appeared in some editions yesterday.

fields.headline: No change for interest rate
fields.standfirst:
The issue explained: setting Britain's interest rates
More about house prices
fields.trailText: The Bank of England has left UK interest rates unchanged at 6% for the seventh month running.
fields.body:
The Bank of England has left UK interest rates unchanged at 6% for the seventh month running.

A slowdown in the housing market and sluggish high street sales may have persuaded the bank's monetary policy committee to leave the rate on hold.

The decision offers relief to Britain's exporters struggling under the weight of a strong pound against the euro.

Retailers will also welcome the decision as worries grow over the continued weakness of sales on the high street.

The rate could, however, rise 0.25% when the bank makes its decision next month to curb the threat of inflation, which may be building on the economy as the price of oil soars and sterling weakens against the rampant US dollar.

Neil Parker, senior economist at Royal Bank of Scotland, predicted their would be no change this month. "Not enough has changed since the August decision to merit a rise this time round," he said.

fields.headline: Dance review
fields.standfirst:
Irek Mukhamedov and Company
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.trailText: At 40, Irek Mukhamedov is still determined to raise hell on stage. So just as he did last year, he's put together a small Anglo-Russian company with which to star. Again, he's ready to show the world how easily he and his ballerina - the great Altynai Asylmuratova (herself 39) can still fill a theatre.
fields.body:
At 40, Irek Mukhamedov is still determined to raise hell on stage. So just as he did last year, he's put together a small Anglo-Russian company with which to star. Again, he's ready to show the world how easily he and his ballerina - the great Altynai Asylmuratova (herself 39) can still fill a theatre.

The programme opens with a staged ballet class, and though it is basic stuff, watching Mukhamedov and Asylmuratova turn routine steps into poetry gives us a fascinating breakdown of their talents. Asylmuratova can inflect a lift with tragic grandeur or send a musical phrase reeling through the air with the timing of her pirouettes. Mukhamedov more blatantly works the crowd, and when he throws off a few of the blazing leaps that first made him a star he cocks his head defiantly.

The really exciting showcase for their partnership ought to have been the two pieces created for the dancers, yet neither rises to the challenge of their stars. Darshan Singh Bhuller's Sita, an exotically sculpted duet, starts off promisingly, with the dancers tensing and folding their bodies through a series of taut embraces. When the movement becomes more extrovert, however, it fails to chime with the dancers' personal styles. Bhuller's halting vocabulary makes both of them appear self-conscious and even inarticulate.

Gillian Lynne's Some You Win is a jazzy ensemble number starring Mukhamedov as a guy on the make and Asylmuratova as the stranger with whom he falls in love. Lynne's choreography allows the former to look charmingly laddish, but discovers nothing remarkable in the latter. It's a throwaway piece that looks as if it has been made in haste - as does the show as a whole. Though Mukhamedov has assembled some real dance talent, most of it looks either under-rehearsed or miscast. Interestingly, the best piece is William Tuckett's modest duet, Unobtrusive Detail, whose invention and directness cut through the gala flim-flam.

 Till Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Again, he's ready to show the world how easily he and his ballerina - the great Altynai Asylmuratova (herself 39) can still fill a theatre. The programme opens with a staged ballet class, and though it is basic stuff, watching Mukhamedov and Asylmuratova turn routine steps into poetry gives us a fascinating breakdown of their talents. Asylmuratova can inflect a lift with tragic grandeur or send a musical phrase reeling through the air with the timing of her pirouettes. Mukhamedov more blatantly works the crowd, and when he throws off a few of the blazing leaps that first made him a star he cocks his head defiantly. The really exciting showcase for their partnership ought to have been the two pieces created for the dancers, yet neither rises to the challenge of their stars. Darshan Singh Bhuller's Sita, an exotically sculpted duet, starts off promisingly, with the dancers tensing and folding their bodies through a series of taut embraces. When the movement becomes more extrovert, however, it fails to chime with the dancers' personal styles. Bhuller's halting vocabulary makes both of them appear self-conscious and even inarticulate. Gillian Lynne's Some You Win is a jazzy ensemble number starring Mukhamedov as a guy on the make and Asylmuratova as the stranger with whom he falls in love. Lynne's choreography allows the former to look charmingly laddish, but discovers nothing remarkable in the latter. It's a throwaway piece that looks as if it has been made in haste - as does the show as a whole. Though Mukhamedov has assembled some real dance talent, most of it looks either under-rehearsed or miscast. Interestingly, the best piece is William Tuckett's modest duet, Unobtrusive Detail, whose invention and directness cut through the gala flim-flam.  Till Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Music review
fields.standfirst:
The Shout
BAC, London
****
fields.trailText: The BAC is celebrating the end of its annual opera festival with a party: dips, crisps and drinks on trestle tables and a trio playing Brazilian tunes. A few moments before midnight, composer Orlando Gough, the Shout's co-founder/leader, peers up into the crowd pressed around the balcony of the grand staircase. Suddenly, Richard Chew, the Shout's other leader/founder, cries out.
fields.body:
The BAC is celebrating the end of its annual opera festival with a party: dips, crisps and drinks on trestle tables and a trio playing Brazilian tunes. A few moments before midnight, composer Orlando Gough, the Shout's co-founder/leader, peers up into the crowd pressed around the balcony of the grand staircase. Suddenly, Richard Chew, the Shout's other leader/founder, cries out.

As we swivel round to see what's happening, Wills Morgan, who has just materialised behind us, sings another impassioned phrase. And then comes another response - a close-textured chant from the remaining Shout members, planted among the partygoers and ticket holders waiting for the concert to begin.

We're experiencing a fragment of The Shouting Fence, usually performed in the open air with 80-odd singers. After a five-minute taste of Chew and Gough's magnum opus (previously heard only at the South Bank and the Bath Festival), we file into the auditorium for the concert.

Despite an absence of funding, commissions and establishment support, the Shout continues to develop an ensemble sound and attitude like no other. It encompasses at least half a dozen different singing styles and traditions, with the freewheeling flexibility of a jazz trio and the power and range of a classical choir twice its size. It is entertaining, funny and deadly serious. It is full of enormous egos and talents, yet they work effortlessly together to create intricate and contemporary textures, hocketing effects and subtle backgrounds with no apparent effort or tension: all the energy is directed towards the audience.

The music is committed to memory, giving the singers a means of audience communication that few "contemporary" groups have. In a little more than two years they have established a signature sound that transcends the individual components: though several key regulars couldn't make Saturday's gig, they sounded as good as ever.

The Shout sang songs from its forthcoming album On Arrival (Shaping the Invisible), such as Why Do You Sing?, And the Days Are Not Full Enough, and Tall Stories, an ambitious, complex work portraying the immigrant workers who built New York's skyscrapers in the early years of the 20th century. We also heard a first performance - Gough's Dream of an Insomniac, which involved an asymmetric chant of "one-two, one-two-three, one-two-three sheep" reminiscent of one of Philip Glass's more soporific operas.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Pop review
fields.standfirst:
Sisters of Mercy
The Forum, London
***
fields.trailText: "I'm getting bored," thinks Doktor Avalanche. "I've been playing this jaunty shuffle beat for nigh on 20 minutes. When are the rest of the band going to turn up, for heaven's sake?" He carries on shuffling while the crowd chatters and smokes, until at last he senses a surge in the electrical system, and a crimson flood of guitars bathes him in ecstasy. Now he is licensed to rock.
fields.body:
"I'm getting bored," thinks Doktor Avalanche. "I've been playing this jaunty shuffle beat for nigh on 20 minutes. When are the rest of the band going to turn up, for heaven's sake?" He carries on shuffling while the crowd chatters and smokes, until at last he senses a surge in the electrical system, and a crimson flood of guitars bathes him in ecstasy. Now he is licensed to rock.

Doktor Avalanche, of course, is a drum machine. The Sisters of Mercy have, wisely, never employed a human drummer. The uncanny precision of the bass drum and the futuristic violence of the snare remind us that the Sisters forged the template for all the Chemical Brothers-style techno-rock that flared in the mid-90s.

The Sisters have been around so long that frontman Andrew Eldritch's trademark Aviator sunglasses are back in fashion - and, for all I know, so is his white polo-neck sweater. But this is not a band given to visual excess: the musicians prefer to stand backlit, an anonymous brotherhood, while Eldritch prowls through the green and purple smoke.

While Doktor Avalanche pounds and clatters, the guitars crunch out power chords. Eldritch alternates harsh muttering with Bowie-esque yodelling, or those howls with falsetto attacks so beloved of New Romantics. In between songs he growls soothingly in German.

Then one guitarist lets rip the chords that introduce Dominion. "Some day, some way - Dominion!" choruses the crowd. The inexorable riffing offers a seductive illusion of power: the audience is made to feel that, in some way, it is causing the music to happen, driving the riffs through force of collective will.

The Sisters of Mercy offer glorious rallying hymns for the downtrodden, and for that we salute them. But they didn't play This Corrosion, and for that we are inconsolable.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Chelsea 2 - 2 Arsenal
fields.trailText: Chelsea Cudicini, Panucci, Babayaro, Leboeuf, Desailly, Poyet, Hasselbaink, Wise, Le Saux, Di Matteo, Zola. Subs: Hitchcock, Melchiot, Flo, Morris, Gudjohnsen.
fields.body:
Chelsea Cudicini, Panucci, Babayaro, Leboeuf, Desailly, Poyet, Hasselbaink, Wise, Le Saux, Di Matteo, Zola. Subs: Hitchcock, Melchiot, Flo, Morris, Gudjohnsen.

Arsenal Seaman, Dixon, Keown, Pires, Lauren, Henry, Parlour, Silvinho, Grimandi, Luzhny, Kanu. Subs: Ljungberg, Bergkamp, Wiltord, Lukic, Vernazza.

Referee M Riley

1 Chelsea kick off, pass it about and win an early free kick. Nothing nasty. Yet.
3 Leboeuf miskicks and Henry has a pop from 40 yards. Worth a go but Cudicini is down quickly to his right to smother the weak shot.
5 Chelsea put their first half-decent move together down the right. Then Grimandi runs full pelt into Wise, knocking him over. Come on, boys, play nicely.
6 Panucci sends a ball down the right-hand channel into the path of the onrushing Di Matteo. Seaman senses the danger and comes out to block the ball with his legs on the edge of the area.
8 Pires and Henry roll smoothly down the left flank and win a corner. Kanu, jumping majestically, beats Cudicini to the resulting set piece, but he fails to connect and the first chance of the match is wasted.
9 Almost immediately, Parlour picks up the ball and bustles to the edge of the area. He pulls back the trigger and shoots and oh dear.
11 Some nice Chelsea interplay on the edge of the Arsenal box. Poyet shoots harmlessly wide.
14 Arsenal win another corner. Meanwhile, Keown and Le Saux point and rant at each other like a couple of blubbing schoolkids. When the kick is finally taken, Grimandi wastes the latest easy free header by glancing the ball wide. Chelsea better watch themselves.
16 This bit was good. Wise, out on the right, curls a lovely cross in towards Hasselbaink, who has peeled away from a static Keown. The Dutch striker places his header to Seaman's left and looks on in disbelief as it's fingertipped away. Great football all round - apart from Keown's contribution, obviously.
21 We're in a period where potentially nice moves keep breaking down because players keep making sloppy loose passes. Great.
24 The first booking - Silvinho is diddled by Panucci near the corner flag and trips him up. Zola takes the resulting free kick and plants the ball on the head of Desailly who, five yards out in the centre of the goalmouth, can only score. Sadly for Chelsea, Leboeuf decides to steal the glory for himself, pushes in first and slaps it wide with his big greedy head.
28 Arsenal are struggling to get the ball at the moment. Luckily, Chelsea aren't doing too much with it.
30 GOAL Chelsea 1 - 0 Arsenal What do you know? Hasselbaink takes the ball off Luzhny, who has fallen over for no reason twenty yards out. There's still a bit to do, but he slides the ball to his right, takes a couple of steps and smashes the ball past Seaman, who by rights should have had a chance to save it from that range but this time had none.
36 Lauren strokes a 40-yard ball down the right to the feet of Henry, who goes at Desailly. He twists and turns the big defender, making space to drag a shot across the face of goal. Not perfect, but more promising for the Arse.
39 Le Saux upends Lauren, who is beginning to cause Chelsea bother. From the free kick, Arsenal knock it about until they create an opening. Parlour curls in a lovely ball from the right to Henry, who is waiting by the penalty spot. The striker powers in a header but it's straight at Cudicini.
44 Poyet smashes a ball towards Hasselbaink, who is hanging around on the right wing. Soon enough, the ball is despatched into the Arsenal box - luckily Keown is awake this time, and he gets his head in the way to clear the danger.

Half-time Chelsea 1 - 0 Arsenal

46 Arsenal start the ball rolling again
47 and almost immediately win a corner. Pires whips the ball in and - for the third time in the match so far - an Arsenal player has an easy header from a corner. Grimandi, six yards out, puts it high and wide.
49 Lauren skins Babayaro on the Chelsea right and plays a ball along the floor to the feet of Kanu, who, with his back to goal, spins round Desailly with one touch. He unluckily crashes his superb shot onto the underside of the crossbar. The ball pops out to the feet of Parlour, who displays hitherto unknown circus skills by shinning the ball away from the goalface.
53 Le Saux is booked for pressing his studs into the shin of his old mate Dixon - it could (and possibly should) have been a red.
56 Parlour nearly has Le Saux's legs off with a pretty little lunge. Coincidence?
57 GOAL Chelsea 2 - 0 Arsenal Leboeuf humps a free kick towards the Arsenal box. Poyet chests it down into the path of Zola, who doesn't seem to have enough time to get a shot in. But he does, flicking his boot early at the dropping ball before the onrushing Keown can make a challenge. The ball sails past Seaman and settles perfectly in the left-hand corner of the Arsenal net. Now can Kanu do it again?
60 A little skirmish between Grimandi and Panucci is quickly calmed down by the referee and, strangely, Keown.
65 Chelsea well in charge. A couple of corners here, a crisp passing move there. Arsenal are once again finding it difficult to put their foot on the ball.
67 Keown gifts the ball to Hasselbaink, and it's one on one. But the England defender recovers well to push the Chelsea man wide and blocks his shot.
69 Zola rolls in a cross from the right between Seaman and his defenders. It's a brilliantly inviting ball, but Poyet can't quite stretch out his leg to guide it in.
70 Here's an attacking substitution for you: Parlour and Dixon go off for Arsenal, while Bergkamp and - for his debut - Wiltord come on. You can't say it's not a brave move.
71 Now it's Gianluca Vialli's turn to play with the electronic numbers board. Poyet goes off and Melchiot comes on.
76 GOAL Chelsea 2 - 1 Arsenal Silvinho slips the ball past the Chelsea back four, who are standing square and still. Henry is suddenly in space down the left and passes the ball past Cudicini and into the right-hand side of the Chelsea net. Surely not?!?
77 Before the restart, some changes. Flo for Zola, Ljungberg for Pires - you know who they play for. Chelsea immediately look shaky, and, let's face it, it's no wonder.
79 Bad boy Le Saux goes off early but it's not a red card. He's replaced by Morris.
82 Flo runs at Keown, Hasselabink twists and turns, Di Matteo takes a wild pop. No end product, but all this is eating up the clock.
85 Hasselbaink picks up the ball wide on the left, turns and curls an unstoppable shot around Seaman. But the right-hand post gets in the way and it pings away harmlessly. 86 GOAL Chelsea 2 - 2 Arsenal Arsenal immediately go down the other end to sicken their opponents. Do you remember Nigel Winterburn's long-range goal here a couple of years ago? Well, this one is almost a carbon copy. Except it's better. And more dramatic. Silvinho runs onto a loose ball which is harmlessly bouncing on the edge of the Chelsea area and smashes it into the top left corner. Jaw-dropping. Cudicini had no chance.
90 Four minutes of injury time coming up. Chelsea pin Arsenal back. Bergkamp wins the ball with his hand and picks out Henry, who is clear 20 yards out. Justice is done when the Arsenal striker sidefoots the ball into the crowd. A few more passes and the final whistle blows.

Full time Chelsea 2 - 2 Arsenal

fields.headline: Doors open, minds closed
fields.trailText: Mark Lattimer: When Blair got in, the doors opened. Charities and pressure groups which had been battling for years outside the stony walls of Whitehall suddenly found themselves invited into the warmth of government.
fields.body:
When Blair got in, the doors opened. Charities and pressure groups which had been battling for years outside the stony walls of Whitehall suddenly found themselves invited into the warmth of government. Dialogues, compacts, placements; liaison panels, working groups, consultative committees. The names may have differed, but the message was the same: we care about your issues and we want to hear what you have to say.

Three years on, many charity and public sector leaders are finding that the doors may be open, but the minds remain closed. For campaigners working on welfare and the environment, it has often been a slow process of disillusionment, as they realise that ministers are good at lending a sympathetic ear - but unwilling or unable to deliver.

A few have got a little of what they want. Civil liberties groups were delighted when the government moved to introduce the Human Rights Act, although they found that Labour's initial reforming zeal was soon replaced by the old Whitehall fondness for secrecy and control in the shape of a watered down freedom of information bill and legislation enabling the state to snoop on private email.

Others have simply felt betrayed. Refugee groups had been reassured by Labour's principled rhetoric in opposition, and devoted countless hours to a two-year long consultation process on reform of the asylum system, only to find themselves confronted with new immigration legislation that sought to exclude, impoverish and criminalise asylum-seekers.

Campaigners who have got little from Labour need to get tough. Surveying the success factors for hundreds of recent campaigns for the new Campaigning Handbook, I noted the number of times organisations had used a new generation of techniques, such as legal actions, news management and internet campaigning, to force government to the negotiating table.

The opportunities for such influence naturally peak in a pre-election year. Before the 1997 election, the Labour Party imposed a moratorium on any new spending commitments, following the decision to stick within Tory expenditure limits. Campaigners for better welfare provision were given a lecture about the real world, and in effect asked to take it on trust. This time, that argument won't wash. Any party which wants to win next time knows it needs to deliver on health, education and welfare. But the time for getting clear commitments from the politicians will soon run out. Campaigners need to negotiate hard now if they are going to get anything more after the next election than an open door and a friendly smile.

 Mark Lattimer is author of the Campaigning Handbook, published next week at £15.95 by the Directory of Social Change (020-7209 5151)

fields.headline: Misgivings on 'free' schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Conservative councillors appear to be on a collision course with their leadership over proposals to abolish local education authorities and create a network of "free schools".
fields.body:
Conservative councillors appear to be on a collision course with their leadership over proposals to abolish local education authorities and create a network of "free schools".

At least one Tory authority has written to William Hague complaining that the plans could be a bureaucratic nightmare if schools were forced to break away from councils.

Others argued that Mr Hague and his team had failed to appreciate the complexities of creating schools in which governors would have complete responsibility for management and setting teachers' salaries.

He also faces criticism that plans to abolish LEAs sit uneasily alongside a commitment to strengthen councils, with greater financial freedom for town halls that pass a "good behaviour" test.

Paul Bettison, leader of Bracknell Forest borough council in Berkshire, yesterday said he had written to Mr Hague to express the misgivings of his councillors. "While we are 100% behind schools having any responsibility they wish to claim, we would like to know if they will be allowed to stay with the LEA," he said.

The chairman of governors of the borough's biggest comprehensive would be responsible for a £5m annual budget. "Are you going to say 'By the way, we don't pay you, give you mileage, or even reimburse your telephone calls'?"

Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, Tory leader of Kent county council, has argued that councils are essential to take big strategic decisions, including "whether to close a school, where to build a new one, and handling complaints and pupil exclusions".

He said yesterday education authorities would continue to have a role under a Tory government and denied there was friction between councillors and the party leadership.

fields.headline: The best producer scene
fields.standfirst: Timecode
fields.trailText: Timecode
fields.body:
At the Los Angeles offices of film company Red Mullet, a group of producers sit in conference.

"Guys, we've got a situation..." begins Evan Watz (Xander Berkeley). "Ah, basically, there's an outbreak of herpes on set. And it's really a nightmare. The insurance people have given us two days..."

"Have they found out who's spreading it?" asks Darren Fetzer (Steven Weber).

"Ah, I think they're trying to avoid naming names."

Onyx Richardson (Golden Brooks) interrupts.

"Oh, our set has been having a few problems."

"Yeah?"

"Yeah. I had to fire the AD. I'm sorry. You know, I didn't want to get sister girl on him, but he challenged me. I had to... But morale is up!"

"It is?"

"Yeah."

"So, we boost morale by firing people..."

"Oh," interjects another executive (Holly Hunter), "I had to fire six people, basically because someone was caught embezzling funds..."

"Woah!"

"Uh-huh. Also, the test cards came back. And what they said was that it wasn't scary. It was more funny."

The rest of the producers look up. Fetzer picks up where his colleague left off.

"Right, there's been a few problems with the sound. The scene where the Buddhist monks set themselves alight, unfortunately the sound effects are such that instead of crackling, they're kind of... popping and exploding."

There's an uncomfortable pause.

"And it's giving a comic overtone to what is really quite a serious visual."

See also: Barton Fink, The Player, The Producers

Don't see also: Who Framed Roger Rabbit?

Pointless trivia: When she was 15, Holly Hunter came eighth in a national poultry-judging competition.

fields.headline: Charles Saatchi
fields.standfirst: Everything you ever needed to know about art collector and advertiser Charles Saatchi
fields.trailText: Everything you ever needed to know about art collector and advertiser Charles Saatchi.
fields.body:
1. Art collector and advertiser Charles Saatchi has had a good old clear out and got rid of some art that he didn't want.

2. And the lucky beneficaries are not the refuse dump and local garbologists but needy art galleries looking for a bit of Jordan Baseman or Richard Woods.

3. Mr Saatchi does this every year. He buys the entire studio contents of artists he likes and either exhibits them in his Saatchi gallery or donates them to less noted institutions in, for example, Swindon and Aberdeen.

4. Face it, he's a flamboyant man - in July he spent more than £150,000 on an old bed.

5. One day, perhaps, he will put it in his £40,000 tent.

6. Saatchi made his fortune in advertising. With his brother Maurice he set up the agency Saatchi and Saatchi which, among other "achievements," helped to put Margaret Thatcher in power.

7. The brothers went on a spending spree in the 1980s - when they tried to buy Midland Bank - but were caught out by the 90s recession and quit the agency in 1995.

8. Since then Maurice has become Conservative party treasury spokesman in the House of Lords and Charles a patron of the arts.

9. 1997's Sensation at the Royal Academy of Arts cemented the repuations of Damien Hirst, Tracey Emin and Chris Ofili.

10. The show attracted some high profile criticism when it exhibited at the Brooklyn Museum of Art but Saatchi is confident enough to reprise his favourite artists with this year's Ant Noises.

webTitle: An extra £47m for the dome - but even that may not be enough

fields.headline: An extra £47m for the dome - but even that may not be enough
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The government last night faced growing calls to shut the Millennium Dome after a further £47m of lottery cash was approved to avoid bankruptcy for the second time, breaking a recent commitment that it needed no extra funds.
fields.body:
The government last night faced growing calls to shut the Millennium Dome after a further £47m of lottery cash was approved to avoid bankruptcy for the second time, breaking a recent commitment that it needed no extra funds.

Millennium commissioners sparked outrage by agreeing the emergency grant in a political face-saving deal after admitting as few as 4.5m visitors will buy tickets for the Greenwich complex, little more than a third of the 12m originally predicted.

The commission said the latest application from new millennium experience company (NMEC) followed an external review of the company's financial position.

"The review has confirmed the commission's concern that there are serious failings in NMEC's financial management," the commission said in a statement.

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the Frenchman hailed as a saviour when he arrived from Disneyland Paris this year, was effectively demoted when he was stripped of his control over its financial running in a fresh management shake-up.

The chairman, David Quarmby, who replaced sacked Bob Ayling last May, quit the post after five months to become deputy chairman. He was replaced by City troubleshooter David James, who promised to work for free.

The latest £47m injection takes to £179m the total of public funds pledged this year to keep afloat an enterprise initially dependent on a £399m lottery grant.

But Mr James admitted he could not guarantee the figures would add up even now, as fresh doubts were cast last night on the dome's viability despite already sucking in £578m - effectively a £128 per head subsidy for every ticket buyer and equivalent to four times the controversial subsidy at the Royal Opera House.

One official at the NMEC, which runs the dome, privately doubted that the £47m would be enough to keep it open until December.

Mr James, currently chairman of the Robinson's soft drinks company, disclosed that the dome had been insolvent with £15m in unpaid bills. A Robinson's colleague, John Darlington, is to be paid a fee to organise the sale to a consortium backed by the Japanese investment bank, Nomura, after being made an executive of the company.

Mr James held out little prospect of the huge sum handed over ever being repaid after its sale, which is due to be finalised at the end of the year.

"I don't think there is any prospect of any cash recovery once the process of the sale has been completed," said Mr James.

Yesterday's announcement was humiliating for Mr Gerbeau who in May said he had "fixed the dome" and would "not ask the commission for any more handouts", claiming they were loans, though Mr James made clear they could never be repaid.

"Whatever P-Y has said, he said with the best knowledge that he had at the time," said Mr James.

The dome was intended by Tony Blair to represent all that was good about "Cool Britannia" and form a springboard to a second election victory after over-riding cabinet doubts to continue a project inherited from the last Tory administration. But what was supposed to be the greatest show on earth has proved an embarrassing financial black hole.

More than 60 Labour MPs signed a Commons motion before Parliament broke up for the summer recess demanding that no more money be spent on the Greenwich white elephant.

Last night backbencher Bob Marshall-Andrews called the latest spending spree a "national scandal" and added: "It will never recoup any of this money. It is completely dead money and it is an outrage. Worse than that there is a total lack of accountability for this public money. Parliament is not even sitting."

The Tories demanded the head of Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister and close friend of the prime minister who inherited the dome from Peter Mandelson.

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, said: "If this is not a resignation matter, then I don't know what is. Lord Falconer is the sole shareholder in NMEC, which has been accused of serious financial mismanagement."

Lord Falconer said: "Of course, it is very, very regrettable but in terms of the public interest it is the right course to take."

A two-hour meeting of the commission, chaired by Chris Smith, and attended by Mo Mowlam and Michael Heseltine, had decided earlier to approve the further £47m despite assurances in May, when another £29m had been agreed, that it was the last rescue package.

A commission statement said: "The commission is extremely sorry that there should be yet another call on lottery funds. It welcomes the full review being undertaken by the national audit office and believes that there will be important lessons to be learnt about the management of major national projects."

Mr James, 62, said he was approached four weeks ago and PricewaterhouseCoopers had gone over the books.

Shutting it before the Nomura consortium was ready to take over the dome as a theme park, he claimed, would cost up to £40m more in redundancies, termination of contracts and disconnection fees.

Asked why he had agreed to become the dome's executive chairman and work for free, four days a week until the end of the year, Mr James said: "Like Everest, it is there, you have to climb it. I'm even providing my own secretary, my own car and costs."

webTitle: Lib Dems take first steps on election warpath

fields.headline: Lib Dems take first steps on election warpath
fields.standfirst: Main points of pre-manifesto
fields.trailText: Main points of pre-manifesto
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats today began setting out their stall for next year's general election, resolving to increase taxation and benefits in their pre-manifesto document Freedom in a Liberal Society.

The party leader, Charles Kennedy, confirmed that fiscal policy would be the important battleground for the election.

"We remain of the view that there is a big argument to be had at the next election, and we are quite clear what side of the street we will be on when this argument takes place, about the decent funding of quality public services," he told BBC Radio 4's World at One programme. "You can't get something for nothing."

Among the proposals were plans to introduce a new top rate tax of 50p on those earning more than £100,000 a year, while reducing taxation for those worse off by abolishing the 10p starting rate on income tax.

The party plans to invest in the NHS, recruiting and training an extra 5,000 doctors and 20,000 nurses over three years. Prescription charges are also to be cut, while charges for dental and eye check-ups would be scrapped entirely, subsidised by a 10p increase on cigarettes.

Contradicting William Hague's reform plans for state pensions, the Liberal Democrats also pledge to increase the basic state pension and make extra payments to the over-75s and over-80s. Child benefits are also to be increased for the youngest child under five.

The pre-manifesto also promised more cash for the police, education and public transport.

The Lib Dems' political opponents rounded on the proposals. The Treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, described the plans as "a menu without the prices".

He said: "Their sums simply don't add up. We knew already that by their own admission there was a £3bn black hole at the heart of the Liberal Democrats' spending plans, but they have avoided all of the difficult decisions on tax and spending."

Conservative party vice-chairman Tim Collins said: "All the Lib Dems have told us in their pre-manifesto is that they are determined to increase taxes and scrap the pound. They are, however, silent about their desperate desire to drag Britain into a single European superstate.

"Their spending plans would mean huge tax hikes for many people. The mainstream majority in Britain will see straight through these ridiculous proposals. With Charles Kennedy continuing to peddle this kind of lunacy, it's clear that a Lib Dem vote is a wasted vote."

Elsewhere in the pre-manifesto, Mr Kennedy's party continued its traditional commitment to radical constitutional reform and civil rights.

Full proportional representation, abolition of the House of Lords, an extension of the electoral franchise to 16-year-olds and European constitution were outlined, as well as measures to combat discrimination and ensure asylum-seekers are treated fairly.

On defence, as Labour party documents this week revealed plans to drop the "ethical" tag from current foreign policy, the Liberal Democrats promise to end subsidies for arms sold to foreign regimes and work for the elimination of all nuclear weapons.

fields.headline: Liberal Democrat pre-manifesto digest
fields.standfirst: Liberal Democrats take first step on election warpath
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrats take first step on election warpath.
fields.body:
Health
 Recruit and train an extra 5,000 doctors and an extra 20,000 nurses
 Cut prescription charges
 Scrap charges for dental and eye check-ups, using funding from a 10p increase on cigarettes

Education
 Reduce class sizes for five to 11-year-olds and introduce a maximum average class size of 25 in primary schools
 Provide free nursery places for all three and four-year-olds whose parents want them
 Abolish tuition fees for university students

Pensions, wages and benefits
 Increase the basic state pension and make extra payments to the over-75s and over-80s
 Reduce taxation for the lowest paid by abolishing the 10p starting rate of income tax
 Introduce a new top-rate tax of 50p on those earning more than £100,000 a year
 Increase child benefit for the youngest child under five and scrap the Child Support Agency

Law and order
 Fund an extra 6,000 police officers

Transport
 Improve public transport with funding from urban congestion and workplace car parking charges
 Lower freight vehicle excise duty

Economy
 Strengthen the independence of the Bank of England
 Set out a positive timetable and policies for achieving a sustainable entry into the euro

Business and innovation
 Cut business rates for small businesses
 Promote a knowledge-based economy by boosting research and promoting links between universities and businesses

The constitution
 Work to introduce a form of proportional representation through the Single Transferable Vote system
 Replace the House of Lords with a smaller directly elected

Senate
 Lower the voting age to 16 and allow people to stand for office at the same age

Civil liberties
 Introduce an Equality Act to tackle all discrimination and create a human rights commission
 Retain the right to jury trials
 Replace the voucher system for asylum seekers and ensure their applications are dealt with in a speedy, fair way

Europe
 Argue for a constitution for the European Union and strengthen anti-fraud measures

Defence
 Work for the elimination of all nuclear weapons and push for a new round of arms reduction talks
 End subsidies for arms sold to foreign regimes by ending the practice of the export credit guarantee department
