fields.headline: Betraying youngsters
fields.trailText: Kirsty Scott on the education crisis in Scotland.
fields.body:
Candice Napier and Lawrence Broadley are 16, going on 17. Two ordinary Glasgow teenagers, each with a very personal goal.

Candice wants to be an occupational therapist; Lawrence an aeronautical engineer. So they studied hard for the higher exams that would get them into university and on to their chosen career track. Candice paid £12 an hour for extra tutoring, learned sign language and arranged work experience in a care home. Lawrence, an A-grade pupil, applied himself to his books.

Their ambitions were handed back to them three weeks ago, brutally dismantled and delivered in a plain brown envelope. Lawrence failed physics and graphics, his two best subjects. Candice failed chemistry and barely scraped a pass in everything else. Doors began to close.

This week the pair are pinning what's left of their hopes on appeals by their schools and today's launch of the Scottish parliament inquiry into Britain's worst education crisis.

Only, no one seems to know what went wrong; just that something profound and pernicious has blighted the results for the class of 2000.

The Scottish Qualifications Authority insists only 10% of all 147,000 pupils who sat higher, standard grade and sixth year exams have been affected by "data management issues". That means that crucial pieces of information, such as continual assessment grades, were not fed into the SQA computer system in every case. Why and by whom the SQA will not say, although several senior managers have already been ousted.

But that doesn't explain Candice and Lawrence, and the authority still refuses to accept that the problem goes much deeper - that there was something unsound about the marking for this year's exams, and something equally flawed with the culture of the SQA itself.

This is an agency that could not even properly fax schools a list of incomplete results; that didn't carry out customary computer checks on expected and actual grades; and that reportedly tried to pressurise inexperienced markers to grade a growing backlog of papers.

And, throughout it all, it has been supported by the education minister, Sam Galbraith.

The Scottish National party and the Tories have been calling for Mr Galbraith's head with a fervour that implies his leaving will end the matter. But it won't; if the minister has been right about one thing, it is that he is almost irrelevant at this point.

Almost, but not quite. Because this skilled neurosurgeon and seasoned politician - the man who spotted Donald Dewar's faulty heart valve and was trusted to sort out the section 28 imbroglio - ought to have seen this coming.

He had been warned for months by teachers that there were problems implementing the complicated new higher exam programme, ironically designed to make the qualification system more inclusive, and there were steady press leaks of serious administrative problems at the SQA.

His excuse that he could not be held responsible for the workings of an autonomous agency does not hold. Education is the executive's flagship policy and his baby. There is little doubt that he should go and growing evidence that he will go once he has done what he can to clear up the mess.

But if he has been careless, then the Scottish executive has been culpable. There was no effort to recall MSPs from recess when the magnitude of the crisis became apparent, and ministers would only comment when pressed to do so by the media.

Instead of a full debate today, discussion has been limited to a ministerial statement and 30 minutes of questions, a blatant betrayal of accountability. The whole point of devolution was to bring government closer to the people. To respond as a nation to uniquely Scottish issues. Not to close ranks and protect your own at the first sign of trouble.

fields.bodyText: Candice Napier and Lawrence Broadley are 16, going on 17. Two ordinary Glasgow teenagers, each with a very personal goal. Candice wants to be an occupational therapist; Lawrence an aeronautical engineer. So they studied hard for the higher exams that would get them into university and on to their chosen career track. Candice paid £12 an hour for extra tutoring, learned sign language and arranged work experience in a care home. Lawrence, an A-grade pupil, applied himself to his books. Their ambitions were handed back to them three weeks ago, brutally dismantled and delivered in a plain brown envelope. Lawrence failed physics and graphics, his two best subjects. Candice failed chemistry and barely scraped a pass in everything else. Doors began to close. This week the pair are pinning what's left of their hopes on appeals by their schools and today's launch of the Scottish parliament inquiry into Britain's worst education crisis. Only, no one seems to know what went wrong; just that something profound and pernicious has blighted the results for the class of 2000. The Scottish Qualifications Authority insists only 10% of all 147,000 pupils who sat higher, standard grade and sixth year exams have been affected by "data management issues". That means that crucial pieces of information, such as continual assessment grades, were not fed into the SQA computer system in every case. Why and by whom the SQA will not say, although several senior managers have already been ousted. But that doesn't explain Candice and Lawrence, and the authority still refuses to accept that the problem goes much deeper - that there was something unsound about the marking for this year's exams, and something equally flawed with the culture of the SQA itself. This is an agency that could not even properly fax schools a list of incomplete results; that didn't carry out customary computer checks on expected and actual grades; and that reportedly tried to pressurise inexperienced markers to grade a growing backlog of papers. And, throughout it all, it has been supported by the education minister, Sam Galbraith. The Scottish National party and the Tories have been calling for Mr Galbraith's head with a fervour that implies his leaving will end the matter. But it won't; if the minister has been right about one thing, it is that he is almost irrelevant at this point. Almost, but not quite. Because this skilled neurosurgeon and seasoned politician - the man who spotted Donald Dewar's faulty heart valve and was trusted to sort out the section 28 imbroglio - ought to have seen this coming. He had been warned for months by teachers that there were problems implementing the complicated new higher exam programme, ironically designed to make the qualification system more inclusive, and there were steady press leaks of serious administrative problems at the SQA. webTitle: Lib Dems take first steps on election warpath

fields.headline: Lib Dems take first steps on election warpath
fields.standfirst: Main points of pre-manifesto
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats today began setting out their stall for next year's general election, resolving to increase taxation and benefits in their pre-manifesto document Freedom in a Liberal Society.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats today began setting out their stall for next year's general election, resolving to increase taxation and benefits in their pre-manifesto document Freedom in a Liberal Society.

The party leader, Charles Kennedy, confirmed that fiscal policy would be the important battleground for the election.

"We remain of the view that there is a big argument to be had at the next election, and we are quite clear what side of the street we will be on when this argument takes place, about the decent funding of quality public services," he told BBC Radio 4's World at One programme. "You can't get something for nothing."

Among the proposals were plans to introduce a new top rate tax of 50p on those earning more than £100,000 a year, while reducing taxation for those worse off by abolishing the 10p starting rate on income tax.

The party plans to invest in the NHS, recruiting and training an extra 5,000 doctors and 20,000 nurses over three years. Prescription charges are also to be cut, while charges for dental and eye check-ups would be scrapped entirely, subsidised by a 10p increase on cigarettes.

Contradicting William Hague's reform plans for state pensions, the Liberal Democrats also pledge to increase the basic state pension and make extra payments to the over-75s and over-80s. Child benefits are also to be increased for the youngest child under five.

The pre-manifesto also promised more cash for the police, education and public transport.

The Lib Dems' political opponents rounded on the proposals. The Treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, described the plans as "a menu without the prices".

He said: "Their sums simply don't add up. We knew already that by their own admission there was a £3bn black hole at the heart of the Liberal Democrats' spending plans, but they have avoided all of the difficult decisions on tax and spending."

Conservative party vice-chairman Tim Collins said: "All the Lib Dems have told us in their pre-manifesto is that they are determined to increase taxes and scrap the pound. They are, however, silent about their desperate desire to drag Britain into a single European superstate.

"Their spending plans would mean huge tax hikes for many people. The mainstream majority in Britain will see straight through these ridiculous proposals. With Charles Kennedy continuing to peddle this kind of lunacy, it's clear that a Lib Dem vote is a wasted vote."

Elsewhere in the pre-manifesto, Mr Kennedy's party continued its traditional commitment to radical constitutional reform and civil rights.

Full proportional representation, abolition of the House of Lords, an extension of the electoral franchise to 16-year-olds and European constitution were outlined, as well as measures to combat discrimination and ensure asylum-seekers are treated fairly.

On defence, as Labour party documents this week revealed plans to drop the "ethical" tag from current foreign policy, the Liberal Democrats promise to end subsidies for arms sold to foreign regimes and work for the elimination of all nuclear weapons.

fields.headline: Liberal Democrat pre-manifesto digest
fields.standfirst: Liberal Democrats take first step on election warpath
fields.trailText:
Health
• Recruit and train an extra 5,000 doctors and an extra 20,000 nurses
• Cut prescription charges
• Scrap charges for dental and eye check-ups, using funding from a 10p increase on cigarettes
fields.body:
Health
 Recruit and train an extra 5,000 doctors and an extra 20,000 nurses
 Cut prescription charges
 Scrap charges for dental and eye check-ups, using funding from a 10p increase on cigarettes

Education
 Reduce class sizes for five to 11-year-olds and introduce a maximum average class size of 25 in primary schools
 Provide free nursery places for all three- and four-year-olds whose parents want them
 Abolish tuition fees for university students

Pensions, wages and benefits
 Increase the basic state pension and make extra payments to the over-75s and over-80s
 Reduce taxation for the lowest paid by abolishing the 10p starting rate of income tax
 Introduce a new top-rate tax of 50p on those earning more than £100,000 a year
 Increase child benefit for the youngest child under five and scrap the Child Support Agency

Law and order
 Fund an extra 6,000 police officers

Transport
 Improve public transport with funding from urban congestion and workplace car parking charges
 Lower freight vehicle excise duty

Economy
 Strengthen the independence of the Bank of England
 Set out a positive timetable and policies for achieving a sustainable entry into the euro

Business and innovation
 Cut business rates for small businesses
 Promote a knowledge-based economy by boosting research and promoting links between universities and businesses

The constitution
 Work to introduce a form of proportional representation through the Single Transferable Vote system
 Replace the House of Lords with a smaller directly elected Senate
 Lower the voting age to 16 and allow people to stand for office at the same age

Civil liberties
 Introduce an Equality Act to tackle all discrimination and create a human rights commission
 Retain the right to jury trials
 Replace the voucher system for asylum seekers and ensure their applications are dealt with in a speedy, fair way

Europe
 Argue for a constitution for the European Union and strengthen anti-fraud measures

Defence
 Work for the elimination of all nuclear weapons and push for a new round of arms reduction talks
 End subsidies for arms sold to foreign regimes by ending the practice of the export credit guarantee department

fields.headline: Snapping,  Tearing, and  Warping
fields.trailText: ANTI-FASH-ISM
fields.body:
ANTI-FASH-ISM

The Fiver wouldn't mind betting a shilling or two that when Nwankwo Kanu was at school he was the quiet one. The sort of kid whose best friend was a beaten-up football, and whose only enemy was the night sky that forced him indoors. But when the ambassador for Nigerian sport, John "Fash the Bash" Fashanu, warned Kanu this week that he "shouldn't go back to Nigeria for his holidays for the next 20 years" if he pulled out of their Olympic squad, something snapped.

"I find the statements made by John Fashanu both reprehensible and hypocritical," a rightly furious Kanu raged earlier today. "It should be remembered that in his playing days he chose to desert Nigeria and play for England instead. He has no right to criticise me when I have given so much to the country I love." And just in case there was any doubt over Kanu's state of mind, he finished by insisting that: "John Fashanu's statements have only strengthened my resolve."

And just to prove that standing up to playground bullies really can work (although the Fiver, for legal reasons can't condemn or condone never mind condom that sort of thing), Fash has apologised for his actions. "Kanu is my brother. He's Nigerian like me," the Bash explained unconvincingly. "Kanu has sweat blood for Nigeria and if it wasn't for serious reasons he would be in Sydney defending the gold medal."

Fash then completed his volte-face by apologising to Arsene Wenger, "who only two weeks ago I had breakfast with - I hope this doesn't sour our relationship. Nigeria and Arsenal are looking to build relationships, not break bridges." Well done the Bash. A long career in diplomacy awaits.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

The Olympian, from Guardian Unlimited

Sign up now for Guardian Unlimited's free daily Olympic email. The Olympian will offer full results, top analysis, a comprehensive guide to coming events and the best gossip.

http://www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/olympian

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A SICK SENSE OF HUMOUR

After another promising England performance, and a good run of form for Spurs, Darren Anderton has gone and got himself injured again and is likely to miss England's upcoming World Cup games with Germany and Finland. He pulled up with a groin injury after crossing the ball one minute into last night's 3-2 comeback victory over Everton. Before bumping his head on the tunnel on the way to the changing room. And crashing his car on the way to the consultant. And scalding himself with the Teasmade this morning, before poking himself in the eye with a cereal spoon.

"I won't know for certain [about the severity of the injury] until I have the scan but it certainly seems as though there is a tear," Sicknote told the London Evening Standard today. "If that is the case then it usually takes around four weeks to sort out. Hopefully, it won't be too serious and I will be back by the middle of next month." We can all dream, can't we.

"It is really frustrating because things had been going so well," Sick boy continued, obviously under the illusion he was on This is Your Life. "I made my England comeback against France and thought that went well enough and I have been pleased with my Tottenham form. Then this happens. I couldn't believe it." Of course. So don't forget to tune in next week, readers, when Patrick Vieira is flabbergasted at receiving a red card, buying some new clothes leaves David Beckham gobsmacked, and Brian Deane cannot contain his astonishment at missing a sitter.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have special feelings for the club and I want to stay. I'm going to have talks with the club when we get home [from a pre-season tour of Scandinavia] and hopefully a contract will be sorted." Straight-talking Sol Campbell back in July.

"I'm a Tottenham player and have no big desire to leave, but I don't see why I should be talking about a new contract at this stage." Straight-talking Sol Campbell today. So he's staying then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S FIGHT NIGHT

It's the evening we've all been waiting for. Yes, it's Chelsea v Arsenal and if there isn't a huge shoot on the pitch involving all 22 players, the ref, a few tattooed supporters, and that hot dog salesman from the Fosters ad, then we'll all be very disappointed. By we, of course, we mean us porky and irresponsible media types who have spent the best part of this week stirring up supposed enmity between French and English players.

Expected Anglo-French altercations include Robert Pires versus Dennis Wise and, of course, Martin Keown versus Marcel Desailly who are expected to be given video screen/score board identification counselling before the match. Wise is expected to feature for the Blues after recovering from a knee knock he picked up in the England game. Arsenal meanwhile look likely to partner Gilles Grimandi with Ray Parlour in central midfield, while Sylvain Wiltord (who may not have scrapped with anyone at all on Saturday) will get a place on the bench.

Scrutiny of this match will be high, with local police set to speak to Mike Reid (oh dear) and his fellow officials about keeping a lid on the game. Arsene Wenger meanwhile has added his own tuppence worth of wisdom. "We will try to go for the ball," he said. "If you expect me to say to the players 'don't go for the ball' then we might as well play feminine football." Which is fair enough, if a little insulting. Even more insulting however was his next remark: "People don't come to football to watch players kick each other." What planet is this man on?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

John Gregory has ended his interest in Celta Vigo's £10m-rated striker Benni McCarthy because of the uncertainty surrounding the transfer system. "It makes sense to wait until after the hearing so that we all know where we stand", reckons John Gregory.

Blackburn Rovers have offered Celtic £1m plus Christian Dailly for Eyal Berkovic, reports the Daily Record. They claim that the Israeli international is desperate to leave Glasgow and that the only stumbling block is that Dailly wants a bumper pay-off before he will leave Rovers.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leicester will find out on Friday whether they will have to travel to Yugoslavia to play their Uefa Cup first round tie with Red Star Belgrade.

Trevor Francis has been given the full backing of the Birmingham board after talks at St Andrews. Francis revealed: "We have cleared the air and we are going on with things in a positive way."

The Imperial Lord Ferg has called for Uefa to investigate the behaviour of Turkish fans. "You hope that UEFA are having a critical and serious look at Turkish fans' behaviour because it is not acceptable what goes on sometimes there really," he said.

The Aston Villa Independent Shareholders Association is calling for club chairman Doug Ellis to be voted out at Friday's annual general meeting because he has too much power. Avisa spokesman Jonathan Collett said: "Given his shareholding and role of chairman, chief executive and director of football, Mr Ellis has too much control, influence and work to do." But Villa's financial director Mark Ansell has attacked Avisa's stance as "neither healthy nor constructive".

Notts County have been taken over by American journalist Albert Scardino and former West Ham chief executive Peter Storrie.

Rangers have beaten off a host of top European clubs to sign Austrian U-16 player Alex Hauser.

Liverpool director Noel White has been reappointed as chairman of the FA international committee.

Northampton have signed Southampton defender Richard Dryden on a month's loan.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Premiership Football - Live: Chelsea v Arsenal (7pm) Blood, thunder, guts, gooners, goals and Richard Keys.

BBC 2: Go on my Son (9pm) More of the same, but with ultra competitive fathers shouting loudly at their little Jonny, instead of Richard Keys.

ITV: The National Football Awards (10pm) Bushy Garry Bushell reckons this Ian Wright-hosted event is "must-see TV."

BBC 1: Match of the Day (10.15pm) Oh yeah? So why will everybody be watching Lineker and co instead, then?

Sky Sports 1: You're on Sky Sports (10.30pm) "He makes Jonathan Pearce look like the bloated half-wit he is AND he's shagged Laura from our office (he was very enthusiastic then as well apparently)," writes Pat Viner. And Pat's not talking about McCaff either, if you catch our drift

Oasis star Noel Gallagher and his wife Meg Mathews have separated nine months after the birth of their daughter, it emerged last night.

The couple, who met in 1994 when the band was in its infancy, have come to an amicable agreement because "they have simply drifted apart over the last year or so", a spokeswoman for Gallagher said.

Gallagher, 33, recently admitted that he met his wife "through drugs" and spent so much of his married life on them he worried he would stop loving her when he gave up. The couple sold their north London home and moved to Buckinghamshire last year in an attempt to build their lives together away from the temptations of the capital. When baby Anais was born in January, Noel described the event as the "best thing ever" to have happened to him.

His spokeswoman said last night: "The couple have lived through, or been together during, the whole meteoric rise of the band and the turbulent years that followed, always under the constant glare of the media. Many things have changed in that time, including themselves it would seem."

She added: "They are still friends and are still devoted to Anais. At the moment, it's a separation."

The split comes at a difficult time for Gallagher, who recently walked out on his band's US tour. Last month his younger brother Liam and his actress wife Patsy Kensit announced they were to divorce.

Both couples wed in 1997 but it was always the elder Gallagher who was deemed to have the more stable marriage.

In an interview in the Radio Times in April, Gallagher said of his wife: "If she left me I'd be destroyed. She's my best friend - I still consider her my girlfriend, not my wife - and I'd never risk what we have for a one-night stand."

fields.headline: Does Curtly dare upset Antigua?
fields.standfirst: In the mid-week instalment of wisden.com's gossip column Charles de Lisle explores Curtly Ambrose's latest dilemma, observes England's heroes dealing with a new phenomenon, and attends cricket's longest night of the year
fields.trailText: Will Curtly dare take his freebie outside Antigua?
fields.body:
Will Curtly dare take his freebie outside Antigua?

There's a little more to come in the procession of events and ovations marking Curtly Ambrose's retirement from Test cricket. At times, they've almost put one in mind of the Queen Mother's fortnight-long 100th birthday celebrations.

That almost unprecedented guard of honour from England's fielders as he walked out to bat for the last time, at The Oval on Monday, and the emotional final send-offs from the buzzing crowd, were not quite the end of the festivities. As has been reported, Curtly is to receive a special present to mark his 400th Test wicket (Mike Atherton, cheaply, at Headingley).

Sandals Resorts, sponsors of the West Indies' tour, have decided to do the obvious and give Curtly and his family a splashy holiday at one of their Caribbean playgrounds. No-one doubts that, after 12 years, 98 Tests and 22,104 deliveries, the great beanpole deserves to put his feet up in style for a few weeks.

But sending a Windies star to a Caribbean resort has a whiff of coals to Newcastle. Also, big Curtly was back in Antigua only a few weeks ago, resting and relaxing for three weeks, between the second and third Tests, at his home in Swetes Village. So he's recently had plenty of sun, sand, rest - and also indulged his favourite hobby (other, perhaps, than making music): fishing with his mates off one of Antigua's 365 scintillating beaches in the evening sunlight.

Sandals' spokesman couldn't be contacted this morning, but it'll be interesting to see which island the Ambroses choose to holiday on. Antiguan pride means that Sandals Antigua may be the only safe choice for a national hero.

When Ambrose took that 400th wicket, Sandals came up with a more original gesture. A huge iced sponge "Curtly cake" was immediately delivered to the press box. More than 60 journalists enjoyed a slice. Says one: "It was delicious, and made a change from our usual fare in the box. As you know, the only way to grab a slice of cake, generally, is to cadge some off the BBC's Test Match Special team."

England stars baffled by groupies

As England's history-making cricketers filed out of their hotel in Chelsea Harbour, car keys dangling, they were surprised to be confronted by a posse of 15 or 20 well-dressed teenage girls.

This scene wasn't all it seemed. Cricket may be sexier now than it was a couple of months ago but the girls weren't actually there to get a glimpse of England's heroes. They were waiting for some other guests at the Conrad International hotel: the Irish boy band Westlife. Alec Stewart, for one, looked quite baffled.

Do of the Week (the eighth in an occasional series)

Occasion The annual dinner of the Cricket Writers' Club, held at the Royal Lancaster Hotel in London. Invariably one of the dos of the year, and this one was no disappointment.

Format Pre-match drinks, then sit-down dinner. The food was rather better than at most cricket dinners: a pastry case filled with asparagus and scrambled eggs, fillet of dover sole, followed by sticky toffee pudding. Close of play, long after the most energetic had moved into the bar for some pretty heavy drinking (in some cases, anyway), was 2.30am. Derek Pringle and Angus Fraser, in prime form as ever, were among the last to leave.

Attendance A record in the club's 55-year history: 342 tickets were sold, most at £30 a head, to newspapers and radio and TV stations, taking tables of 10-12. You couldn't look up from your food without catching sight of a top player. Mike Atherton was there. So were his fellow player-columnists Nasser Hussain, Alec Stewart and Mark Ramprakash. The trio was joined by their injured England team-mate and shop steward Dean Headley in an intriguing after-dinner huddle in a quiet corner of an otherwise very noisy bar. Their conversation went on for about an hour.

Also enjoying themselves Sir Viv Richards and his BBC Test Match Special colleagues Graham Gooch and Donna Symmonds, and Mark Nicholas and Simon Hughes of Channel 4. Steve James, fresh from hitting a triple century for Glamorgan, pitched up too. Colin Croft was very much in evidence, wearing a red bow tie - one way of interpreting a "lounge suits" dress code. England's current stars played it straighter, turning out in dark suits. So did Paul Franks of Nottinghamshire and England's one-day side, who was chosen by the club as the latest Young Cricketer of the Year, and made a gracious little speech - without a note.

Notable absentees Australian stars Shane Warne and Justin Langer, who pulled out of The Times' table at short notice. Also David Gower, his Sky TV colleague Ian Botham, Henry Blofeld of TMS (that, at least, meant one less bow tie), Richie Benaud of C4 and TalkSport's Geoffrey Boycott. All five are a little too grand to attend what is essentially a hacks' jolly, traditionally held on the eve of the NatWest Final (most cricket correspondents live out of London, and this isn't a do you should drive home from).

Entertainment A good speech by Dermot Reeve, the C4 commentator and former Warwickshire captain, who was observed nervously tweaking his notes as he waited to go on stage. The only blemish was length: at 35 minutes, the speech was too much of a good thing by 10 minutes.

Later Reeve, who entertained the assembled to his impressive impersonations of Imran Khan, Allan Lamb, Boycott, Benaud and other notables, confessed that he'd been more frightened of addressing hundreds of cynical reporters than he ever was of the late Malcolm Marshall's bowling. "Mark Nicholas certainly wouldn't be up for this gig," a relieved Reeve told me as things hotted up in the bar afterwards. Not that he'd let me have a look at his script. "This is really a private affair" was his line. More to the point, perhaps: those notes, as an amused onlooker commented, are worth thousands of pounds a year in fees: Reeve is a successful after-dinner speaker, though he wasn't being paid this time. You have to do it for honour alone at this do.

Main talking points The NatWest final, whether England could hold on to win the Test series, and, it has to be said, runners and riders in the race to be the next editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

webTitle: You bet your life: the expert's view

fields.headline: You bet your life: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Every week, Blue Square's Patrick Murray takes a look at the bets made by our valiant punters and advises them how to improve, at the same time as putting the boot in
fields.trailText:
Paul MacInnes
Holland v Republic of Ireland - Half-time draw/full-time Holland at 4-1: £6
fields.body:
Paul MacInnes
Holland v Republic of Ireland - Half-time draw/full-time Holland at 4-1: £6

This looks a fair bet to me at 4/1. Last week I was saying how draw/favourite represented better value than favourite/favourite and its good to see that someone at least appears to be listening to my advice. My only reservation would be that the Dutch injury crisis touched upon by Mr MacInnes, allied with the fact that most of their players play in Italy and Spain and thus are short of match practice, made the second part of the equation, the Dutch full-time win, considerably less likely (although, of course, making the half-time draw more likely). If I was going to have a bet on this game it probably would have been on Ireland on the Asian Handicap where they were getting a goal and a quarter as it was hard to see the makeshift Dutch team, albeit still a team packed with stars, dominating the game in the way Louis Van Gaal's first choice eleven might have. But I don't think Paul has done a lot wrong here and if he keeps thinking along these value lines he should make a profit on the season.

Craig Thomas
France v England - Thierry Henry first scorer, correct score 3-1 (to France) at 28-1: £7.50

I know one shouldn't be rude to, or about, guests but really I'm left with little choice. The scorecast, as the first goalscorer and correct score double is known, is what we in the trade like to call a 'fun bet', a euphemism for 'mug bet' that perfectly encapsulates the way the bookmaker wants you, the punter, to view gambling. We all bet for fun I hope - and who can deny the enjoyment to be had in punting on a long shot to add a little extra spice to your football viewing - but betting for fun and betting for profit are two different, and often mutually exclusive, things. And I am here to tell you how to bet for profit not for fun.

Bookies adore scorecasts because the profit margins are frankly obscene. Mr Thomas's use of the word value (combined with the word good just to compound the error) in the context of a scorecast fills me with despair. Is Henry to score first and France to win 3-1 really a 28/1 shot? I don't think so; 100/1 would be far nearer the mark. To reach this price of 28/1 the bookies have multiplied the price of Henry to score first (first goalscorer being a market with a massive profit margin) by the price of 3-1 to France (correct score being a market with a massive profit margin) and then added on a load more percentage because the two outcomes are slightly connected (if Henry scores first a 3-1 victory to France is more likely than if, say, Adams scores first). There are thousands of possible different outcomes to this market and I wouldn't even rate Henry and 3-1 in the top ten. But enough opprobrium. If you want a fun bet I heartily recommend scorecasts; if you want a value bet don't touch it with a bargepole. Are you listening Mr Thomas?

Sean Ingle
£20 accumulator on Israel to beat Liechenstein (1/20), Yugoslavia to beat Luxembourg (1/14), Brazil to beat Bolivia (1/8) and Sweden to beat Azerbaijan (1/5)

With odds-on shots toppling like skittles (as usual) on a World Cup weekend Mr Ingle was fortunate enough to pick four of those who didn't. He could have gone for Norway to beat Armenia at 1/8, he could have backed the Ukraine, Holland, Italy, Slovenia etc etc all of whom failed to oblige but he chose Yugoslavia, Israel, Brazil and Sweden. Luck or judgement? Who am I to say?

As Mr I isn't slow to tell us all his teams were "certainties", but if the certainties always won there won't be any bookies left. What's more their certainty was in the price. No one is going to get rich backing 1/14, 1/20 or even 1/5 shots. No one save the bookies that is, because, as Mr Ingle kindly reminds us, they can fail to oblige, as Portugal did against Azerbaijan last year, as Norway did on Saturday.

Mr Ingle has finally won some money however, for which we must applaud him. But I can't think this is the way forward. There is no such thing as a sure thing and in the long run it only takes one stubborn defence or profligate attack and suddenly the bankroll is looking thin again.

Scott Murray
£10 Treble: France to beat England (4/7); Germany to beat Greece (1/4); Holland to beat Republic of Ireland (2/5)

As I said earlier, given the Dutch injury list and their lack of competitive match practice, they were never value at 2/5. Germany, similarly, at 1/4 could not appeal to me. Okay so they were playing a poor Greece side, and they had just beaten Spain 4-1, but it doesn't pay to read too much into friendlies and they were abject in Euro 2000. The only leg of the treble I couldn't disagree with was France to beat England, the best team in Europe against a very mediocre one on current form. The final result just illustrates the dangers of backing odds-on shots in friendlies.

It is often tempting to do odds-on multiples, but one must remember that football is 'a funny old game' and certs get beaten. All the time. If there is one thing I have learnt over the years it is that the value is to be had in opposing the favourites not in backing them. Okay so I back less winners than I used too, but strangely I make more money. But enough, dear punter, as Mr Ingle showed us once again this week 'its better to be lucky than good'. Happy punting.

fields.headline: 'E's no pigeon, me old China
fields.standfirst: A flyaway budgie, an overflowing postbox, the signs that don't work and the press officer's dictatorial insult
fields.trailText: A flyaway budgie, an overflowing postbox, the signs that don't work and the press officer's dictatorial insult
fields.body:
Takeaway budgie makes a getaway
A new sighting has given fresh hope to a man hunting his missing budgerigar.

Paul Dainton inadvertently allowed budgie China to escape when he left the door to his aviary open. But he revealed his erstwhile pet may find it hard to disguise his identity while on the run, as it speaks in a distinct Oriental patois.

The latest lead came from a fisherman at nearby Kirkthorpe, who spoke to a budgie that reportedly replied: "'Ello, wa ya want?"

Mr Dainton, who acquired the bird from a Chinese restaurant in Manchester when it shut down, said: "He talks Chinese and a bit of pidgin English. Things like 'rice or chips'."

Paul is offering the reward of a Chinese meal for two for the budgie's return.
Yorkshire Evening Post

Royal Mail try boxing clever
Abusive Cleethorpes parents have brought chaos to a Royal Mail post box outside Signhills school.

The 3.30pm collection from the box was cancelled after a postie was verbally abused as she picked up the mail.

Now, according to councillor Keith Brookes, frequently residents "cannot get their letter in and there is mail about to fall out."

Further, he claimed the postie's delivery van used to park right next to the box, blocking the school car park entrance. Parents had, for a long time, politely asked the driver to park the van just 10 yards away, before apparently cracking.

As a temporary concession, the Royal Mail has introduced a 4pm collection. But an insider claimed that a bigger box was not needed and blockages caused by large objects were behind the overflows.

Mr Brookes urged people not to use the post box unless they could see the letter actually drop right inside it.
Grimsby Telegraph

Signifying nothing
Five new signs to encourage visitors to come to Oswestry have sparked bitter criticism.

The signs - paid for with European funding - have been condemned as being in the wrong place.

Town mayor, councillor Heather Bickerton, said: "The signs are placed on the approach roads to the town, but motorists can only see them when they have already decided to come to Oswestry.

"They should be placed on the bypass so motorists can clearly see what attractions the town has then, they can decided whether to come here or not.''

Council transport officer Richard Jones said: "Unfortunately the Highways Agency would not allow us to place the signs on the bypass so we had to place them as close as possible."

However, he added, the council was intending to contact the local MP to lobby for "other signs to be placed on the bypass directing motorists to the larger signs."
Border Counties Advertiser

Saddam slight causes council gulf
A council press officer has survived a no-confidence motion brought by fellow councillors after he compared them to Saddam Hussein.

Bramhope parish council chairman John Mordy called a debate on the future of fellow councillor Clive Fox after the latter likened the council's attempts to extend the parish boundary into neighbouring Arthington to the Iraqi leader's invasion of Kuwait.

Mr Mordy said the council must "consider whether it is still appropriate that councillor Fox should continue." The press officer's analogy of Bramhope council with a brutal Middle East dictator had, he said, made them "very unhappy."

Other members of the parish council said they were happy to let Mr Fox continue in the role.

An unrepentant Mr Fox asked for an apology from the council for questioning his right to attend meetings. Wharfedale Observer

But an insider claimed that a bigger box was not needed and blockages caused by large objects were behind the overflows. Mr Brookes urged people not to use the post box unless they could see the letter actually drop right inside it. Grimsby Telegraph Signifying nothing Five new signs to encourage visitors to come to Oswestry have sparked bitter criticism. The signs - paid for with European funding - have been condemned as being in the wrong place. Town mayor, councillor Heather Bickerton, said: "The signs are placed on the approach roads to the town, but motorists can only see them when they have already decided to come to Oswestry. "They should be placed on the bypass so motorists can clearly see what attractions the town has then, they can decided whether to come here or not.'' Council transport officer Richard Jones said: "Unfortunately the Highways Agency would not allow us to place the signs on the bypass so we had to place them as close as possible." However, he added, the council was intending to contact the local MP to lobby for "other signs to be placed on the bypass directing motorists to the larger signs." Border Counties Advertiser Saddam slight causes council gulf A council press officer has survived a no-confidence motion brought by fellow councillors after he compared them to Saddam Hussein. Bramhope parish council chairman John Mordy called a debate on the future of fellow councillor Clive Fox after the latter likened the council's attempts to extend the parish boundary into neighbouring Arthington to the Iraqi leader's invasion of Kuwait. Mr Mordy said the council must "consider whether it is still appropriate that councillor Fox should continue." The press officer's analogy of Bramhope council with a brutal Middle East dictator had, he said, made them "very unhappy." Other members of the parish council said they were happy to let Mr Fox continue in the role. An unrepentant Mr Fox asked for an apology from the council for questioning his right to attend meetings. Wharfedale Observer

webTitle: Saatchi & Saatchi moves HQ to US

fields.headline: Saatchi & Saatchi goes west
fields.standfirst: Saatchi & Saatchi's decision to switch its headquarters from Charlotte Street to the US surprised few in the ad industry, Claire Cozens explains.
fields.trailText: Saatchi & Saatchi's decision to switch its headquarters from Charlotte Street to the US surprised few in the ad industry, Claire Cozens explains.
fields.body:
It feels like the end of an era. Saatchi & Saatchi is moving its headquarters to the US, cutting its remaining links with the small creative hot shop the Saatchi brothers set up in Charlotte Street 30 years ago.

It may still be Britain's most famous advertising agency, but nowadays there is not much that is British about Saatchi & Saatchi. It is owned by French advertising group Publicis, is run by a US chairman and New Zealander chief executive and derives 50% of its revenue from the US. Today, Saatchi & Saatchi is a far cry from the agency that began in 1970 with a team of nine people and by the 1980s had grown into the worldês biggest agency, with some of the world's most famous ads to its name.

It is one of the few ad agencies to have become a household name, partly because its two founders did an even better job of selling themselves than they did selling their clients.

But by the mid-1990s, the agency had run into financial difficulties following a string of ambitious deals that culminated in the failed takeover of Midland Bank. In 1994, the brothers were ousted from the board by institutional shareholders in what must be the industry's bitterest and most public bust-up.

The Saatchi & Saatchi that developed over the years had a very British feel to it. Its clients included British Airways, British Rail and the Conservative Party. And its most famous ad since the "Labour isn't working" election campaign poster for the Conservatives was a poster of a pregnant man with the strapline "Would you be more careful if it was you that got pregnant?" for the Health Education Council.

Today, the agency has a more corporate, international feel about it. Its biggest client is Cincinnati-based consumer goods manufacturer Procter & Gamble, while other major clients include Toyota, Hewlett-Packard and Sony. It still does work for the UK government, but is just one of a number of ad agencies that are used.

The news comes as no surprise to the ad industry, which has long considered Saatchi & Saatchi's true home to be the US. David Kershaw, a partner at breakaway agency M&C Saatchi, says: "I think New York is much more its home now, both spiritually and commercially. Charlotte Street has not been the agency's true home for some years - but then I would say that, wouldn't I?"

webTitle: Pace Micro Technology back on track with memory chips

fields.headline: Pace Micro Technology overcomes components drought
fields.trailText: Pace Micro Technology, which makes set-top boxes for Britain's major digital and satellite TV channels, is back in business after overcoming a components drought.
fields.body:
Pace Micro Technology, which makes set-top boxes for Britain's major digital and satellite TV channels, is back in business after overcoming a components drought.

Chairman Michael Bett told shareholders at the annual general meeting that product shipments are back on track after a memory chips shortage slowed production, forcing cable TV company Telewest to halt the marketing of its digital service.

"The company is winning new orders, finalising new designs and increasing production capacity to meet demand and, although supply chains are still tight, we are confident of continued growth," said Mr Bett.

Pace Micro's customers include NTL, BSkyB's SkyDigital service and ONdigital, the joint venture between Granada Media and Carlton Communications. The company is supplying the latest box for ONdigital, with shipments starting soon.

Mr Bett told the AGM that his company has secured an order for 10,000 ADSL set-top boxes from Hull-based Kingston Communications. The boxes will provide high-speed internet access and interactive TV services through Kingston's networks.

The stock market ignored the good news, marking down the Pace shares 21.5p to 837.5p.

fields.headline: The return of Northants
fields.trailText: It wasn't so long ago that this column ended with the not-disinterested plea, "Come on Northants. Please." My side had just failed to defend over 300 against Glamorgan and were on course for relegation to the third division of the County Championship - if such a thing existed. Phrases like "ineptitude", "dark despair" and "tears of rage" popped up like bat-pads off the bowling of Abdul Qadir. Well, it's been one-way stuff since then, and Northants have been at the wheel. This piece is by way of apology. Because I never lost faith really.
fields.body:
It wasn't so long ago that this column ended with the not-disinterested plea, "Come on Northants. Please." My side had just failed to defend over 300 against Glamorgan and were on course for relegation to the third division of the County Championship - if such a thing existed. Phrases like "ineptitude", "dark despair" and "tears of rage" popped up like bat-pads off the bowling of Abdul Qadir. Well, it's been one-way stuff since then, and Northants have been at the wheel. This piece is by way of apology. Because I never lost faith really.

Since that cock-up at Cardiff in mid-July, Northamptonshire have won five Championship games in a row - and now need just six points from their final two matches to be the first side to gain promotion in the history of the competition. They have also won four out of five National League matches to move to third in Division One. The government's Do Not Resuscitate orders clearly didn't reach Wantage Road.

The recovery has taken place for a number of reasons. They started when one of the worst things to happen to Northamptonshire turned out to be a whopping great rain-cloud with a golden lining. Michael Davies, the left-arm spinner who toured with England A last winter, got the yips against Warwickshire and was dropped for offspinner Jason Brown. The change worked pretty well at first as Brown took 15 wickets at 24.53 in his first three games.

But it really paid off when 35-year-old left-arm seamer Paul Taylor returned to the side after injury. The rough he created outside the right-hander's off stump was just what Brown needed to move up a gear. In the next five games, all of which Northants won, Brown picked up 38 wickets at 18.03, including four five-fors and two ten-wicket hauls.

Taylor's inclusion also put an end to a search for a consistent opening bowler to go with the excellent, under-rated Darren Cousins, who had taken 57 wickets at 19.33 before today's game against Essex, despite having to plug away on the unresponsive wickets at Northampton. Taylor, a regular 50-wickets-a-season man, was more accurate than Devon Malcolm (now on the lookout for another county) and more penetrative than Richard Logan and Michael Strong. At Eastbourne, where Sussex prepared a greentop in an attempt to neutralise Brown and Graeme Swann, Taylor cashed in with 10 for 69.

The batting too has got better. Matthew Hayden started turning quickfire 40s into quickfire 100s and responded to the Glamorgan game by scoring 341 in his next three innings.

Then there's Russell Warren. Four years ago, on the back of a double-hundred against Glamorgan, he was being talked about as the next England wicketkeeper. Then he lost his form - and his place in the Northants side. Now he returned, at the expense of Mal Loye, who kept hitting sixes and then getting himself out, and began with scores of 60 and 151.

With a more dependable middle order allowing Tony Penberthy to grind out the scores, Northants regularly batted their opponents out of the game. Against Worcestershire they made 519 and won by an innings and 72; against Sussex 460 and an innings and 17; against Gloucestershire 469 and an innings and 74. Relentless, ruthless and victorious - everything, in fact, that Northants have struggled to be for four years.

They've emerged well from the few tight spots they've encountered as well. In the match at Eastbourne, Northants trailed by 43 on first innings in a low-scoring affair. But Jeff Cook, who had scraped together just 69 runs in his previous six Championship knocks, came to the rescue with 116. Set 228, Sussex made 65. And in a recent National League game, Kent began the final two overs needing just 10 with Rahul Dravid at the crease. They fell five runs short.

These are the sort of matches in which Old Northants would have choked. New Northants are a tougher breed. As I said all along, it was only a matter of time.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous County View, on the ifs and buts of a hypothetical county-cricket transfer market, click here

fields.headline: Terms of estrangement
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: Home and away: The diary of a part-time father
fields.body:
The most difficult part about composing a conciliatory letter to Dilys was having to pretend that I was somebody else. Please don't take this too literally: I didn't write under a false name (that would have been a bit transparent, don't you think?). But I found that it was impossible to set out my position to my former partner in anything approaching my true voice.

How does that voice sound? Oh, you know: scornful, sardonic, sour - the one you know and love. However, having promised Gloria while walking on the beach that I would try to build a bridge of understanding with her mother as soon as we returned from Little England-on-Sea, I felt honour-bound to use any device that worked, however inhibiting, however absurd. So I made believe that Dilys was an elderly dowager living in the late 1940s and that I was her solicitous bank manager. The letter started off: "Dear Dilys..."

Of course, such a familiar beginning was not at all in character, but I could hardly have addressed her as "Miss Day". One of the curiosities of relationships between hostile former partners is that they never cease to be on first-name terms.

Anyway, my letter continued: "Now that we are approaching the fifth anniversary of our relationship ending, I am wondering if this would be an appropriate juncture at which to take stock of the situation that has subsequently arisen..."

You can't beat a bit of old- fashioned formality, can you? All the boiling inner furies neatly concealed beneath a cloak of civility. I even wrote it with a fountain pen. My only regret is that I didn't have a quill.

"If I may count on your indulgence, perhaps I could enumerate one or two matters regarding our shared care of the children which are giving me particular concern..."

Admittedly, all this plodding formality did create the risk that Dilys would think I was taking the piss. Only a small risk, though. An inflated opinion of her own importance has given Dilys a big blind spot where satire is concerned. Besides, by this stage I was having too much fun to stop.

"My considered diagnosis is that most of the causes of tension in the present arrangement arise from your preoccupation with promoting a certain sort of relationship between Gloria, Jed and Billy and your present spouse Chris..."

Actually, this was the sentence that gave me the most problems. "Spouse" is a stupid word, but Chris, presumably because he's besotted with all things "alternative", has not become Dilys's husband, and the word "partner" always makes me think of doubles teams in tennis.

But my greatest difficulty was resisting the urge to shatter the affected mood of deference I'd so lovingly created by describing Chris as "that pillock you ran off with". For five long minutes I fought the awful urge by kneeling on the floor and biting on the corner of the kitchen table. Only then did I feel able to resume.

I won't treat you to further excerpts - too much of a good thing, and all that. Let me simply record that I briefly listed what bothers me the most about the regime chez Pillock and suggested to Dilys that she reply, enumerating any anxieties of her own, with a view to sorting out some of our differences.

Let me also disclose the underlying spirit of my lovingly constructed overture. The fundamental point is this: my dislike of Dilys is utterly exhausting and, for all my gritted-teeth efforts at keeping it from them, nothing but destructive for the children. Alas, hostilities can be consoling, even when only conducted in the crazier corners of your own head. The holiday period, though, has made me braver. Billy has been all sweetness, some of the thunderclouds have lifted from Jed's brow, and Gloria has started feeling like my kindred-spirit daughter once again. More secure in myself, I've been able to think of Dilys and Chris less as my looming nemeses and more as a pair of terminal self-obsessives who need saving from themselves.

I finished off my letter at 3.30 in the morning. I could have shown it to Angie. Maybe to Gloria as well. Instead, I stepped out into the night, ran down to the postbox and slipped it through the slot before I could give myself a chance to change my mind.

fields.headline: That's my boy
fields.standfirst: For many fathers, it's the ultimate dream: to see their sons play in the Premiership. But are some football-mad dads pushing their boys too hard?  Sally Weale  reports
fields.trailText: For many fathers, it's the ultimate dream: to see their sons play in the Premiership. But are some football-mad dads pushing their boys too hard? Sally Weale reports
fields.body:
It is 6.45am on Wandsworth Common. It is still dark and there is hardly anyone about. Just two little boys in custard-yellow fleeces running. Ojay and Troy Keen are out training with their father Derek, whose dream is that at least one of them will become a Premiership footballer. "Come on! Don't slow down, Troy!" shouts Derek. A little voice comes back: "I can't, I can't." Derek shouts again: "Quicker, Troy! You're going too slow!"

Derek is a devoted soccer dad. He takes his sons for early morning runs, he spends his weekends and evenings ferrying them to training and matches; he watches their performances as closely as Alex Ferguson watches Beckham and Giggs. He's a season ticket holder at Chelsea but he'd much rather watch his sons playing in the local boys' Sunday league.

Especially Ojay. Because Ojay, the elder of the two boys, is going to make it. Derek feels it in his bones. Ojay, he says, is like a mini Roy Keane, but faster and more skilful. He's 10 years old and he's the best of his age his dad has seen. "I love watching him play. You're watching your own flesh and blood out there. I feel proud. Very, very proud."

Derek and his sons are featured in a Modern Times television documentary called Go On My Son!, which follows a group of fathers involved in boys' football in south London. It's entertaining, thought-provoking television, raising interesting issues about father-son bonding, about talented children, ambitious parents and the potential dangers when the two are combined.

The world of sport is full of ambitious, pushy parents, but football - our national sport and obsession, the stars of which are constantly paraded before us, with their ever increasing wealth and status - is in a league of its own.

Parents sign up their four-year-olds for football training; fathers are willing to make a pact with the devil to secure a place for their son in the Arsenal under-12s. But with all the risks, the disappointments and the pressure involved, it hardly seems a desirable career choice for your child. Or does it?

"I want it all day long for him," Derek says unambiguously. "If you are going to do a job you enjoy and get paid for it, why not? I wouldn't make him do it for the love of the money. I want him to do it for the love of the game."

On the south London youth football circuit, Derek must be among the most vocal. He stands on the sidelines, his hands thrust deep into his pockets, hurling gobbets of advice, criticism and - occasionally - praise at his son. "Ojay, move up. Move up!" He groans and turns away in despair. " I'm pissed off with this. Ojay, move up !!" When Ojay comes off the field, Derek tells him it's the worst he's seen him play. Ojay runs off, distraught. Meanwhile, Troy, who is playing elsewhere, watched by his mother, Dawn, is upset because he thinks his dad is more interested in Ojay than him.

Off the pitch, Derek, a 40-year-old builder, is much less fearsome. The kitchen of the family's terraced house is filled with football trophies, there is football on the television and the small back garden is dominated by a set of goalposts. Ojay and Troy, who is nine, were still in the baby walker when they started messing around with a football; they went to their first Chelsea match when they were two. Derek's father, who died when he was 14, did not share his interest in football. Derek never got the support he now gives to his sons and he feels he missed out.

Derek insists that his sons don't miss out on anything; they do exactly the same things as other children. Their schoolwork is good; they have friends and other interests; but Derek is very serious about their football. If he thinks they've been slacking during training, when everyone else is going home at the end he makes them do it again. At school, he has instructed Ojay not to play football at playtime because of the risk of injuring his joints on the concrete playground. "I don't hear anyone moaning about Tiger Woods's dad pushing him," he says.

He is determined that Ojay will not lose his focus as he gets older. One girl has already been ringing him up, trying to get him interested in her. "I said to him straight, these girls are not coming between you and your football. I've seen it happen, at 14 or 15, they want girlfriends, they're going out all the time, they're having their first four or five pints, and they're not turning up for their matches. I'm not going to let that happen." Ojay, a beautiful, quiet boy with an inscrutable face, shrugs when you ask him about the pressure. "It's OK with me. I like playing football."

But what if Ojay decides he doesn't want to pursue his football? "The day my son turns to me and says he doesn't want to do it I'll be upset, but it's something I'm going to accept straightaway. I would never want that to happen, but if it happens, it happens. If Ojay wanted to be a solicitor, or a doctor, that's fine by me. Whatever makes him happy." He almost sounds convincing, then he adds: "But I couldn't help him out as much." In other words , football is something they can share together as father and son - law and medicine they cannot.

A mutual interest between parent and child is an important part of bonding - as reflected in tonight's film - according to educational psychologist Professor David Fontana, but there are enormous dangers if the child has not got the talent or motivation. "Certainly it's important if the child is very good at something, to support them physically by taking them to matches and emotionally by sharing in their success.

But it's very important for parents to realise that what's interesting for a child, whether it's music or sport, that interest may not last into adult life. If there's failure later on, there's not only the father's feeling of being let down, but the son's feeling of letting the father down.

Childhood, says Fontana, is a part of life that is valid in and of itself. It should not simply be a preparation for adult life. "If parents invest too much of themselves, their time, money and ambitions, and their children cannot live up to that, it's very destructive for the relationship between the parent and child and also for the child's self-esteem."

Jack Tarr, chairman of the English Schools Football Association, also urges fathers to be cautious. "It's nice to be able to go into the pub and say - my son plays for Chelsea under 12s. But the chances of going all the way - well, it really is clutching at straws. There are so few boys who can possibly make it into the premier league."

"Football is a wonderful game," says Tarr. "But it's a game that can lead to great disappointment. Certainly when you think of boys who do make the grade, there will always be a very supportive father - and mother.

"But be wary. He might be the one in a million who makes the grade, but there are not many of them."

fields.bodyText: It is 6.45am on Wandsworth Common. It is still dark and there is hardly anyone about. Just two little boys in custard-yellow fleeces running. Ojay and Troy Keen are out training with their father Derek, whose dream is that at least one of them will become a Premiership footballer. "Come on! Don't slow down, Troy!" shouts Derek. A little voice comes back: "I can't, I can't." Derek shouts again: "Quicker, Troy! You're going too slow!" Derek is a devoted soccer dad. He takes his sons for early morning runs, he spends his weekends and evenings ferrying them to training and matches; he watches their performances as closely as Alex Ferguson watches Beckham and Giggs. He's a season ticket holder at Chelsea but he'd much rather watch his sons playing in the local boys' Sunday league. Especially Ojay. Because Ojay, the elder of the two boys, is going to make it. Derek feels it in his bones. Ojay, he says, is like a mini Roy Keane, but faster and more skilful. He's 10 years old and he's the best of his age his dad has seen. "I love watching him play. You're watching your own flesh and blood out there. I feel proud. Very, very proud." Derek and his sons are featured in a Modern Times television documentary called Go On My Son!, which follows a group of fathers involved in boys' football in south London. It's entertaining, thought-provoking television, raising interesting issues about father-son bonding, about talented children, ambitious parents and the potential dangers when the two are combined. The world of sport is full of ambitious, pushy parents, but football - our national sport and obsession, the stars of which are constantly paraded before us, with their ever increasing wealth and status - is in a league of its own. Parents sign up their four-year-olds for football training; fathers are willing to make a pact with the devil to secure a place for their son in the Arsenal under-12s. But with all the risks, the disappointments and the pressure involved, it hardly seems a desirable career choice for your child. Or does it? "I want it all day long for him," Derek says unambiguously. "If you are going to do a job you enjoy and get paid for it, why not? I wouldn't make him do it for the love of the money. I want him to do it for the love of the game." On the south London youth football circuit, Derek must be among the most vocal. He stands on the sidelines, his hands thrust deep into his pockets, hurling gobbets of advice, criticism and - occasionally - praise at his son. "Ojay, move up. Move up!" He groans and turns away in despair. " I'm pissed off with this. Ojay, move up !!" When Ojay comes off the field, Derek tells him it's the worst he's seen him play. Ojay runs off, distraught. Meanwhile, Troy, who is playing elsewhere, watched by his mother, Dawn, is upset because he thinks his dad is more interested in Ojay than him. Off the pitch, Derek, a 40-year-old builder, is much less fearsome. The kitchen of the family's terraced house is filled with football trophies, there is football on the television and the small back garden is dominated by a set of goalposts. Ojay and Troy, who is nine, were still in the baby walker when they started messing around with a football; they went to their first Chelsea match when they were two. Derek's father, who died when he was 14, did not share his interest in football. Derek never got the support he now gives to his sons and he feels he missed out. Derek insists that his sons don't miss out on anything; they do exactly the same things as other children. Their schoolwork is good; they have friends and other interests; but Derek is very serious about their football. If he thinks they've been slacking during training, when everyone else is going home at the end he makes them do it again. At school, he has instructed Ojay not to play football at playtime because of the risk of injuring his joints on the concrete playground. "I don't hear anyone moaning about Tiger Woods's dad pushing him," he says. He is determined that Ojay will not lose his focus as he gets older. One girl has already been ringing him up, trying to get him interested in her. "I said to him straight, these girls are not coming between you and your football. I've seen it happen, at 14 or 15, they want girlfriends, they're going out all the time, they're having their first four or five pints, and they're not turning up for their matches. I'm not going to let that happen." Ojay, a beautiful, quiet boy with an inscrutable face, shrugs when you ask him about the pressure. "It's OK with me. I like playing football." But what if Ojay decides he doesn't want to pursue his football? "The day my son turns to me and says he doesn't want to do it I'll be upset, but it's something I'm going to accept straightaway. I would never want that to happen, but if it happens, it happens. If Ojay wanted to be a solicitor, or a doctor, that's fine by me. Whatever makes him happy." He almost sounds convincing, then he adds: "But I couldn't help him out as much." In other words , football is something they can share together as father and son - law and medicine they cannot. "Certainly it's important if the child is very good at something, to support them physically by taking them to matches and emotionally by sharing in their success. But it's very important for parents to realise that what's interesting for a child, whether it's music or sport, that interest may not last into adult life. If there's failure later on, there's not only the father's feeling of being let down, but the son's feeling of letting the father down. Childhood, says Fontana, is a part of life that is valid in and of itself. It should not simply be a preparation for adult life. "If parents invest too much of themselves, their time, money and ambitions, and their children cannot live up to that, it's very destructive for the relationship between the parent and child and also for the child's self-esteem." Jack Tarr, chairman of the English Schools Football Association, also urges fathers to be cautious. "It's nice to be able to go into the pub and say - my son plays for Chelsea under 12s. fields.headline: Fragile hearts
fields.standfirst: Ulrika Jonsson has been told that her unborn child has a heart defect. What is it like to go through a pregnancy knowing that your baby will probably need surgery?  Joanna Moorhead  on every parent's worst nightmare
fields.trailText: Ulrika Jonsson has been told that her unborn child has a heart defect. What is it like to go through a pregnancy knowing that your baby will probably need surgery? Joanna Moorhead on every parent's worst nightmare
fields.body:
Ask any pregnant woman about her hopes and fears and she'll tell you the same thing: all she wants is a healthy baby. These days, science can increase her chances of that - but, as TV presenter Ulrika Jonsson has discovered, it can also diagnose a serious illness in a baby whose birth is several months away.

How does it feel to be pregnant with a baby who may not survive infancy? Ulrika is said to be devastated by the news, which came after an ultrasound scan, that her baby has a rare heart condition known as double-inlet left-ventricle defect. The chances of success are thought to be good, but no two cases are the same and the baby will have to endure at least three critical operations.

Mother-of-three Louise Hall knows what Ulrika and her partner, Markus Kempen, are going through. Five years ago she and her husband, Duncan, were told that their unborn son had a potentially fatal heart condition called hyperplastic left-heart syndrome.

For Louise, the remaining weeks of the pregnancy were the hardest part of a desperately difficult year. "Until Ben was born I seemed to be carrying the weight of it all: I felt it was just my problem. I never said, 'Why me?', but there were times I'd see a pregnant woman drinking or smoking, and I would think, 'Hold on a moment - I haven't been doing that, but look what's happened to my baby.' Some days were very hard to get through."

When the diagnosis was confirmed, at around 20 weeks, Louise was offered three choices. "I was told I could opt to continue, and the baby could have surgery after the birth. Or I could carry on, but not opt for the surgery, in which case the child would certainly die. Or I could opt for a termination.

"We considered termination briefly, but to be honest we couldn't face it - the baby was moving around by then." The Halls decided they would carry on and have their baby operated on - but there was no way they could pretend the pregnancy was normal any more. "I was aware that, if my baby died, his life inside me would be the only life he'd ever have," says Louise. "So I knew I had to make the most of it, and I had to make sure that although he wasn't yet born, he was a real person to us.

"We found out he was a boy, so we gave him a name, Ben, and I talked to people about him by name. What I didn't want was for him to be born and die without anyone but me knowing him.

"I got very good at telling people Ben's story, but inside it was always hard, because pregnancy is all about the beginning of a new life, and it goes against your deepest grain to tell someone that your baby might be going to die." There was also the issue of being judged by people who felt that, if they had been in the Halls' shoes, they'd have taken a different course of action.

Like Louise, Angelina Fellowes was around 20 weeks pregnant when a routine scan showed that her unborn son's heart hadn't formed properly. "They couldn't tell exactly what was wrong, so I was referred to Guy's Hospital," she says. "There, I was told that my baby had not only double-inlet left-ventricle defect, but several other heart problems as well. As a midwife I knew I had the option to terminate, but I didn't want to do that. When she gave me the news, the doctor went straight on to talk about what could be done, and that was very important to me. It seemed really positive."

But the rest of the pregnancy was tough. "I've got two older sons so I've got lots of baby clothes in the attic, but I didn't get them down or buy any new ones. Most of the time I just tried to keep busy so I didn't have to think about it. But some days I was distraught - it was so terrible to just have to wait, not knowing until the birth how bad things would be."

For Angelina - as for Louise and Ulrika Jonsson - the workings of the foetal circulatory system meant that the baby was safe inside the uterus. Only when the baby was born, and took his first breath, would his own circulation kick in and the heart defect become dangerous.

Because of this, Louise found herself dreading the birth. "I desperately wanted to keep him inside me, because I knew he was OK there. I knew that when my body gave him up, that was the point when he'd be ill."

In the event, Ben's birth was not as traumatic as Louise had feared. Although babies with diagnosed heart conditions are usually born in specialist hospitals, the Halls chose to have the delivery at a maternity hospital near the family home in Chester to make it more "normal". Eight hours after the birth he was transferred to Birmingham children's hospital, where he had his first operation at the age of 23 hours. Since then he's had three more, and Ben is now a healthy four-year-old - albeit one whose long-term future is uncertain. "We've been told he'll probably need a heart transplant in his early 20s," says Louise. "But we're going to cross that bridge when we get to it - research is changing things all the time."

Today, through the support group Left Heart Matters, Louise counsels couples who have heard that their unborn child has a heart problem. Not all, says Louise, find it easy to bond with a baby who might not survive: some mothers can't allow themselves to get close to a child they may lose. Pat Sorhaindo, senior midwife at the Harris Birthright Trust prenatal diagnosis unit at King's College hospital in London, agrees. She says she has seen an automatic protective mechanism in some women. "It's natural, really," she says. "And you get some couples, too, who wish they could unlearn what they now know, because it's taken away the joy of being pregnant and filled their lives with worry."

Sorhaindo tries to concentrate on the advantages of knowing that there's a problem: often it means the baby can be born in a hospital where expertise is immediately available, and parents can read up on the condition (though this doesn't always reassure - Louise's initial investigations into her baby's heart defect led her to believe it would prove fatal). There is also the chance to adjust other family members to the fact that the baby is going to have problems, and to make arrangements to deal with the upheaval of having a child in hospital.

Parents also get a chance to meet the surgeon who will deal with their baby, and to look round the special care unit where their baby will be cared for. "We tell them that forewarned is forearmed," says Sorhaindo. "They can do all they can to get ready for what's going to happen."

According to Joanie Dimavicius of the support group ARC (Antenatal Results and Choices), many women find that after a diagnosis of a problem has been made it's the unborn baby, rather than their status as a pregnant mother, which is the focus. "They sometimes say they feel like they're just the container for this baby," she says. "They may have lots of visits to foetal medicine units and specialists, but far fewer opportunities just to chat to a midwife about how they're feeling themselves."

 The Children's Heart Federation helpline is on 0808 8085000. Left Heart Matters is on 0121 455 8982, and Antenatal Results and Choices (ARC) is on 020-7631 0285.

webTitle: Is a new internet credit card for kids a good idea ?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst:
The question: A new internet credit card for kids will make it easier for children to spend their pocket money on the web. Is this a good idea?
Shopping unlimited
fields.trailText: The question: A new internet credit card for kids will make it easier for children to spend their pocket money on the web. Is this a good idea?
fields.body:
Briand Beausoleil Managing director, Splash Plastic

We developed the card to overcome the risks of shopping online and have focused on safety, security and privacy. The card can only be used at selected websites that sell appropriate products for the teenage market such as CDs, games, research material and fashion. There are also no risks of over-spending or getting into debt. Children are already using pre-paid cards for mobile phones and are learning how to get most value out of them through text-messaging. Children can be independent from their parents because there are no risks involved.

 Verdict: Yes

Wendy Elms Mother of four children aged nine, 12, 14 and 16

Children today are lazy enough already, and this will be another reason for them not to get up off their chairs and get a bit of exercise. Shopping on the net draws them in and can easily become an obsession, so I'd be very wary of anything that encourages it. Although I take the point about the credit on the card, there's still the risk they will just blow all the money at once - and because it's just a card it won't help them learn the value of real cash. It's just another pressure on parents, isn't it? Mine already go on about needing their mobile phone credits topped up.

 Verdict: No

Tom Hadfield Student and net user, 17

The Internet will make it easier for young people to spend money, and it will seem a much more usual place to buy things to my generation than it was to my parents'. Of course there are dangers in that, and some parents won't like the idea of a credit card for kids, or that their children can buy things on the net that they can't at the shops. But I'd say this is an opportunity - the answer isn't to restrict them, it's to teach them about responsible spending. In any case, these cards aren't strictly credit cards at all. Every teenager will want one, and I want one too.

 Verdict: Yes

Anna Bradley Director, National Consumer Council

There's no question that Splash plastic offers advantages. The fact that it is pre-paid means that teenagers can spend only the amount parents have agreed to - much like pocket money. That means parents won't end up with higher-than-expected bills and teenagers should learn to budget. The fact that you can only use the card on certain accredited sites could be an additional comfort to some parents. As with everything, less-well-off parents are likely to find themselves being pestered to take out a card or top it up, when they can ill afford to.

 Verdict: Maybe
