fields.headline: Benefit complaints rise
fields.standfirst: Ombudsmen find problems with 'contracted out' services
fields.trailText: Ombudsmen find problems with 'contracted out' services.
fields.body:
The local government ombudsmen for England have identified a 73% increase in complaints about the administration of housing benefit.

In their annual report today, they say the problem was one of the main reasons why their national caseload swelled to record proportions in 1999/2000.

Most of the 2,353 housing benefit complaints were in London and the lion's share of those were in the boroughs of Lambeth, Hackney, Islington and Southwark.

"Many of the complaints were justified," says Edward Osmotherley, the ombudsman for London. "This is reflected in the fact that local settlements were obtained in 69% of housing benefit complaints. All four councils have contracted out the administration of housing benefit to private companies; all four accept performance of their bene- fit services has been unacceptable."

Failure to deal with claims properly could cause serious injustice. "Some people lose their homes, get deeply into debt, or even attempt suicide," Osmotherley says.

The ombudsmen say work at the benefit fraud inspectorate could help to pinpoint fundamental problems giving grounds for complaint. They have also written to the Local Government Association suggesting model contracts based on the experience of councils that have successfully contracted out benefit administration.

fields.headline: Headhunted
fields.standfirst: The voluntary sector is losing talent
fields.trailText: The voluntary sector is losing talent
fields.body:
Another leading light of the voluntary sector is moving to work for the government. Colette Kelleher, director of the Daycare Trust, is to join the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) as an adviser on early years development and child care partnerships.

Her switch is the latest in a series, including those of Maeve Sherlock, who has left the leadership of the National Council for One Parent Families to join the Treasury's council of economic advisers, and of Balbir Chatrik, who has gone on secondment from the Unemployment Unit and Youthaid to help develop the DfEE's new children and young people's unit.

Kelleher, 38, has been the Daycare Trust's director since 1996. She has been instrumental in getting child care on to the mainstream political agenda and ensuring government action to improve Britain's poor provision.

She says: "Much has been done, but there is a much longer way to go before we achieve child care for all. There is still a child care gap, with groups including parents with children under three, children living in poverty, shiftworking parents and studying parents missing out.

"Child care staff are still underpaid and undervalued. Child care costs remain a stumbling block for those falling outside the child care tax credit. Sustainability and quality remain key concerns. The vast majority of employers are not making any contribution to child care."

The Daycare Trust is advertising today for Kelleher's replacement. On the one hand, her recruitment is a feather in the group's hat. On the other, though, the upheaval caused by her loss will bring problems - however able her successor turns out to be.

Paul Convery is, with Chatrik, joint director of the merged Unemployment Unit and Youthaid. He says there is a noticeable trend in the way Labour is now plucking seasoned voluntary sector talent after initially recruiting advisers who had little on-the-ground experience. While it makes good sense for ministers, they need to consider the consequences for the groups concerned.

"I have seen voluntary organisations who have taken quite a hit," says Convery. "It's great for the government, but it can often have quite an effect on the people left behind. The government possibly needs to go a little bit further in helping underpin an organisation from which they have taken the top talent."

It is, nonetheless, a two-way street. Having a former director, or secondee, in Whitehall can do no harm to a campaign group. "It can be tremendously valuable in terms of insights and a sense of how Whitehall works," admits Convery, stressing that Chatrik has of course betrayed no state secrets.

fields.headline: Streets ahead
fields.standfirst: Homeless benefit from coordinated care
fields.trailText: Homeless benefit from coordinated care.
fields.body:
Housing charities Shelter and Crisis are today releasing evidence that action by the main care services could achieve the government's target of reducing street homelessness by two thirds by 2002.

They surveyed 916 homeless people last winter at eight Millennium Plus projects in Blackpool, Manchester, Stoke-on-Trent, Norwich, Bath, Camborne, Bournemouth and Canterbury.

On arrival, the vast majority were not in touch with services that might help them to get off the streets. An astonishing 98% said they had no contact with their local homeless persons unit, 88% with social services and 74% with outreach services. Furthermore, 70% had never used a day centre. As well as providing shelter between December and March, the projects offered co-ordinated advice from all the support services that can help the homeless move off the streets.

Results were available for only about two-thirds of the original 916 sample, but they suggested an encouragingly high response. The initiative provided 52% with direct access to housing advice, 33% with advice from drug agencies, 29% from alcohol agencies, 28% with resettlement support, 18% with benefits advice, 14% with health services, 11% with mental health services and 2% with disability advice.

It is too soon to say whether this will provide long-term solutions to help homeless people with complex problems. But, at this stage, 37% have found accommodation. The charities said ongoing care had been provided for more than 230 people. They have individual care plans, prepared by multi-agency panels involving housing, social services, health, probation, drug and alcohol agencies to avoid clients being referred between agencies.

Chris Holmes, director of Shelter, says: "We know that many of the most vulnerable street homeless people often become cut off from the help they need. Others give up after being passed from one agency to another. Millennium Plus shows that harnessing a multi-agency response which works alongside street homeless people in hostels can make a difference."

They have individual care plans, prepared by multi-agency panels involving housing, social services, health, probation, drug and alcohol agencies to avoid clients being referred between agencies. Chris Holmes, director of Shelter, says: "We know that many of the most vulnerable street homeless people often become cut off from the help they need. Others give up after being passed from one agency to another. Millennium Plus shows that harnessing a multi-agency response which works alongside street homeless people in hostels can make a difference."

fields.headline: On the mend
fields.standfirst: Private homes to get small repair grants
fields.trailText: Private homes to get small repair grants.
fields.body:
More than £10bn urgently needs to be spent on repairs to privately owned houses, according to the government. Yet grants have dwindled and, at the current rate of investment, it would take 25 years to deal with existing needs.

The biggest problems are in poorer areas and one answer is the creation of new funds to finance low-cost, small-scale work for low-income householders. Such a scheme is to be launched shortly in Birmingham, based on a report published this week.

Pat Conaty, one of the report's authors, says the housing repair problem is part of the wider issue of financial exclusion. "The repair and improvement market for the middle classes is wide open. They live in the right part of town where values are going up and the building societies are desperate to keep their business. But in low-income areas, there are issues about property values and people being laid off work. It puts lenders off."

On top of this is the classic dilemma of small-scale finance. Small amounts are difficult for commercial lenders to handle because of the transaction costs. It can cost a bank or building society £500 to make a loan, which eats up the profit on loans of less than £5,000.

But experience with micro-credit in this country and abroad shows that such loans can work. The report, Stopping the Rot, cites the experience of Neighbourhood Lending Services in Chicago, which had to write off less than 0.5% of home- improvement loans over 10 years.

Aston Reinvestment Trust (Art) was set up to fill this finance gap in the small enterprise sector in Birmingham. Now, with Art Homes, it is trying to do the same for building repairs. Birmingham city council has agreed to fund a pilot scheme for three years; a former senior manager at the Nationwide Building Society has been recruited to lead a small team; and a deal is about to be concluded with a high-street bank to provide £250,000 of initial capital.

The target is £1m. Conaty says: "Demand for this is really going to take off." His optimism is based on US experience with similar schemes and the results of research among residents in the Birmingham neighbourhoods of Kings Heath, Tyseley and Sparkhill.

The vast majority of the people questioned had done some repairs over the past five years, but most said more work was needed, with windows, roofs and damp-proof courses the most common.

Across Birmingham, 15,000 households are already in the grant queue. Art Homes aims to break this logjam. With financial support from the council, it can afford to make small loans: the expected range is £1,500 to £3,500 and the scheme should be running by November.

 Stopping the Rot is available at £10, inc p&p, from Art Homes, The Rectory, 3 Tower Street, Birmingham B19 3UY

fields.headline: M&S reveals e-commerce deals
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer dazzles City with plans to rejuvenate its business through digital media. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer, the high-street retailer that is undergoing a facelift, has revealed plans to rejuvenate its business through digital media.

After saving up various deals for one major announcement, M&S dazzled the City by unveiling e-commerce agreements with Beeb.com, Telewest, Open and MSN - so much so that its share price shot up 8.75p on Wednesday morning.

The aim is to position M&S as a multi-channel retailer, and M&S products are to be sold through the TV for the first time.

As part of the new strategy, M&S, which took its time warming to e-commerce, said it would ensure that more than 3,000 products are available on its website by Christmas.

The internet deals mean M&S will take the premier position on MSN.co.uk's revamped shopping channel, MSN shopping. And it will have a strong presence on the Beeb.com shopping portal.

The TV deals mean M&S can sell products through an interactive service, which will go live on Telewest next month and on Open in the middle of next year.

"The development of our multi-channel offer means that we will be able to give our customers greater choice and improved customer service, while enabling us to maintain a closer relationship with them throughout the transaction process," said Keith Bogg, director of Marks & Spencer Home & New Selling Channels.

fields.headline: French truckers rebuff government
fields.trailText: France's largest road hauliers' union today rejected government concessions on fuel prices as inadequate, voting to continue a crippling blockade of the country's oil refineries and depots that has choked petrol stations of supplies and left motorists searching desperately for a fill-up.
fields.body:
France's largest road hauliers' union today rejected government concessions on fuel prices as inadequate, voting to continue a crippling blockade of the country's oil refineries and depots that has choked petrol stations of supplies and left motorists searching desperately for a fill-up.

Transport minister Jean-Claude Gayssot said he hoped the hauliers would be "reasonable" and accept his offer, made overnight, of a 3.5p per litre reimbursement on fuel taxes this year and a 2.5p refund next year. However the National Federation of Road Hauliers said it was preparing to "reinforce its mobilisation".

New meetings between the minister and haulage firms' representatives, who had initially hailed the offer as a victory, were planned for later today. But protestors blocking the entrances to some 85 refineries and fuel depots throughout France said they had no intention of backing down.

"We are going to maintain our blockade and keep up the pressure," said Arnaud Dujardin, leader of the UNOSTRA haulage firms' federation in Dunkirk. "The government has to understand the proposals made last night are not enough."

Oil giant TotalFinaElf said over 80% of its 6,000 petrol stations in France had now run dry, and local authorities in 51 of France's 96 administrative districts introduced fuel-rationing measures or ordered pumps to serve only doctors, police and the emergency services.

Adding to the chaos, farmers, taxi drivers, private ambulance drivers, coach operators and even refuse collectors joined in the truckers' blockade in many regions, threatening to start independent campaigns if they were not offered similar tax cuts to compensate for soaring fuel prices.

Meanwhile in Paris, about 20 barges and bateau-mouche sightseeing boats had blocked all traffic on the river Seine by mid-morning.

Protestors say the cost of diesel fuel has risen 40% in the past year to about 55p a litre - one of the highest rates in Europe, mainly due to France's high state fuel taxes - and they risk going out of business unless the government takes urgent action.

fields.headline: Media Monkey business
fields.trailText:
Mo better box
Word that retiring Labour MP St Mo of Mowlam is considering a TV career has got the Media Monkey flicking through its contacts book in search of old broadcasting muckers who may be able to help out. The first call will undoubtedly be to the ITV Network Centre, where they are still a chief executive short of a full ITV Council. St Mo would be the ideal candidate - after all, she has plenty of experience of a job where people are always knifing you in the back. But Media Monkey would welcome other suggestions...

Mo better box
Word that retiring Labour MP St Mo of Mowlam is considering a TV career has got the Media Monkey flicking through its contacts book in search of old broadcasting muckers who may be able to help out. The first call will undoubtedly be to the ITV Network Centre, where they are still a chief executive short of a full ITV Council. St Mo would be the ideal candidate - after all, she has plenty of experience of a job where people are always knifing you in the back. But Media Monkey would welcome other suggestions...

"Nasty" Nick snapped
Media Monkey is certain the Sun, as the official Big Brother newspaper, will be gagging to get its hands on some photos reportedly doing the rounds, which show "Nasty" Nick Bateman in his first public clinch with a member of the opposite sex since being evicted from the house of two-way mirrors. The offending snaps, taken outside the Met Bar after the TV Quick awards on Tuesday night (September 4), are said to feature Nick in a warm embrace with, er... go-getting Sun TV reporter Emily Smith. All in the line of duty, no doubt.

Sky's the limit
Does the low cunning of the BSkyB marketing department know no bounds? Imagine little Johnnie and Jemima's delight when, after a spot of bulletin reading courtesy of Sky News during their visit to the Millennium Dome, they are given a videotape of the performance to take home and treasure. Imagine their disappointment when, on getting home and watching the video, they have to sit through several minutes of trailers for Sky TV services before glimpsing their brief moment of fame. Fiendishly clever.

A few Choice words
The dirtiest catfight in telly, Terry Wogan v Stuart Murphy, splutters on in the letters column of BBC in-house organ Ariel. You may recall that in a letter to Ariel last week, BBC Choice head honcho Murphy launched a stout defence of the BBC following La Wogan's recent attack on the corporation, telling him he was "living in a bizarre fantasy world of an Auntie's Bloomers script". This week in Ariel, BBC broadcasting and presentation staffers Mark Thomas and Christina Dunley leapt to Wogan's defence, accusing Murphy of "wanting us to work for a Stalinist BBC where employees dare not utter any criticism of their masters". The pair conclude: "Let's face it Stuart, Choice has never delivered on the promise of its name... the sooner BBC3 rises from its ashes the better." Miaow!

Don't talk at Talk
The queen of New York publishing, Tina Brown, is giving Brits abroad a bad name. Staff members at Talk magazine have been told not to approach Ms Brown directly with ideas or questions, as their input is "driving her crazy". New York magazine reports gleefully that the new rule is that editorial director [Bob Wallace] or his direct underling [Perry van der Meer] must filter Tina's traffic. Wallace disputes the account, saying that while Van der Meer -- who worked under Brown at The New Yorker -- was brought in recently to streamline the editorial process, "anyone can still come to Tina and me or e-mail us at any time about any issue. And believe me, they do." The New York Times' source notes sorrowfully: "No one wants to hear that they're driving their boss crazy." Ms Brown is in England on holiday.

Croaky name?
It's official: advertising agency names are getting sillier. First there was Mother - the trendy, Clerkenwell-based agency that looks after Harvey Nichols and Hoegaarden Beer. Then the disgraced political lobbyist Derek Draper launched an ad agency and mysteriously decided to call it Farm. Now Swiss banking giant Credit Suisse - a company that's surely old enough to know better - has appointed an agency called Strawberry Frog to handle its ads. It makes you long for the good old days, when adland was full of egotists who called their agencies after themselves, and had done with it.

A little unfortunate
Marks & Spencer has been trying to do its bit for normal women by using unusually curvaceous models (to put it politely) in its new ad campaign. So it was unfortunate that only the day before the distinctly uncurvy Tara Palmer-Tomkinson appeared on the front page of the Daily Mail as the new face of Splendour.com - a lingerie-selling website in which M&S has a stake. A small case of double standards, perhaps?

No small beer
Far be it from us to suggest that anyone in advertising takes the whole business of making ads too seriously. But the reaction of Heineken international marketing manager Frazer Thompson to the French ban on alcohol ads may have been a little extreme. "In France the world has gone dark," said a grief-stricken Thompson.

Toilet watch
News that Channel 4 is planning to bring out a Big Brother jigsaw in time for Christmas has inspired the Media Monkey to ponder what other sensational TV tie-ins broadcasters may have up their sleeves. We'll start the ball rolling with the mouth-watering prospect of Channel 4 linking up with Armitage Shanks and Triton to bring out Big Brother-branded toilets and showers with built-in CCTV cameras. Other suggestions welcome.

Obvious passion
It seems that some people who are involved with the media juggernaut that is Big Brother are not satisfied with being stuck in the wings and are itching to get into the limelight. Step forward Jason George (from Big Brother website designer Victoria Real ), James Herring (whose company, Avalon, is handling Big Brother's PR) and Charlie Gardner (PR for Big Brother producer Endemol UK), who late one night during the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival were overheard auditioning for the role of the show's voiceover man in the George Bar. Queue much repetition, in cod Geordie accents, of illuminating lines such as: "Craig realises he is being filmed..."

Duddy phone
Terry Duddy, chief executive of Argos, was ominously silent after parent company Great Universal Stores bought Jungle.com for a bargain £37m. Was he furious that the Argos internet operation had to link up with a company that has debts of £10m? No, Duddy's mobile phone kept cutting out, leaving many members of the press quote-free. Heads might roll if it transpires he got his handset from the local Argos.

Family misfortune
Congratulations are due to Rafik al-Hariri, ex-prime minister of Lebanon, after his storming victory in the country's general election. But the population of the middle east country must be praying his political judgment is sharper than his eye for the stock market. Al-Hariri's family are said to have been heavily involved with catastrophic online clothes retailer Boo.com, which folded with debts of £25m. Bet he didn't put that in his manifesto.

webTitle: Moving on: Greenham women call it a day after 19 years

fields.headline: Moving on: Greenham women call it a day after 19 years
fields.trailText: There were emotional scenes at Greenham Common yesterday when women peace campers finally left the site after exactly 19 years of continuous presence.
fields.body:
There were emotional scenes at Greenham Common yesterday when women peace campers finally left the site after exactly 19 years of continuous presence.

A group of about 40 campaigners gathered to watch the last caravan leave on the back of a lorry.

There will no longer be a permanent presence at the site, but the work of the peace camp will continue - members are trying to raise pounds 100,000 for a memorial site to commemorate their battle against the nuclear weapons based there.

Sarah Hipperson, a member of the project's commemorative fund appeal collective who has been part of the camp since 1983, said: "It has been wonderful.

"Our time at Greenham is an experience I'd never want to have missed.

"I feel very privileged. I don't think I could have spent this part of my life in a better way."

fields.headline: The Millennium Dome
fields.standfirst:
The future of the Millennium Dome hangs in the balance after yesterday's announcement that it is to be given yet another handout - £47m of lottery cash - to enable it to stay open until the end of the year. Patrick Butler explains how Britain's flagship millennial exhibition got itself into so much trouble
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The future of the Millennium Dome hangs in the balance after yesterday's announcement that it is to be given yet another handout - £47m of lottery cash - to enable it to stay open until the end of the year. We explain how Britain's flagship millennial exhibition got itself into so much trouble.
fields.body:
Why are the dome's finances so rocky?
The dome's failure to attract enough visitors since it opened to the public in January 2000 has plunged it into financial crisis. It originally aimed to attract 12m visitors in the first year; this figure was swiftly downgraded to 10m just four weeks after launch. This month, the dome's organisers, the New Millennium Experience Company (NMEC), announced that it expected to attract just 4.5m paying visitors over the year. Even in its best month, July, when 606,000 people visited, figures trailed targets by 4,000 a day.

How much has the dome cost?
The dome itself cost £700m to build, including £400m from lottery funds and £160m from commercial backers such as British Airways. It received a £60m subsidy in January, and a £29m subsidy in May, after which NMEC said that the dome was "fixed" and that it would need no more handouts. However, in August it received a £43m "advance" on the £106m sale of the site to leisure and entertainment developers Dome Europe. The injection of £47m announced yesterday is aimed at keeping the dome solvent and open for business until the end of the year, bringing total dome spending to around £870m so far. By December, the final bill for the dome is expected to reach £1bn.

Hasn't the dome been sold?
In July, Dome Europe and its financial backers Nomura International beat off five rivals to win the right to buy the Greenwich site for £106m and begin redeveloping the dome from 2001. It announced plans to invest £800m to create an "urban entertainment resort" combining "enthralling interactive attractions", shows, cultural events, hotels and restaurants, and educational "experiences." But Nomura now maintains that it has not signed the contract to buy the dome, and that it needs to study the dome's new financial projections to see if its own ambitious plans remain viable.

Why is Nomura suddenly so jittery about buying the dome?
Nomura agreed to underwrite Dome Europe's plans to revitalise the site to the tune of £400m. This investment was based on what now appears to be possibly misleading business projections for the dome given to potential buyers in July. A subsequent review of NMEC's finances has indeed revealed "serious failings" in its "financial management". There are now fears that an examination of the dome's true financial position will reveal it to be a lame duck, and that Nomura and Dome Europe will walk away.

How does the dome's performance compare to other millennium project attractions?
Scotland's showcase millennium attraction, Dynamic Earth in Edinburgh, which opened in July 1999, had exceeded its annual visitor target of 434,000 by May 2000. It cost £34m of which £15m came from the lottery. The Lowry Centre in Salford, which opened in April 2000, cost £106m, of which the lottery contributed £68.9m. It aimed to attract 77,000 visitors over 12 months. It attracted 70,000 in its first week and in 420,000 in its first five months. The Tate Modern art gallery in London, which received £50m from the Millennium Commission, anticipated 2m-3m visitors in its first year. Since it opened in May, over 2m visitors have passed through its doors.

What is the future for the dome?
The minister in charge of the dome, Lord Falconer, says he can give "no guarantee" that the dome would require no more money to stay open until the end of the year, although he is confident that the latest bailout will be the last. He said the £47m handout was less than it would cost to close the dome early. Even if it stays the course, much will depend on whether Nomura and Dome Europe press ahead with their plans. If the Nomura deal collapses, the costs of closing the site, and paying off creditors and staff, will add scores of millions to the already massive costs of the dome.

It received a £60m subsidy in January, and a £29m subsidy in May, after which NMEC said that the dome was "fixed" and that it would need no more handouts. However, in August it received a £43m "advance" on the £106m sale of the site to leisure and entertainment developers Dome Europe. The injection of £47m announced yesterday is aimed at keeping the dome solvent and open for business until the end of the year, bringing total dome spending to around £870m so far. By December, the final bill for the dome is expected to reach £1bn. Hasn't the dome been sold? In July, Dome Europe and its financial backers Nomura International beat off five rivals to win the right to buy the Greenwich site for £106m and begin redeveloping the dome from 2001. It announced plans to invest £800m to create an "urban entertainment resort" combining "enthralling interactive attractions", shows, cultural events, hotels and restaurants, and educational "experiences." But Nomura now maintains that it has not signed the contract to buy the dome, and that it needs to study the dome's new financial projections to see if its own ambitious plans remain viable. Why is Nomura suddenly so jittery about buying the dome? Nomura agreed to underwrite Dome Europe's plans to revitalise the site to the tune of £400m. This investment was based on what now appears to be possibly misleading business projections for the dome given to potential buyers in July. A subsequent review of NMEC's finances has indeed revealed "serious failings" in its "financial management". There are now fears that an examination of the dome's true financial position will reveal it to be a lame duck, and that Nomura and Dome Europe will walk away. How does the dome's performance compare to other millennium project attractions? Scotland's showcase millennium attraction, Dynamic Earth in Edinburgh, which opened in July 1999, had exceeded its annual visitor target of 434,000 by May 2000. It cost £34m of which £15m came from the lottery. The Lowry Centre in Salford, which opened in April 2000, cost £106m, of which the lottery contributed £68.9m. It aimed to attract 77,000 visitors over 12 months. It attracted 70,000 in its first week and in 420,000 in its first five months. The Tate Modern art gallery in London, which received £50m from the Millennium Commission, anticipated 2m-3m visitors in its first year. Since it opened in May, over 2m visitors have passed through its doors. What is the future for the dome? The minister in charge of the dome, Lord Falconer, says he can give "no guarantee" that the dome would require no more money to stay open until the end of the year, although he is confident that the latest bailout will be the last. He said the £47m handout was less than it would cost to close the dome early. Even if it stays the course, much will depend on whether Nomura and Dome Europe press ahead with their plans. If the Nomura deal collapses, the costs of closing the site, and paying off creditors and staff, will add scores of millions to the already massive costs of the dome.

fields.headline: Out of stock
fields.standfirst: Faced with huge debts, Glasgow's Labour authority is preparing to get rid of all its council housing, despite mounting opposition.  Peter Hetherington reports on a case with implications for big cities throughout Britain
fields.trailText: Faced with huge debts, Glasgow's Labour authority is preparing to get rid of all its council housing, despite mounting opposition. Peter Hetherington reports on a case with implications for big cities throughout Britain.
fields.body:
Her flat is damp. It has no central heating. Pipes are "constantly" leaking. Now her one-year-old son has asthma. Charlotte can rattle off a long list of other complaints about high-rise living on the edge of Glasgow city centre. But like many tenants battered by bureaucracy's apparent inability to tackle basic repairs, she has given up hope.

Even scaffolding, clamped to the side of the crumbling 60s structure, in a belated stab at installing double glazing, fails to impress the 22-year-old. "They should knock this lot down instead of putting all these windows in," she says, a faint smile betraying deepening resignation. "Everything here is bad, really bad. It's like the house that Jack built, freezing in the winter and damp in the summer. I hope to get out soon -to England."

Across what passes for a square in the St George's Cross district, littered with rubble and broken glass ("more wear and tear than vandalism - don't blame the weans [children]," sighs a middle-aged woman) Gordon Dodd is walking his six-year-old son home in the late evening. While his low-rise flat nearby is in slightly better repair - "although heating would be nice" - he is under no illusions about the scale of the problem facing Britain's biggest council landlord. "To be honest, half the houses in Glasgow need to be bulldozed and rebuilt. These big blocks of flats [the city has 150] are no use to man or beast. They're in a terrible condition."

A mile away, surveying the city from his new office in Glasgow's business quarter, the man charged with sorting out a housing crisis would not disagree. "The stock is in a hellish condition and everyone realises it is not fit for the 21st century, for the dignity of people who want to stay in their homes," admits Bob Allan, chief executive of the embryonic Glasgow Housing Association (GHA) and former head of a nearby local authority. "It's saddled with debt, dampness, cold, poor electrics - everything far worse than the UK average."

After years of defensiveness, no one in authority disputes that the city's 94,000 council flats and houses are among the worst in Britain. Only a quarter reach acceptable standards, while a further quarter are seen as "saveable". The remaining 50%, in areas like St George's Cross and elsewhere, are in such poor condition that they face an uncertain future in a city which, because of low demand, has been demolishing 2,300 council houses annually since 1993.

Saddled with a housing debt approaching £1bn and facing a repairs backlog of £1.2bn for stock deteriorating by the day, Glasgow city council has thrown ideology to the wind. Memories of that old political cliche, Red Clydeside, may still linger in older hearts; after all, the government in 1919, fearing a Bolshevik uprising, put tanks on the streets outside the city chambers.

But now the Labour pragmatists running the city chambers have decided to get rid of that monument to municipal socialism - council housing. In a move certain to set the pace for big English cities - notably Birmingham - it is preparing to hand over its entire stock to Allan's housing association next year, provided tenants vote "yes" in a city-wide ballot.

The move has become a cause célèbre for the Scottish executive and the young minister for communities, Wendy Alexander, whose enthusiasm and direct involvement - she co-chairs a steering group with councillors - has clearly ruffled feathers in the marbled city chambers.

"We have an opportunity to create a new, positive spirit in many communities," Alexander has said. "From initial soundings with tenants' groups there is a genuine desire for constructive change. Tenants will lead the way throughout the entire process . . . this will be for the people of Glasgow, by the people of Glasgow."

As part of the deal with the council, the executive has agreed to go one step further than its Whitehall equivalent by servicing Glasgow's housing debt from its own funds. Free of this financial albatross, the emerging GHA would then set about tackling the repairs backlog and (in Allan's words) "rebuilding communities". As debt repayment accounts for half the average weekly rent of £45, this is no mean subsidy.

The other attraction for the council, target of constant sniping from disgruntled tenants, is that housing associations, unlike local authorities, can get loans from banks and building societies - using the income stream from rents as collateral. As a result, the council hopes that institutions, including possibly the European Investment Bank, will help raise around £1.6bn over 10 years to smarten up what remains of the former municipal stock.

Both Alexander and the council are adamant that the GHA must be a non-profit making mutual association, controlled by communities and not by businessmen. After the ballot, the idea is to shift control to some 14 area organisations - and eventually fur ther down the chain to smaller associations of about 500 houses each.

But assurances of mutuality have failed to halt criticism that the housing transfer smacks of backdoor privatisation. Tommy Sheridan, a Scottish Socialist Party councillor and a member of the Scottish Parliament, says opposition will match the great anti-poll tax campaign, which he led in the late 1980s. "This will develop into a very bitter and bloody battle," he insists. "There is a tremendous amount of fear. For the first time in modern history, Glasgow will be left without a council house if this goes through."

Sean Clerkin, who chairs a Glasgow-wide campaign against stock transfer, claims the plan is not only a "test bed for council house privatisation throughout the UK", but also an issue which could seal Alexander's fate as a minister. "It will either be her big success story," he says, "or the noose that hangs her because she's that closely associated with it."

Charlie Gordon, Labour leader of Glasgow, accepts the issue is so emotive that the council and the Scottish executive have some way to go in convincing 94,000 tenants. He says: "There is a folk memory in Glasgow of what it was like renting from private landlords and older people [over a quarter of tenants are pensioners] remember exploitation and the rest of it."

If a ballot were held tomorrow -rather than next year - Gordon accepts that the plan would be overwhelmingly rejected. "This is a process and we are still in the early stages," he says, accusing opponents of being "politically motivated dogmatists", unwilling to accept plans for "another form of social ownership".

Others are not so restrained. In a recent newsletter, produced on behalf of the council and the Scottish executive, critics were accused of feeding Glaswegians "a diet of fear, half-truths and misinformation" about rocketing rents, widespread redundancies, and privatisation.

But with more than 2,000 staff in the housing department, and a further 3,000 employed by the council's direct labour organisation (DLO) - mainly on council house repairs - job losses are clearly a fear. That is why the Scottish TUC is opposed to the scheme, although job assurances, and a commitment to give a contract to the DLO after the transfer, will be given. Allan's next step will be formally to present a transfer package to the council by the end of the year, outlining investment and rent levels, the structure of his organisation and tenancy agreements. If the authority accepts, plans for a ballot will be set in train.

To win hearts and minds, he says publicity material will have to be free of hype and spin. "We have to do this in an honest and open way rather than as a smart piece of salesmanship." In the end, he believes they will get a "yes". "But we will have to work hard for it."

One thing is clear. If the vote goes against the council and the Scottish executive - so far, in smaller author ities, stock transfer ballots have exceeded general election turnouts - ministers will not let matters rest. "The status quo is not an option," insists Allan.

But in St George's Cross, and elsewhere, it is clear that the GHA has some explaining to do. "I'm afraid they might make us go private," laments Jean Thomas, who has lived on the 11th floor of a block for 23 years. "You hear so much about private landlords putting you out. We're all right the way we are, aren't we?"

Gordon Dodd isn't so sure. "To be honest, I don't think there is an option. I'll vote yes. It's a bold step they're taking. I just hope housing remains an integral part of society in the future. I was with a private landlord before I got a council flat and wouldn't like to go back to that."

South of the border

In England, 450,000 houses have already been hived off, with 165,000 likely to follow in this financial year - although 3.2m still remain in council hands. But no big city has transferred its housing, largely because of uncertainties over huge debts. Birmingham, with a debt of £650m, is holding talks with the Department of the Environment, but the ruling Labour group is clearly divided on the issue. The Conservatives have accused unions, and Labour dissidents, of being at odds with the official line on transferring 92,000 homes - slightly fewer than Glasgow - to a series of social companies.

While English ministers insist that councils will not be forced to get rid of their houses, the Chartered Institute of Housing has calculated that 200,000 homes annually will have to be transferred if the government is to meet its target of clearing a £19bn repairs backlog in 10 years.

But the scale of the challenge to win over tenants was illustrated last month at Wycombe district council, Buckinghamshire, when tenants opposed transferring 7,150 houses to a new social landlord in a postal ballot which registered a near 70% turnout.

fields.headline: Mowlam high on Labour agenda
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam is set to take centre stage at the Labour conference this month, with a platform performance highlighting the war on drugs and a headline appearance at the Tribune rally, the traditional forum for dissent at the conference.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam is set to take centre stage at the Labour conference this month, with a platform performance highlighting the war on drugs and a headline appearance at the Tribune rally, the traditional forum for dissent at the conference.

She is also to speak at a rally of Charter 88, which campaigns for a "modern and fair democracy", where she will insist that the party rank and file should remain vital to modern politics.

Ms Mowlam, Cabinet Office minister, saddened Labour members and many non-partisan observers when she announced on Monday that she would stand down at the next general election. It fuelled accusations that Tony Blair had misused her talents.

Conference organisers said Ms Mowlam would always have been given a prominent slot at the conference. But in the light of her resignation the backroom staff are likely to rejig the agenda to make sure that she is seen to be given the biggest possible slot.

She is also certain to be given an emotional standing ovation. Downing Street will be worried that it could be interpreted as an implicit attack on Mr Blair's treatment of her.

Ms Mowlam yesterday countered suggestions that she had been forced out of politics by the Labour "boys' club" or by jealousy on the part of the prime minister. She said she was still "good friends" with Mr Blair.

At her meeting with him on Monday "what he ended up by saying was that he would miss me", she said. "But he said that if I thought I was taking the right decision for me then he would live with it."

She went on: "I just want to try something different now. Politics will always be a part of me, and I will continue to work as hard as I always have up to the next election. Parliament will also always be in my soul, but whether it will be in my future I cannot say."

Ms Mowlam also countered suggestions that she had authorised Julia Langdon's forth- coming biography of her. The book is certain to deal with the rumours surrounding the leading politicians who may have briefed against her.

Ms Mowlam conceded that she had read a draft for factual inaccuracies but said she had not commented on the book's opinions.

She also sought to play down suggestions that she was at war with Peter Mandelson, who succeeded her as Northern Ireland secretary. She said she still talked to him and implied that he would be on the invitation list for her leaving party.

"I am not bitter or angry with anyone," she said. "This was a personal decision."

Ms Mowlam, 50, who had "no idea" yet what she would do when she left parliament, said serving as Northern Ireland secretary had been her most enjoyable time in politics.

She has said she is attracted to the idea of becoming an international peace conciliator.

She will get an early chance to practice her hand as an international peacemaker when she attends a conference soon to be held in Madrid on the peace talks in Colombia. President Clinton last week allocated more than $1bn to Colombia to help its government fight drug traffickers and growers.

Meanwhile the row over her departure ignited again with comments from veteran Labour stalwart Baroness Castle who said the higher reaches of government were too male dominated. "I do think that women's representation in government will suffer from Mo's departure and the Cabinet will be the weaker for it," she said.

webTitle: Fawlty Towers tops list of TV Golden Oldies

fields.headline: Fawlty Towers tops list of TV Golden Oldies
fields.standfirst: Nostalgia wins the day as newer programmes are pushed down BFI ratings poll
fields.trailText: September 6: TV Golden Oldies list shows 72 out of 100 programmes were made by the BBC, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Through the fog of today's endless repeats, tacky game shows and trashy films, a golden age of British television shone yesterday when jaded writers, producers and critics turned back the decades to identify the all-time smallscreen greats.

In a list of 100 television programmes picked for the British Film Institute, the most recent of the top 10 was first shown in 1982. The greatest television programme in broadcasting history was named as Fawlty Towers, currently enjoying prime-time exposure on BBC1.

As the BBC struggles to redefine itself in the digital age, the corporation could take comfort in the knowledge that it is still regarded as a powerhouse of quality programmes: 72 of the top 100 were BBC shows. The first three in the list, Fawlty Towers, Cathy Come Home and Doctor Who, were all seminal moments in modern cultural history.

While more contemporary programmes figured lower down in the poll - perhaps reflecting the perspective of the voters rather than the quality of the shows - it is clear that broadcasting brilliance is still within the grasp of TV creatives.

Changing nature
Yet, in an illustration of the changing nature of broadcasting, many of today's hits have come from outside the big broadcasting institutions - the Royle Family sitcom (31st in the list) was written by Caroline Aherne and Craig Cash before it was picked up by Granada and sold to the BBC; the game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (23rd) came to ITV from the then little-known production house Celador; and the Wallace and Gromit animation The Wrong Trousers (18th) was picked up by the BBC from Aardman productions.

Our Friends in the North (25th) stood out as one of the few truly in-house modern BBC dramas in the top 50.

Joan Bakewell, the broadcaster and chairwoman of the BFI, said many of today's shows would be regarded as classics in the future. "Nostalgia plays a large part in people's love for programmes. As they recede into the past, you forget their faults. It conjures up a time in our lives when we were less stressed, younger and life was easier."

The BFI polled 1,600 programme makers, critics and executives with a list of around 600 suggested programmes to choose from - voters could add their own - and just over a quarter replied. They came up with five shows from the 1950s, the first significant television decade, and between 22 and 25 from the next 40 years.

Gerry Anderson, creator of Thunderbirds (60th), said of the poll: "It either says that people have fond memories of the past, or it says today's television programmes are lousy. There are so many repeats now, and you have to search around to find something different."

The top children's programme was Blue Peter (6th), which started in 1958. It is also the show with the most editions ever produced. Peter Purves, a former presenter, said its enduring appeal was due to the range of issues it covered.

"The items are about three or four minutes long, maybe five at the most if it's a film from Africa or somewhere, and in a 25-minute show that means six or seven elements, so if you didn't like one, there would be something else along soon. The concept gelled, and after 42 years, they must be doing something right."

Douglas Argent, one of the producers of Fawlty Towers, said its lasting appeal was down to the writers, Connie Booth and John Cleese. "Fawlty was such an anti-hero. Everyone agreed with him. The scripts were extremely good, each one had a strong singular plot."

Soap opera
He said that few sitcoms today came up to the same standards. "The Royle Family is the one thing that stands out in the past four or five years." The problem, he said, was that there were few good writers penning quality comedy scripts. "It's just the writers, I suppose. You sink or swim by your script."

Only one soap opera featured in the list - Coronation Street (40th). Some observers were surprised at its position, and the absence of the BBC's EastEnders.

Paul Merton, whose quiz show Have I Got News for You came 70th, said the Street should have won. "It has always done well in the ratings and it broke the mould of British television," he said. "It was the first time that working-class, northern people were shown on TV."

Granada, the soap's producer, was the most represented independent broadcaster in the list.

Michael Parkinson, who introduced the poll at a ceremony in London yesterday, and whose BBC chat show came eighth, said: "I think it shows British television is very strong. We all like to believe there was a golden age of TV, but what the poll shows is that this is not really true. There are roughly 25 shows from every decade, and that tells you a lot about the standard of British TV."

Chris Dunkerley, the critic and broadcaster, disagreed. "Whether one likes it or not, there was indeed a golden age of television."

Ken Russell, the maverick film-maker, was philosophical. "It's a only list, you know, just like a shopping list."

fields.bodyText: Through the fog of today's endless repeats, tacky game shows and trashy films, a golden age of British television shone yesterday when jaded writers, producers and critics turned back the decades to identify the all-time smallscreen greats. In a list of 100 television programmes picked for the British Film Institute, the most recent of the top 10 was first shown in 1982. The greatest television programme in broadcasting history was named as Fawlty Towers, currently enjoying prime-time exposure on BBC1. As the BBC struggles to redefine itself in the digital age, the corporation could take comfort in the knowledge that it is still regarded as a powerhouse of quality programmes: 72 of the top 100 were BBC shows. The first three in the list, Fawlty Towers, Cathy Come Home and Doctor Who, were all seminal moments in modern cultural history. While more contemporary programmes figured lower down in the poll - perhaps reflecting the perspective of the voters rather than the quality of the shows - it is clear that broadcasting brilliance is still within the grasp of TV creatives. Changing nature Yet, in an illustration of the changing nature of broadcasting, many of today's hits have come from outside the big broadcasting institutions - the Royle Family sitcom (31st in the list) was written by Caroline Aherne and Craig Cash before it was picked up by Granada and sold to the BBC; the game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (23rd) came to ITV from the then little-known production house Celador; and the Wallace and Gromit animation The Wrong Trousers (18th) was picked up by the BBC from Aardman productions. Our Friends in the North (25th) stood out as one of the few truly in-house modern BBC dramas in the top 50. Joan Bakewell, the broadcaster and chairwoman of the BFI, said many of today's shows would be regarded as classics in the future. "Nostalgia plays a large part in people's love for programmes. As they recede into the past, you forget their faults. It conjures up a time in our lives when we were less stressed, younger and life was easier." The BFI polled 1,600 programme makers, critics and executives with a list of around 600 suggested programmes to choose from - voters could add their own - and just over a quarter replied. They came up with five shows from the 1950s, the first significant television decade, and between 22 and 25 from the next 40 years. Gerry Anderson, creator of Thunderbirds (60th), said of the poll: "It either says that people have fond memories of the past, or it says today's television programmes are lousy. There are so many repeats now, and you have to search around to find something different." The top children's programme was Blue Peter (6th), which started in 1958. It is also the show with the most editions ever produced. Peter Purves, a former presenter, said its enduring appeal was due to the range of issues it covered. "The items are about three or four minutes long, maybe five at the most if it's a film from Africa or somewhere, and in a 25-minute show that means six or seven elements, so if you didn't like one, there would be something else along soon. The concept gelled, and after 42 years, they must be doing something right." Douglas Argent, one of the producers of Fawlty Towers, said its lasting appeal was down to the writers, Connie Booth and John Cleese. "Fawlty was such an anti-hero. Everyone agreed with him. The scripts were extremely good, each one had a strong singular plot." Soap opera He said that few sitcoms today came up to the same standards. "The Royle Family is the one thing that stands out in the past four or five years." The problem, he said, was that there were few good writers penning quality comedy scripts. "It's just the writers, I suppose. You sink or swim by your script." Only one soap opera featured in the list - Coronation Street (40th). Some observers were surprised at its position, and the absence of the BBC's EastEnders. Paul Merton, whose quiz show Have I Got News for You came 70th, said the Street should have won. "It has always done well in the ratings and it broke the mould of British television," he said. "It was the first time that working-class, northern people were shown on TV." Granada, the soap's producer, was the most represented independent broadcaster in the list. Michael Parkinson, who introduced the poll at a ceremony in London yesterday, and whose BBC chat show came eighth, said: "I think it shows British television is very strong. We all like to believe there was a golden age of TV, but what the poll shows is that this is not really true. There are roughly 25 shows from every decade, and that tells you a lot about the standard of British TV." Chris Dunkerley, the critic and broadcaster, disagreed. "Whether one likes it or not, there was indeed a golden age of television." Ken Russell, the maverick film-maker, was philosophical. "It's a only list, you know, just like a shopping list." webTitle: Interfocus poised to swoop on Osprey

fields.headline: Interfocus poised to swoop on Osprey
fields.trailText: Interfocus, the integrated marketing agency, will today announce that it has acquired the listed advertising group Osprey Communications.
fields.body:
Interfocus, the integrated marketing agency, will today announce that it has acquired the listed advertising group Osprey Communications.

Osprey, which counts Friends Provident and Calor Gas among its clients, is listed on the London Stock Exchange. It is headed by chief executive Chris Still and chairman Jack Rubins, who holds a 20 per cent stake.

Osprey's shares were suspended earlier this year when the company attempted a merger with architects HLM. That deal has now fallen through.

Earlier this week the Lowe Group sold its majority holding in Interfocus to chief executive and co-founder, Matthew Hooper, for an undisclosed sum. Hooper in turn sold a 60 per cent stake in the company to Maxxcom, a Canadian marketing communications specialist.

At the time, Hooper said the sale would give him the funds to make "acquisitions in advertising, direct marketing, new media and design."

No one at Osprey or Interfocus was available for comment.

fields.headline: Desmond Wilcox, acclaimed documentary-maker, dies
fields.trailText: September 6: The broadcaster and award-winning documentary film-maker, Desmond Wilcox, died in hospital early today, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The broadcaster and award-winning documentary film-maker, Desmond Wilcox, died in hospital early today.

Wilcox, 69, died at St Mary's Hospital in London in the early hours of this morning, his wife Esther Rantzen said. He had suffered from coronary heart disease for many years and undergone two heart bypass operations.

Rantzen said: "I had 32 of the best years of my life with him. He radiated warmth and light into our lives and for the moment we fear that we have lost the sunshine we depended on." She added that her husband had wished for some of his organs to be used to help others, a gesture that was typical of "an extraordinary caring and giving man".

Wilcox began his career in journalism as a reporter on a weekly newspaper in 1949, following a spell in the merchant navy. In 1960 he moved to television as a reporter on ITV's This Week current affairs programme, where he stayed for five years until joining the BBC.

But it was for the BBC that he was to make his mark with his highly-regarded documentary-making. He was co-editor and presenter of the landmark Man Alive series in 1965, pioneering some innovative documentary techniques, and formed the Man Alive Unit three years later.

From 1972 to 1980 Wilcox was head of general features at the BBC and went on to make series such as Americans, The Visit, Black in Blue and A Day in the Life. His series of six documentaries about David Jackson - the boy without a face - garnered five international awards. Wilcox was also a long-standing member of the Bafta council.

webTitle: Lycos Europe posts massive losses in annual results

fields.headline: Lycos Europe predicts further losses after disappointing annual results
fields.trailText: Internet portal Lycos Europe said it will continue to lose money until 2004 after posting massive losses in its annual results.
fields.body:
Internet portal Lycos Europe said it will continue to lose money until 2004 after posting massive losses in its annual results.

The joint venture between German media giant Bertelsmann and US portal Lycos recorded pre-tax losses of E99.7m (£61m), against a deficit of E8.7m (£5.3m) last year. The company blamed the losses on marketing and sales costs of E112.8m (£69m), despite a rise in the number of ads placed on the network.

The Neuer Markt Nemax index in Frankfurt was not impressed, marking down the Lycos Europe shares to E10.75 (658p), a fall of 13.9%. It is a dramatic turnaround in fortunes for a company which floated in March at E24 (1470p).

Lycos Europe had tried to paint an upbeat picture of its results, saying sales had risen from E10.8m (£6.6m) to E40.2m (£24.6m). It expects next year's revenue to rise by 50% thanks to its new Fireball site and finance portal.

The company's confidence is underpinned by user statistics which show that a third of all European internet users visit its network each month. Page views in June were 12.8m, compared to 4.4m for the same period last year.

fields.headline: Desmond Wilcox
fields.trailText: September 6: The late Desmond Wilcox presented and edited the BBC's first current affairs series, Man Alive, in 1965, reports Philip Purser
fields.body:
Desmond Wilcox, who has died aged 69, was a key innovator in what might be called the humanisation of current affairs television, dwelling on the joys, fears and problems of ordinary people rather than on the politicians and pundits who shaped or meddled with such circumstances. That said, Wilcox and his wife and partner, Esther Rantzen, cannot be altogether cleared from some blame for the later debasement of this branch of television, when compassion turned into exploitation.

Born in Welwyn Garden City, and thus into the heartland of early 20th-century social idealism, the young Desmond attended landlubber schools in Cheltenham and London before going to the Outward Bound sea school, and thence into the Merchant Navy in 1948 as a deckhand. His National Service soon afterwards, however, was in the army, as a lieutenant. He had already fitted in a bit of local-newspaper reporting. On release he was briefly an agency reporter, and from 1952 to 1960 on the staff of the Daily Mirror. To increase his salary, he did extra Saturday stints for the Mirror's then stablemate, the Sunday Pictorial.

While helping out on an expose of a criminal gang he was hit on the head with a car-jack, an injury which left him temporarily paralysed.

When he resumed work he was put on the "graveyard shift" in the small hours of the morning, when seldom much happens. Leafing through a trade paper he spotted a job advertisement for a reporter on a current affairs TV programme. From clues in the text he deduced that it was ITV's This Week and applied directly to Rediffusion rather than the box number given. This stroke of enterprise impressed the producers enough to outweigh his tripping over and landing flat on his face when summoned for an audition, and he was taken on.

His open face and forthright manner soon made him popular with the audience, though an item on battery chicken farming became the stuff of legend not for anything Wilcox said, but for what befell the fully stocked laying battery which a chicken farmer had been persuaded to set up in the studio. After the scene-shifters had cleared it off the set to make way for the next story, every hen and every egg had mysteriously vanished.

In 1965, Wilcox moved to the BBC 's newly established second channel to present and edit, with Bill Morton, the first current affairs series avowedly devoted to such human predicaments as agoraphobia or the search for an ideal partner, Man Alive. "They wheel a plague cart through the world," I wrote, "crying 'Bring out your dread' NOT dead. But there were some powerful episodes and within three years the Man Alive unit was a little free state within the BBC empire.

In 1972, Wilcox was promoted to be head of general features, when one of the tasks which befell him was to tell the patrician journalist Peregrine Worthsthorne, after Perry had just become the second luminary to pronounce the f-word on television, that a projected series he was to write and present would no longer be going ahead.

Wilcox was still able to conduct occasional projects of his own. Americans (1978), a series of 13 profiles of unsung, ordinary citizens, would have been a classic if only he had not succumbed to temptation or pressure from above and included two wretched celebrities, child film star Jodie Foster and the then First Lady, Rosalynn Carter.

The Visit ran intermittently from 1983 to 1985, initially as one-off films to the early cinema-verite formula of catching its subject about to undergo some crucial encounter, eg a family going to see their mentally handicapped daughter, but returning more and more to two continuing stories, one of an injured policeman 's struggle to regain the use of his legs, the other about a Scottish surgeon toiling to restore the ravaged face of a little Peruvian boy, and then to adopt him.

Meanwhile, the distaff side of his career was taking off. Esther Rantzen first came into his life as a production assistant on Man Alive. In Braden 's Week, which Wilcox and Bill Morton also edited, she was one of the perky researchers (the other was John Pitman) who appeared on the show - a television version of Bernard Braden 's long-running radio series - to deliver in person the replies to viewers' complaints about faulty services and goods they had drawn from hapless company spokesmen and public relations officers, Love bloomed, they married and were blessed not only with a family but also a continuing strand of light-hearted, consumer watchdog programmes in the Braden mould, of which That 's Life was the best-known and most durable, running from 1973 to 1994.

Behind the scenes, Wilcox remained an able and creative broadcaster, by now the head of his own production company. Over the years he won a number of Bafta awards. He published several books related to his TV series and, with Esther Rantzen, Kill the Chocolate Biscuit, a light-hearted collection of mostly funny things that had happened to them on their way to becoming one of television 's most celebrated and most durable husband-and-wife teams - if, as they recall, a source of some unease to the BBC of their early days together, when such relationships were not liked.

 Desmond John Wilcox, television producer and presenter, born May 25 1931, died September 6 2000.

fields.body:
SlateUK, the proposed British version of popular US e-zine Slate, is in talks with a number of media companies with a view to them taking a sizeable stake in the venture. Benjamin Wegg-Prosser, former adviser to Peter Mandelson and publisher of SlateUK, is doing the rounds and looking for a strategic UK media partner to invest in the operation. The partner will provide backbone services and resources to bring the venture to market next year - in return for equity.

Wegg-Prosser said he had secured some seed funding from a number of small private investors, but was hoping to raise a total of around £1.5m. He declined to detail which companies he is talking to, but said he had received positive responses.

Slate (url: Slate.com) launched in 1995 and is 100%-backed by Microsoft, which has held off from repeating the same funding model in the UK, preferring instead to take a minority stake. The deal is similar in style to Thestreet.co.uk in that it takes the name of the US sister site but is run as a joint venture in the UK. Thestreet.com merely holds a stake in the UK business.

Wegg-Prosser said he had finalised the finer details of the licensing agreement with Microsoft, which allows the company to use the name and tap into Microsoft technology, distribution, and some content.

While Microsoft's overall involvement in SlateUK will be limited, the venture will be heavily promoted across its MSN UK portal, which is expected to drive substantial traffic to the site.

MSN is one of the most popular UK sites, according to MMXI Europe, with more than 4m unique users visiting each month.

Additionally, Slate.com is reputedly a regular haunt for around 100,000 British internet users.

fields.headline: ITV dominates peaktime
fields.trailText: The return of Peak Practice and start of a three-part storyline for The Bill helped ITV to dominate peaktime last night, says Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The return of Peak Practice and start of a three-part storyline for The Bill helped ITV to dominate peaktime last night.

Long runner Peak Practice opened a new series at 9pm with 7.7m viewers and a 34.6% share, against BBC1's 9pm news (5.6m/25.2%) and the conclusion to two-part drama Waking The Dead (6.6m/27.5%), which ran from 9.30pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Before that, The Bill averaged 7.4m (34.6%) over 60-minutes from 8pm, against Vets in Practice (6.6/30.9%) and repeated docu-soap Airport (6m/27.4%) on BBC1. Later on, ITV documentary Manhunt, about the search for kidnapper and murderer Michael Sams, drew 4.5m (25.2%) from 10pm.

Manhunt no doubt suffered from the continuing Big Brother effect. The Channel 4 gameshow-cum-real-life soap has slipped from the ratings high induced by the "Nasty" Nick eviction, but is still bringing in useful numbers for the broadcaster. Last night's 35-minute instalment drew 4.4m (21.6%) from 10pm.

At 9pm last night, Channel 4 factual offering A Very British Murder (1.9m/8.3%), which looked at the controversial case of the farmer, Tony Martin, who was convicted of murder for shooting an intruder, was up against high profile BBC2 Storyville documentary One Day In September (1.7m/7.8%).

fields.headline: Mobile text messaging lifts Logica
fields.trailText: Logica's annual results took the City by surprise, thanks to the continuing boom in mobile phone text messaging, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Software company Logica's annual results took the City by surprise, thanks to the continuing boom in mobile phone text messaging.

Logica lifted pre-tax profits from £58.6m to £98.1m, with operating profits in the mobile networks division leaping from £12.4m to £33m. The group also operates in the energy, utilities and financial services sectors.

The company's SMSC messaging software carries more than half of the world's text message traffic, and contracts have been signed to roll out the system in the lucrative Japanese market.

Managing director Martin Read said: "We predict that within three years mobile telecoms operators will be sending up to 100 billion short messages per month - a 170% per year increase on current levels.

"Overall, market conditions remain positive, and in this environment the board is confident of delivering superior performance for the year ahead."

Logica shares fell 70p to 2149p in early trading, with market sentiment still damaged by poor results from rival the Sema Group on September 5.

fields.headline: Chopper granny rounds globe
fields.trailText: A Somerset grandmother today entered the record books after becoming the first woman to fly solo around the world in a helicopter.
fields.body:
A Somerset grandmother today entered the record books after becoming the first woman to fly solo around the world in a helicopter.

60-year-old Jennifer Murray from Hemington, Frome completed her 100-day, 21,750-mile flight, touching down at Brooklands airfield in Weybridge, Surrey.

Accompanying her was 49-year-old Colin Bodill, from Nottingham, who set his own record for the first solo circumnavigation of the world in a microlight. The pair landed to cheers from friends and family.

Mrs Murray said: "It's utterly wonderful to be here. We've had a great and fantastic adventure and have been very privileged to see the world the way we've seen it and meet the wonderful people we've met."

The duo left Brooklands on May 31 this year and flew in an eastbound direction passing over 30 countries, including Greece, Saudi, Arabia, Thailand, Vietnam, Japan, Canada and Greenland.

During their epic journey, the pair were ordered to leave Pakistani air space within four hours or face being shot down. Mr Bodill was also forced by the Chinese air force to land in a paddy field to avoid potentially lethal storms.

Praising her colleague, Mrs Murray said: "Colin had me unnerved time and time again as he was going through one drama after another. He's given me a lot of scary moments. I had a few, too, but I had a much stabler aircraft."

Their flight was intended to raise £700,000 for Operation Smile, a charity providing reconstructive facial surgery to underprivileged children, and was sponsored by TV and Internet company Network of the World.

A former textile designer, Mrs Murray only took up flying after husband Simon bought a helicopter but didn't have time to fly it himself.

She became the first woman to circumnavigate the world in a helicopter in 1997, when she made the journey with a co-pilot. "I've always loved a challenge. Going to the limits is very exciting," she said.

The duo decided to undertake the project after meeting an airshow two years ago. Mr Bodill said: "Jennifer asked me if I had anything planned for the millennium. I said I was flying around the world and invited her to come along. Twenty minutes later we were shaking hands on a round-the-world trip."

They have no immediate plans for a further adventure.

fields.headline: Channel 5 plans Jailbreak
fields.trailText: In the grounds of a remote Hertfordshire farmhouse, Channel 5 today unveiled the spartan quarters that will be home for 10 volunteer prisoners in the latest mutation of the reality TV game show rash.
fields.body:
In the grounds of a remote Hertfordshire farmhouse, Channel 5 today unveiled the spartan quarters that will be home for 10 volunteer prisoners in the latest mutation of the reality TV game show rash.

Locked up in a prison camp that is a cross between Colditz and a construction site, the Jailbreak participants must plot their way out to scoop a £100,000 prize. The show, which will air daily from September 12, is the broadcasters big hope for the autumn season.

Its launch was almost scuppered when presented Ulrika Jonsson pulled out with two weeks to go before transmission - health problems with her unborn child forced her to cancel - but C5 announced today that Craig Charles is stepping into the breach.

Charles, who has had his own brush with the prison system while on remand accused of rape - he was later cleared - insisted that he had been chosen because of his TV experience rather than his time behind bars.

A large number of very clever people appear to have gone to great lengths to design what is essentially an elaborate but unashamedly trashy game show. A collection of corrugated iron shacks form a mock prison camp, with two dormitory huts, a shower block, library, kitchen and reception centre furnished with items from a recently closed Scottish jail.

Inmates will sleep in prison-issue beds, supplied by the firm that provides furniture for the prison service. They will wash in shatterproof basins and shower in unfriendly blocks. Just like in real prisons there are no seats on the toilets - for security purposes, of course. There is an advanced security system with an 18ft perimeter fence topped with razor wire, infra-red detector beams and the occasional old-fashioned lock and key - and 35 guards.

It is the contestants task to discover the predetermined chinks in the system. An interactive element is almost compulsory these days: viewers can email the prisoners suggestions for escape plans. Contestants are deprived of all privileges of civilian life - they must complete prison tasks such as translating books into Braille and packing soft toys to earn £6 a week. Their cooking budget is £2.20 a day. Its a real fully functioning, all purpose nick, Charles said.

Michael Attwell, the controller of features at Channel 5, insisted Jailbreak was different from other reality TV shows like Channel 4s Big Brother. We dont know how Jailbreak is going to play on the screen, but we all think its a fantastic idea.
