webTitle: Saving the dome, trying to save face

fields.headline: Saving the dome, trying to save face
fields.standfirst:
Gerbeau's repeated optimism as he kept asking for more cash could not overcome dome's fantasy finances

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: In the years before he was plucked from the French dole queue to save the Millennium Dome, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau's job at Disneyland Paris was to look after children, who like Alice, were lost in Wonderland.
fields.body:
In the years before he was plucked from the French dole queue to save the Millennium Dome, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau's job at Disneyland Paris was to look after children, who like Alice, were lost in Wonderland.

Last night, as the dome got an extra £47m to add to the magic mountain of cash already lavished on the Mad Hatter's tea party at Greenwich, it was he who seemed a little lost.

Demoted and humiliated, having lost overall financial control to the troubleshooter David James, the previously unflappable Frenchman was struggling to summon the boundless optimism with which he has greeted each new disaster at the dome. This being the through-the-looking-glass-world of the New Millennium Experience Company, however, Mr Gerbeau's Cheshire Cat smile was still intact as he insisted the dome would make its much revised 7m visitor target.

It is now traditional on days when the dome is bailed out for Mr Gerbeau to give assurances he will not ask for any more money. There were no such assurances yesterday. Tellingly, he disappeared before journalists had a chance to question him. Asked if he had run off, Mr James said: "Embarrassment and PY are not two expressions I would put in the same sentence."

If the dome does manage to stay open until December without more subsidies - and dome insiders are sceptical about that - it will have cost a staggering £937m. Few, however, expect it to come in under a billion.

As the calls for its early closure grew louder last night, its original chief executive Jennie Page and chairman Bob Ayling, whose own brilliant careers were cut short by the debacle, could be forgiven for counting their blessings that they were kicked out so soon.

There were no such wry smiles at the Millennium Commission, which voiced its "deep disappointment" at having to dole out another £47m loan yesterday to add to the £132m it already has poured into the "black hole" that is the dome's finances. The meeting which decided that the dome should struggle on was chaired by the culture secretary Chris Smith, who is widely believed to have been against the enterprise from the start. His fears that the dome had the potential to become an own goal rather than a vote catcher for Labour have been proved right. However, he was overruled by Peter Mandelson, John Prescott and the prime minister himself, who was swayed by Simon Jenkins, the journalist and grandee who chairs the Millennium Commission.

In what has become known as the "Euan letter", Mr Jenkins promised the prime minister that the dome would be something his eldest son would be able to tell his children about. Jenkins' prediction may yet hold true - although Mr Blair's children have yet to visit the Dome - but for all the wrong reasons.

Last night the commission made no attempts to disguise the depth of the crisis. In a statement shortly after the extra money was released, it said: "In considering the application, the commission has had to recognise that without extra grant, the NMEC would have gone into immediate liquidation and the dome would have had to close. Outstanding creditors, including many small businesses, would have gone unpaid, around 2,000 jobs would have been lost, and thousands of people who have already booked would have been unable to visit." In agreeing to make the extra cash available, it wanted a complete reorganisation of NMEC's fi nancial management. It said the troubleshooting team headed by Mr James "has clear instructions to take what steps it can to reduce as far as possible the final call on lottery funds".

But last night the question being asked was why, in the face of incontrovertible evidence of the dome's financial failure, it has taken so long for the commission to demand such a root and branch overhaul.

The dome stared bankruptcy in the face as long ago as May 22 when Mr Gerbeau famously "put a gun to the head of the commission" and demanded an extra £45m to add to the £60m he negotiated to push through his rescue package in March. He got £29m.

Even as the first of that money was being spent, Mr Gerbeau said he had "fixed the dome" and all he needed to do now was overcome the negative publicity he claimed had unfairly undermined it.He also vowed he would not "ask the commission for any more handouts. We are turning the dome round," he declared. At that time, the NMEC dismissed rumours that it owed its suppliers as much as £10m as "nonsense". The true figure, they said, was around £1m. Today it emerged they owe suppliers around £15m.

By August, despite his repeated assurances to the contrary, Mr Gerbeau was back asking for more money. The extra £43m this time - which came from the sale of the site to the Japanese bank Nomura - was not a "handout", he maintained, but a loan which would be paid back. The £29m shelled out in May was also a loan which the media has "misinterpreted" as a grant. "We have never used the word grant," a NMEC spokesman explained.

Whatever the semantics, as the new supremo Mr James yesterday made clear, there was never any likelihood of these "loans" being paid back. The Alice In Wonderland accounting was not just Mr Gerbeau's. Right from the beginning, the dome's balance sheet was an exercise in wishful thinking. As the flamboyant Frenchman himself memorably put it, the projected 12m visitors on which its precarious financial equilibrium was based was "pure fairyland. It was a fantasy. Crazy, crazy, what can I say?" Mr Gerbeau's first priority when he replaced Jennie Page in January was to lower expec tations. Visitor targets were revised down to 10m then fell further to 7m. But with the dome dependent on ticket sales to keep going, and Mr Gerbeau's ability to slash costs severely limited, it was always going to lumber from one calamity to the next.

The manner of his appointment itself came to symbolise the hamfisted management and political interference which dogged the project. The minister for the dome, Lord Falconer, was behind grandiose claims that Mr Gerbeau had been the man who had turned around Disneyland Paris, when in fact he was just an ambitious young middle manager there earning around £35,000 a year.

As visitors numbers continued to fall hopelessly below the revised figures - they trailed targets by 4,000 a day even in their best month - and heavy discounting made no real dent in the deficit, Mr Gerbeau's souffle of bombast and bonhomie eventually fell flat.

With the indications clear last night that the latest £47m injection will not be enough to tide the dome over, the Liberal Democrat spokesman, Norman Baker, said the government must come clean on the costs of closing the attraction early. "Those figures need to be put in the public arena now. This grim pantomime cannot go on," he said. "We can't have a succession of blank cheques being written behind closed doors. How much lottery money are we supposed to waste to save ministers face?" Even Mr James, who was approached four weeks ago, seemed to suggest that the dome could be closed early for around £40m, with much of the staff being transferred to Nomura, who are due to take over on January 1. Others have predicted the cost of closure between £50m and £60m.

Government sources last month talked about a "line in the sand" being drawn when the dome received its last handout. That phrase was again being used last night. It remains to be seen how seriously it should be taken this time.

 The head of Germany's Expo 2000 said yesterday that the country's first attempt to stage the world fair had been a financial disaster, with visitor figures a fraction of those forecast. With projected losses soaring to 2.4bn marks (£650m), six times the original forecast, "the financial side has been catastrophic", Expo chief Birgit Breuel told West German radio.The fair is now hoping to attract a total of 14m visitors, far below its 40m original forecast.

It said the troubleshooting team headed by Mr James "has clear instructions to take what steps it can to reduce as far as possible the final call on lottery funds". But last night the question being asked was why, in the face of incontrovertible evidence of the dome's financial failure, it has taken so long for the commission to demand such a root and branch overhaul. The dome stared bankruptcy in the face as long ago as May 22 when Mr Gerbeau famously "put a gun to the head of the commission" and demanded an extra £45m to add to the £60m he negotiated to push through his rescue package in March. He got £29m. Even as the first of that money was being spent, Mr Gerbeau said he had "fixed the dome" and all he needed to do now was overcome the negative publicity he claimed had unfairly undermined it.He also vowed he would not "ask the commission for any more handouts. We are turning the dome round," he declared. At that time, the NMEC dismissed rumours that it owed its suppliers as much as £10m as "nonsense". The true figure, they said, was around £1m. Today it emerged they owe suppliers around £15m. By August, despite his repeated assurances to the contrary, Mr Gerbeau was back asking for more money. The extra £43m this time - which came from the sale of the site to the Japanese bank Nomura - was not a "handout", he maintained, but a loan which would be paid back. The £29m shelled out in May was also a loan which the media has "misinterpreted" as a grant. "We have never used the word grant," a NMEC spokesman explained. Whatever the semantics, as the new supremo Mr James yesterday made clear, there was never any likelihood of these "loans" being paid back. The Alice In Wonderland accounting was not just Mr Gerbeau's. Right from the beginning, the dome's balance sheet was an exercise in wishful thinking. As the flamboyant Frenchman himself memorably put it, the projected 12m visitors on which its precarious financial equilibrium was based was "pure fairyland. It was a fantasy. Crazy, crazy, what can I say?" Mr Gerbeau's first priority when he replaced Jennie Page in January was to lower expec tations. Visitor targets were revised down to 10m then fell further to 7m. But with the dome dependent on ticket sales to keep going, and Mr Gerbeau's ability to slash costs severely limited, it was always going to lumber from one calamity to the next. The manner of his appointment itself came to symbolise the hamfisted management and political interference which dogged the project. The minister for the dome, Lord Falconer, was behind grandiose claims that Mr Gerbeau had been the man who had turned around Disneyland Paris, when in fact he was just an ambitious young middle manager there earning around £35,000 a year. As visitors numbers continued to fall hopelessly below the revised figures - they trailed targets by 4,000 a day even in their best month - and heavy discounting made no real dent in the deficit, Mr Gerbeau's souffle of bombast and bonhomie eventually fell flat. With the indications clear last night that the latest £47m injection will not be enough to tide the dome over, the Liberal Democrat spokesman, Norman Baker, said the government must come clean on the costs of closing the attraction early. "Those figures need to be put in the public arena now. This grim pantomime cannot go on," he said. "We can't have a succession of blank cheques being written behind closed doors. How much lottery money are we supposed to waste to save ministers face?" Even Mr James, who was approached four weeks ago, seemed to suggest that the dome could be closed early for around £40m, with much of the staff being transferred to Nomura, who are due to take over on January 1. Others have predicted the cost of closure between £50m and £60m. Government sources last month talked about a "line in the sand" being drawn when the dome received its last handout. That phrase was again being used last night. It remains to be seen how seriously it should be taken this time.  The head of Germany's Expo 2000 said yesterday that the country's first attempt to stage the world fair had been a financial disaster, with visitor figures a fraction of those forecast. With projected losses soaring to 2.4bn marks (£650m), six times the original forecast, "the financial side has been catastrophic", Expo chief Birgit Breuel told West German radio.The fair is now hoping to attract a total of 14m visitors, far below its 40m original forecast.

webTitle: City doctor called to save sickly patient

fields.headline: City doctor called to save sickly patient
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: If there were even a smidgen of doubt left that the Millennium Dome is in trouble, it would have been dispelled with the appointment of David James as the third chairman in its brief life.
fields.body:
If there were even a smidgen of doubt left that the Millennium Dome is in trouble, it would have been dispelled with the appointment of David James as the third chairman in its brief life.

Mr James, 62, is one of the most high profile "company doctors" in the City, hauled in by the banks to salvage something from the wreckage of corporate disasters when all else has failed.

He is well used to what are known in the square mile as basket cases and has overseen the break up of the British Shoe Company, the rescue and subsequent sale of airline Dan Air, and the winding up of conglomerate Eagle Trust.

During his chairmanship of Eagle Trust he enjoyed his most notable brush with fame, after stumbling upon development of the Iraqi supergun.

During a visit to one of the company's subsidiaries in 1990 he noticed three steel pipes one of which looked "like a thumping great muzzle, just like a cartoon representation of a siege gun". He made inquiries and reported his findings, the first tangible evidence that part of the gun was being built in Britain, to M16.

Mr James is unlikely to be phased by the criticisms which will undoubtedly come his way in taking on the much derided dome. Another colourful episode in his career gave him a ringside seat in Tripoli at the US bombing raid on Libya, where he was trying to negotiate the release of a dozen of his staff working in the region who had been taken hostage.

In his first job he spent five years at Lloyds Bank before joining the launch team of the credit arm of Ford.

In 1973 he joined accountancy firm Cork Gully where he played a role in the rescue of a company called Cedar Holdings. This acted as a springboard to his career as a company doctor, although he prefers the title of "crisis manager".

He went on to play a bruising role in the closure of a number of manufacturing businesses during the 1970s and 80s where he faced running battles with workers.

Mr James, who is also a member of the monitoring and investigations committee for Lloyd's of London, was awarded the CBE in 1992. He is the only child of a caterer father and unmarried. It is little surprise that Mr James has had offers from publishers to write his life story. The dome, which he has said will be a "hands on" job, could provide an intriguing epilogue.

fields.headline: At this price?  KMS
fields.trailText: Knowledge Management Software may have won support in the City but its toughest test is likely to come over the next six months.
fields.body:
Knowledge Management Software may have won support in the City but its toughest test is likely to come over the next six months.

The company, which produces information retrieval software, will intensify competition with rival Autonomy when it introduces its "Universal" product before next month. Autonomy, the Cambridge-based but Easdaq and Nasdaq listed high-flier, is the current industry darling and there will be an interesting contest between the two over the coming months.

"Autonomy is a much loved stock because it's cutting- edge," said one analyst. "People like the idea that there's a number two and are waiting to see if KMS has the technology that puts it right up there."

The industry itself has huge potential. Research carried out by Ovum predicts the knowledge management market will grow from £2bn in 1999 to £8bn by 2004 because the technology is favoured in call centres, itself a rapidly growing sector, as well as on computer helpdesks.

Buying into KMS now could also be a shrewd move because there are very few companies involved in the industry and those that are will reap the rewards when it takes off over the next year.

Its ambition cannot be faulted even though the management, in the eyes of some observers, lacks the "arrogant approach" of some rivals. The past year has been nothing short of a whirlwind, headlined by a move from Ofex to the Techmark index in May this year and the raising of £26.9m in the process.

In its results for the 18 months to June 30, 2000, announced yesterday, KMS said sales were doing well at just under £2m, and a £3.25m operating loss was below budget.

The share price slipped 4p to 224.5p when the markets closed last night, off the 270p year's high but well ahead of the 100p low. The results failed to ignite the City because sales were in line with expectations. The drop is temporary. A climb back towards its high is on the cards.

webTitle: Euro ministers can talk but they can't hide

fields.headline: Euro ministers can talk but they can't hide
fields.standfirst: Little comfort for single currency
fields.trailText: European central bankers worried about the inflationary effect of the weak euro have drawn comfort from the belief that at some point the circumstances which have made the dollar such a buy against the single currency - higher US interest rates and faster growth - must change in their favour.
fields.body:
European central bankers worried about the inflationary effect of the weak euro have drawn comfort from the belief that at some point the circumstances which have made the dollar such a buy against the single currency - higher US interest rates and faster growth - must change in their favour.

Even as US economic historians are preparing to rewrite the record books and plan hagiographies on Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, the central bankers in Frankfurt are still asking when, not if, the turnaround will occur. It is a sensible enough approach. Despite the influence of the new economy, growth in the US must slow. The debate about the outlook for the US now centres on whether Mr Greenspan has engineered a "hard" or a "soft" landing. Euroland is seeing some of the structural economic changes demanded by its critics. Growth may be patchy - too fast in some areas, too slow in others - but the overall performance is likely to be in the right direction. As euroland closes the gap, so the single currency ought to rally.

One snag: the yen. Although Japanese interest rates have only just moved above zero and anticipating a recovery in the economy has become akin to waiting for Godot, the yen has given the euro a hammering on the foreign exchanges.

When it was introduced in January last year, the euro bought 134 yen. Now it is fewer than 94. Logic is not always the foreign exchange markets' long suit, but the yen/euro rate suggests there is more to the weakness of the single currency than a tendency of the euroland economy to trail in the US slipstream.

That weakness will certainly not be remedied by well-meaning statements from finance ministers of the kind reportedly planned for later this week. Rather the opposite.

Power switch
American firms came to Britain in the mid-1990s to snap up our privatised utilities, arguing there were better rates of return here. Now British companies such as National Grid and PowerGen are doing the reverse.

They have learned their lessons in their home market and are taking them to the US where regulators sign 20-year deals with plenty of incentives, unlike here where the regulator changes the rules every five years.

The stock market has been a bit jittery about National Grid's latest expansion into the US because of the large sums being spent and the rather spotted track record of British firms in the US. But the once dull utility that decorated our domestic landscape with pylons has shown a fair spark of common sense in its North American strategy so far. It built a bridgehead with the expensive-looking but well managed New England Electric System, and intends to build on that with the $3bn (£2bn) takeover of Niagara Mohawk Holdings.

Gearing is high as a result of the US acquisition programme but offset by the stake in Energis worth around £3.8bn. Niagara Mohawk has always produced plenty of cash and there are big opportunities for savings here, buoyed by synergies with NEES. National Grid wants to expand further in the US and on current form deserves shareholders' backing.

Wait and MPC
The two camps on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee will each find comfort in yesterday's monthly snapshot of the service sector. As the MPC sits down this afternoon to its deliberations over interest rates, the hawks will be able to point to robust growth in the sector to bolster their case for a rate rise, while the doves who want to see rates kept at 6% will counter with evidence that price pressures are easing.

It has been a confusing month for signals about the direction of the economy and there is every chance that the result of this week's meeting will prove to be just as much of a cliffhanger as the last when the committee divided five-four in favour of keeping rates on hold. Since it last met, average earnings growth has fallen, house prices are down and retail sales are slowing. But the revised national accounts data for the second quarter showed a sharp recovery in household spending while the pound's plunge against the dollar threatens to increase fuel and raw materials prices.

The deciding factor which won the battle for the doves last month appears to have been the exchange rate, which is acting as a brake on inflationary pressures, so the dip against the dollar is not good news for the doves. The MPC does, however, pay more attention to sterling's trade-weighted value, which has yet to fall below the 105 level seen as critical by Bank watchers.

It would only take one change of mind to swing the outcome of tomorrow's meeting. But, with inflation below the Bank's target and the lowest in Europe, expect howls of protest if Threadneedle Street raises rates tomorrow.

fields.headline: Steeled for relegation
fields.trailText: Although it will not be officially confirmed until later today, it appears that internet service provider Freeserve has done just enough to save itself from relegation to the FTSE 250.
fields.body:
Although it will not be officially confirmed until later today, it appears that internet service provider Freeserve has done just enough to save itself from relegation to the FTSE 250.

Index compiler FTSE International today gives the results of its latest quarterly review in what promises to be a gloomy day for a number of old-economy stocks.

On last night's closing prices it looks as though Anglo-Dutch steel group Corus, engineer Rolls- Royce, brewer Scottish & Newcastle, building materials firm Hanson and AB Foods - the company behind the Silver Spoon sugar and Twinings tea brands - will be out of the blue chip index.

Replacing them will be Granada offshoot Granada Media, South Africa-based IT firm Dimension Data, telecoms equipment maker Spirent, electronic devices distributor Electrocomponents and internet security firm Baltimore Technologies.

fields.headline: TMT falls halt six-day wonder
fields.trailText: On a day when TMT - telecom, media and technology - stocks were struck down by a nasty bout of profit-taking, the performance of Vodafone raised a few eyebrows.
fields.body:
On a day when TMT - telecom, media and technology - stocks were struck down by a nasty bout of profit-taking, the performance of Vodafone raised a few eyebrows.

Shares in London's biggest stock climbed 7p, or 2.46%, to 292p on heavy turnover of 230m as analysts reported back in upbeat mood after a meeting with the company.

Deutsche Bank and SG Securities restated their "strong buy" ratings, while CSFB and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson advised clients to "buy".

According to dealers, the bottom line of Monday's briefing was that, despite spending billions on next-generation mobile phone licences, Vodafone could have very low levels of net debt by the end of the year. Some were even predicting that it might have no debt if the disposal of Infostrada, its Italian fixed-line telecom business, is made in conjunction with the initial public offerings of its German equivalent, Arcor.

While definite plans for an IPO of Arcor are some way off, dealers expect news on Infostrada in the next few weeks.

Leading shares, meanwhile, ended lower for the first time in seven sessions, as investors decided it was time to book profits in the TMT stocks after last week's phenomenal run.

Led by a sell-off in the IT software sector, the FTSE 100 index ended 45.6 points lower at 6,752.5. All the other main indices were in negative territory, with the TechMark 100 down 184.03 points at 4,102.97.

"Everything in the TMT world has had such a massive run-up in the last week and we have been waiting for this to happen," said one dealer.

Among the blue chips, Anglo-French software group Sema was the worst performer, falling 229p to £11.21 after posting a disappointing set of interim results.

At first glance the figures seemed impressive enough. But after analysts stripped out a £14.3m contribution from a Swedish pension fund refund doubts started to creep in, with some suggesting the com pany had suffered a decline in operating profits.

While Sema said it was unfair to strip out the pension refund, analysts were not prepared to give the company the benefit of the doubt. Dresdner Kleinwort Benson cut its rating to "reduce" from "buy" and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter shifted its stance to "outperform" from "strong buy".

With Sema's figures out in the open, scrutiny turned to rival software company Logica, which reports full-year figures today. Its shares closed 205p weaker at £21.75.

Other big TMT losers included Misys, down 40p to 745p, Sage, off 28p at 650p, Colt Telecom, 178p lower at £22.80, and WPP, 37p weaker at 975p.

Anglo-Dutch software group CMG shed 34p to £13.83p, unsettled by talk of directors' share selling. A statement from the company released after the market closed revealed that chairman Cor Stutterheim had sold 200,000 shares, chief executive Tom Rusting 100,000 and deputy chairman Clay Brendish 744,000 at £13.70p each. It was also revealed that trusts connected with Mr Brendish had sold 2.5m shares.

Blue Circle managed to buck the trend, advancing 22p to 423p on news of a deal which might save it $200m a year on fuel costs.

Royal Bank of Scotland rose 31p to £13.14 after Merrill Lynch issued a weighty "buy" note. Merrill reckons the stock is undervalued relative to its British and European peers and has set a £16.50 target price.

Outside the leading index, engineer BBA slipped 51p to 427p after its chief executive quit, while media group Aegis added 7p to 203p, aided by talk that next week's first-half results will beat expectations.

In the smaller company universe, automotive parts group Bostrom surged 35.5p to 222p after agreeing a £38.5m cash offer from rival CVS but leisure management group Kunick tumbled 5.5p to 23p after warning on profits.

fields.headline: Littlewoods cuts prices and jobs
fields.trailText: Littlewoods is cutting some 250 head office jobs, including three boardroom posts, as part of a plan to reinvent the company as a rock-bottom discount retailer.
fields.body:
Littlewoods is cutting some 250 head office jobs, including three boardroom posts, as part of a plan to reinvent the company as a rock-bottom discount retailer.

The family-owned company has been squeezed by competition from "value" high street chains such as Matalan and Bhs. It intends to fight back by offering jeans for less than £10 and men's shirts for under £5

Redundancies will start at the top with the departure of operations director Mike Wynne, trading director Paul Sprague and corporate development director Jim Michie.

A Littlewoods spokeswoman said: "Internally, there is obviously a lot of sadness about this but colleagues at head office have been anticipating something."

The group's property director and human resources director, who are below board level, will also go.

Between 200 and 300 of the 2,200 staff at the group's Liverpool base will leave over the next 18 months.

The savings will release funds for a £300m investment in changing the group's 120 stores and improving new technology at its three call centres.

In April Littlewoods cut prices by 15-20%. The spokeswoman said: "We have been having a review of the business and we've got to do more than our recent price-cutting campaign."

The company was recently separated from the Littlewoods pools empire, which the cotrolling Moores family sold to leisure tycoon Trevor Hemmings for £161m.

The company also recently agreed to lease eight branches of the C&A chain, which is pulling out of Britain.

The family-owned company has been squeezed by competition from "value" high street chains such as Matalan and Bhs. It intends to fight back by offering jeans for less than £10 and men's shirts for under £5 Redundancies will start at the top with the departure of operations director Mike Wynne, trading director Paul Sprague and corporate development director Jim Michie. webTitle: Old Mutual finds buyer for unit

fields.headline: Old Mutual finds buyer for unit
fields.trailText: Old Mutual yesterday reported first-half profits up 61% to £457m from £283m and said it is on target to sell its Scottish fund management operation, Murray Johnstone, for around £150m in the next six weeks.
fields.body:
Old Mutual yesterday reported first-half profits up 61% to £457m from £283m and said it is on target to sell its Scottish fund management operation, Murray Johnstone, for around £150m in the next six weeks.

Rival Scottish investment management groups are believed to have pulled out of the bidding for Murray Johnstone, which manages £4.2bn, with the buyer now expected to be an American or European group. Old Mutual acquired Murray Johnstone after buying its parent group, United Asset Management, for $1.46bn (£993m) and said yesterday that it plans further disposals from the portfolio of investment management groups within UAM.

Despite diversifying into asset management and listing on the London Stock Exchange, Old Mutual still obtains around 85% of its profits from its South African insurance operations, where it controls one-third of the market. In the first half, it saw South African new business rise 9% and profits advance by 26%. Profits at Nedcor, its banking operation, jumped 27% to £119m but insurance profits were hit by heavy claims after severe flooding earlier this year.

Almost unknown in the City five years ago, Old Mutual has become the stock exchange's largest shareholder after a string of acquisitions of private client stockbrokers, taking in Capel Cure Myers, Albert E Sharp and Greig Middleton, to be rebranded under the name Gerrard.

 Abbey National is expected to confirm tomorrow that it is buying Scottish Provident for £2bn, resulting in windfalls for its 300,000 members averaging £5,000, but leading to the loss of more than 500 jobs.

fields.headline: Profit hopes for Corus fade
fields.trailText: Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, is expected barely to break even this year and next because of the strong pound, weak euro, operational problems and restructuring costs, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, is expected barely to break even this year and next because of the strong pound, weak euro, operational problems and restructuring costs, it emerged yesterday.

The group, which fell out of the FTSE 100 last night as its shares slumped a further 0.75p to close at 68.5p, surprised the City with a third-quarter loss despite a strong rebound in European demand and prices.

Analysts, who had expected a pre-tax profit of some £20m, instead saw a loss of £40m as problems at its Dutch plant in Ijmuiden, and at Teesside and south Wales combined with £44m of provisions for manpower cuts and continuing losses in carbon steel to keep the group in the red.

John Bryant, co-chief executive, said the operational problems unique to the industry had reduced output by 1m tonnes in the first nine months and cost Corus £60m.

The impact took the gloss off an improvement in operating losses in the first nine months: £96m compared to £354m in 1999. But this included a first-time profit contribution of £128m from Hoogovens, the merged group's Dutch arm. Pre-tax losses were £165m.

Corus said it would pay an interim dividend of 1p in October, suggesting a full-year pay-out of 3p, against market expectations of up to 6p.

Mr Bryant promised "better times ahead" but the group has set aside a further £47m for the cost of the 3,700 British jobs it is shedding, a fresh blow to earlier City forecasts of full-year operating profits of around £150m. Pre-tax earnings could be in the red this year and just above break-even next year, analysts said. Frans Willem Briet, an executive director, said earnings would have been £500m better if the pound had been at its "true" value of DM2.60, compared to the current DM3.10.

The strength of sterling has meant that, while the price of UK steel is 20% higher than last year, it is still below 1998 levels. European producers, however, have seen the price of steel go up by more than a third and at a level not seen since 1995, according to John Rennock, finance director.

Weak British demand produced operating losses of £301m in carbon steel in the first nine months, partly offset by profits of £125m in stainless steel and £80m in aluminium. Mr Bryant, who pledged a "constant and remorseless drive to improve productivity", said the group should make annual savings of £300m through the merger.

But he left a question mark hanging over vulnerable British plants, notably Llanwern, saying that everything depended on the size and quality of Corus' customer base and the rate at which, if ever, the pound enters the euro club. Corus executives indicated they could now live with an entry rate of DM2.75/2.85.

fields.headline: Old-style Mini's demise date set
fields.trailText: The last old-style Mini will roll off the production lines at Rover's Longbridge factory early next month, ending more than 40 years of continuous production.
fields.body:
The last old-style Mini will roll off the production lines at Rover's Longbridge factory early next month, ending more than 40 years of continuous production.

Industry sources say final production will take place on October 4 - soon after BMW unveils its successor to the Mini at the Paris motor show.

The Mini was launched in August 1959 when it cost just under £500 - £200 cheaper than its nearest competitor. Initially it was sold under Austin and Morris marques.

Since 1959 more than 5m Minis have been sold and although the exterior has changed little, there have been some 140 versions.

The car dominated the Monte Carlo rally in the mid 1960s and starred in a number of films, most famously The Italian Job. The man behind the Mini was Sir Alec Issigonis. The revolutionary element of the Mini's design was the decision to mount the engine across the width of the car, rather than facing forwards. That allowed the length to be kept down to 10ft.

BMW had been planning to develop a new Mini before its decision to sell Rover earlier this year and to retain the new version.

It will transfer the production line from the Longbridge factory, which was sold to the consortium that bought Rover, to the plant at Cowley, which it retained.

webTitle: Off the runway: National Express to dispose of airports

fields.headline: Off the runway: National Express to dispose of airports
fields.trailText: National Express will not take less than £200m to dispose of its two British airports, at Bournemouth and the East Midlands.
fields.body:
National Express will not take less than £200m to dispose of its two British airports, at Bournemouth and the East Midlands.

Chairman Michael Davis said yesterday that they were high quality operations, but he did not think the investment required in them would produce satisfactory returns for shareholders. National Express, one of Britain's leading bus and train operators, made it clear that it wanted to dispose of the airports by the end of the year.

The company reported pre-tax profits for the first half up 10% at £50.4 m. After charges, including the settlement of US litigation and goodwill write-offs, the group recorded pre-tax profits of £21.8 m against £39.3 m last year.

Operating profits at the British train operations, which includes the Gatwick Express and Midland Mainline, rose to £14m from £13.1m. The group is increasing its dividend by 13% to 6.5p.

Phil White, chief executive, said the company was pleased with the deal it had with the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority on the takeover of Prism.

He said the SSRA's flexibility allowed companies to come up with ideas on how railways should develop.

fields.headline: Wallpaper maker rescued
fields.trailText: The hand-printed wallpaper factory which supplied £350-a-roll Pugin paper for the lord chancellor's state apartments has been rescued after an outcry about its closure by furnishings group Walker Greenbank.
fields.body:
The hand-printed wallpaper factory which supplied £350-a-roll Pugin paper for the lord chancellor's state apartments has been rescued after an outcry about its closure by furnishings group Walker Greenbank.

The 240-year-old manufacturer Cole & Son holds a royal warrant for wallcoverings. Its paper hangs in the White House, the Palace of Westminster, the Foreign Office and in many stately homes.

Walker Greenbank upset traditionalists in May by shutting Cole's Islington premises and amalgamating the business into its modern wallcoverings operation in Loughborough.

The company yesterday announced it was selling Cole's and another upmarket manufacturer, John Perry, for £3m to a consortium led by Karen Beauchamp, a leading interior designer. Walker Greenbank's chief executive, Aidan Connolly, said: "They made us an offer we couldn't refuse. It's not a growth area - there's only ever going to be a limited market for £300-a-roll wallpaper."

Ms Beauchamp has teamed up with a former managing director of Cole's, Anthony Evans, to take the business back to its original location and rehire its workforce.

Cole's, which made a small profit of £350,000 last year, is one of the last wallpaper manufacturers using hand-carved wooden blocks to print patterns. It hit the headlines in 1998 when it supplied paper for the £650,000 refurbishment of Lord Irvine's quarters.

Its ornate Islington factory housed more than 4,000 blocks of carved designs. Long-serving craftsmen refused to move to Loughborough and critics said relocation would destroy a rare skill.

Derek Rothera, an accountant advising the new owners, said: "This is not just saving an old company, it's saving something worth saving. It will be producing lots of new and exciting products - not your Indian restaurant-type stuff but high-quality flock wallpaper."

The wallpaper industry has been through a tough period because of the popularity of paint. Walker Greenbank has suffered more than most, due to management bust-ups and technical problems.

fields.headline: Short order
fields.standfirst: Leaner times for restaurant group
fields.trailText: Trendy Italian eateries Est Est Est and Caffe Uno are "wobbling a little", according to their owner, City Centre Restaurants, which yesterday warned its profits could be below target.
fields.body:
Trendy Italian eateries Est Est Est and Caffe Uno are "wobbling a little", according to their owner, City Centre Restaurants, which yesterday warned its profits could be below target.

The company, which also owns Garfunkel's and Deep Pan Pizza, blamed poor divisional management, tough competition and the Euro 2000 football tournament for the shortfall. Its shares fell 6.5p to 49.5p.

Chief executive James Naylor said: "We had a pretty good start to the year but then May was fairly flat and June was nothing short of horrible."

The company' first-half profits fell 14.4% to £5m and it said it would be unable to make up the deficit later in the year.

The 24-strong Est Est Est chain was bought by City Centre last year. Customers include David and Victoria Beckham, who are said to be regulars at their local branch in Cheshire.

Mr Naylor said Est Est Est's operational management team performed poorly after deciding "a big company wasn't for them".

Euro 2000 cost the group £2m in sales. Mr Naylor said restaurants lost the custom of some 20m visits by people who watched the games. Fierce competition from other restaurants was also damaging.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: National Grid loses in Brazil
fields.body:
National Grid loses in Brazil

National Grid has admitted to start-up losses of £75m in the first six months of its Intelig telecoms venture in Brazil. National Grid finance director Stephen Box refused to predict how much could be lost in the full year by Intelig, a joint venture with Sprint and France Telecom.

He said one of the problems was accomodating 9m users in such a short time. The company was also hit by a high number of offpeak calls which were uneconomic.

Woolwich cash payout date

Barclays' £5.4bn takeover of Woolwich is set to be officially completed on October 24, and Woolwich's 1.1m shareholders should receive their cash and shares by November 7, it was announced yesterday. Woolwich yesterday started mailing voting packs to its shareholders ahead of two special meetings to vote on the deal taking place on October 3.

Barclays is offering Woolwich shareholders about a ninth of a Barclays share and £1.64 in cash for each share they hold. Based on Barclays' closing share price of £17.20 on August 31, the offer values each Woolwich share at 366p, which translates into a total payment of £2,404 for someone with an average holding of 657 shares.

Iceland goes cold on fridges

Iceland said it might stop selling fridges and freezers after poor figures for white goods sales took the shine off a 10% surge in half-year profits to £32m.

The frozen food chain gave an encouraging update on the progress of its recent merger with Booker, the cash-and-carry company, sending its shares up 10.5p to 304p. Iceland is reviewing its stocking of electrical goods after sales declined 7% to £29m.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: News of long-lost friends from the Tory era is always a delight, so a warm helloooo! to David Hart.
fields.body:
 News of long-lost friends from the Tory era is always a delight, so a warm helloooo! to David Hart. Once an active player in the backrooms of the Thatcher and Major governments - he hosted shooting parties for ministers at his Chadacre retreat in Herts; ran the fight against the miners strike from a Dorchester suite; and advised Malcolm Rifkind and Polly Portillo (the two tried to wangle him a knighthood) - but since 1997 he has been spookily obscure.

What a relief to find news of him in Contact, the parish newsletter serving his village of Hertest. "Pyramid mausoleum to be built at Chadacre," one section begins, reporting a parish council meeting to consider "a planning application by David Hart for the construction of a mausoleum on Chadacre estate land. This structure, to be built in the shape of a pyramid, was to house a possible 32 bodies." Blimey. What he wants with space for so many bodies may be an academic question. "It was the general opinion of the parish council that this structure was not appropriate in the position chosen." Better luck with the next position, David. Luxor, perhaps?

 Warm favourite for September's PC Brains is the genius who conceived the title of the next Crimestoppers campaign. "Finger a thief" is the name.

 Hats off England for beating the West Indies (all they have to do now is win in Pakistan and Sri Lanka, and regain the Ashes next summer, and we can start talking about a recovery) and farewell after many years as Test sponsors to Cornhill. First in line to take over, it seems, is Happy Shopper, who may already sponsor the umpires, but it's quite a leap from there to "and now for news of the first Happy Shopper Test at Trent Bridge, it's over to Pat Murphy...."

 Today we launch a major advertising campaign. If Tony Bilsborough of Cadbury's media relations department in Birmingham would care to send us all those boxes of chocolate bars, we'd be very grateful.

 Happy Shopper is owned by Booker, where - and note the smooth regional radio link - there is more sponsorship news. After Booker's recent merger with supermarket chain Iceland, Malcolm Walker, chairman of the combined firm, wants to rename the literary prize. Having rejected the Iceland prize and the Iceland Booker prize, fearing that "all the literary types would go nuts", he has decided it will continue as the Booker prize. But at the ceremony, all promotional material will read: "the Booker prize, sponsored by Iceland". Not bad, but "the Booker prize bought to you in association with Iceland, where this week packs of Bird's Eye boil in the bag cod and parsley are on special offer at £1.99" might be more elegant still.

 Confirmation that all the "Queen of New York" stuff hasn't gone to Tina Brown's head comes on New York magazine's website, where my so-called rival reports that Talk magazine staffers are "bristling over an order to maintain their distance". Tina, it seems, tired of the "constant barrage of questions and ideas," and staff have been ordered not to email, memo or approach her directly, but be filtered through the editorial director. Quite right. Don't these little people realise their editor is a very busy woman?

webTitle: Siamese twin case judges in unlawful killing dilemma

fields.headline: Siamese twin case judges in unlawful killing dilemma
fields.trailText: The complicated and emotive issue of whether an operation to separate Siamese twins Jodie and Mary would amount to the unlawful killing of the weaker sister was raised in the appeal court yesterday.
fields.body:
The complicated and emotive issue of whether an operation to separate Siamese twins Jodie and Mary would amount to the unlawful killing of the weaker sister was raised in the appeal court yesterday.

Several times during the hearing one of the three judges, Lord Justice Brooke, held up a photograph of the babies and asked how the operation could be carried out without an "invasion" of Mary's body.

The parents of the girls are appealing against a high court ruling that the operation should go ahead even though it will lead to the death of Mary, who relies on her sister for blood and oxygen.

On Monday the judges ordered that a second opinion be sought on the conclusions of the doctors at St Mary's hospital in Manchester, where the children are being cared for.

Yesterday a surgeon and paediatric cardiologist from Great Ormond Street hospital were examining the twins. Jodie and Mary - false names to protect their identity - were born at St Mary's on August 8, joined at the lower abdomen and sharing one working heart and set of lungs.

The Manchester doctors believe that Jodie could lead a full and active life if she is separated, but acknowledge that the operation would result in Mary's death. If no operation takes place, they are convinced that both would die. The parents, strict Catholics who came to Britain from a remote European community, insist that nature should take its course.

Yesterday Judith Parker QC said that if there was a "lawful way" of performing the operation, the case for performing it in Jodie's interests was "overwhelming". Responding to a question about "the best interests" of Mary, she argued: "We say there are no best interests in preserving what is unfortunately a futile life."

The court focused attention on the criminal law aspects of the case, which have been described as "astonishingly difficult". Lord Justice Ward said: "The moment the knife goes in to that united body, it touches the body of unhappy little Mary. It is in that second an assault. You fiddle about, rearrange the plumbing. An hour later you put a clamp on the aorta [cutting off the blood supply to Mary]. You cannot pretend that is not actively engaged in assaulting her integrity. For what justification? None of hers."

The judge said the parents could arguably be guilty of the manslaughter of Jodie if they did not act, but guilty of the manslaughter of Mary if they allowed the separation.

Asked whether Jodie and Mary should be regarded as "one life" in the legal sense - which could help to clear the way for an operation to save Jodie - Simon Taylor, for the parents, said that doctors and nurses at St Mary's considered the twins as separate individuals.

The judges also queried whether Mary had, in fact, been "born alive", given that she depended on her twin for her continuing existence. Mr Taylor said: "Maybe she is relying on her sister, but nevertheless she was born alive."

fields.headline: On mike, off message
fields.standfirst: Politics needs these unguarded moments Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The gloves are coming off in the US presidential race after months of phoney war sparring and boomerang polls. Labor Day electoral surveys, taken as a whole, confirm the contest as finely balanced and likely to remain so down to the November 7 finishing line.
fields.body:
The gloves are coming off in the US presidential race after months of phoney war sparring and boomerang polls. Labor Day electoral surveys, taken as a whole, confirm the contest as finely balanced and likely to remain so down to the November 7 finishing line. In prospect is possibly the closest result since 1976 when Jimmy Carter pipped Gerald Ford. Psephologists calculate that, following the party conventions, the rival camps are now fighting over a mere five million undecided votes among the 103m people expected to cast a ballot (out of 205m of voting age). This target audience can be shrunk further, to the fewer than one million undecideds who live in key battleground states.

The need to sustain nationwide appeal while wooing elusive swing voters is only one of the pressures now crowding in on the campaigns. They know they are entering the killing ground of presidential politics, a time when candidates begin to show their true colours and to make mistakes. Thus the Democrat Al Gore, over-compensating for his charisma gap, naively explains that he is "not a natural politician". Unnatural perhaps? Or simply inept? And thus the Republican George W Bush, his "keep smiling" media management lessons forgotten, is caught waspishly describing a reporter as a "major league asshole". How does he know? Perhaps Mr Bush has finally found an issue on which he is expert.

From silly to nasty is but a short step in these hothouse days. Regressing towards the negative tactics of his primary shootout with John McCain, a new Bush commercial portrays his rival as untrustworthy and untruthful. Mr Gore, wrangling over TV debate schedules, accuses his opponent of running scared from public scrutiny. The candidates' mutual dislike grows ever more obvious. With so little margin for error, it can only get more brutal. And informative. For as policy and personal differences sharpen, America's choice gets clearer by the day.

webTitle: Letters: When No really means No

fields.headline: When No really means No
fields.trailText: Hugo Young (Comment, September 5) misrepresents the launch of No, the campaign against the single currency but in favour of the European Union. The slogan of "Europe yes, euro no" is neither untenable nor an oxymoron. There is no ambiguity or dishonesty in our stance, it is simply a reflection of the complexity of the issue that we, as a group of people positively committed to the European Union, have our doubts about the viability of the euro for Britain.
fields.body:
Hugo Young (Comment, September 5) misrepresents the launch of No, the campaign against the single currency but in favour of the European Union. The slogan of "Europe yes, euro no" is neither untenable nor an oxymoron. There is no ambiguity or dishonesty in our stance, it is simply a reflection of the complexity of the issue that we, as a group of people positively committed to the European Union, have our doubts about the viability of the euro for Britain.

Hugo Young's assumption that opposition to the single currency is also opposition to the European Union is wrong. Britain's continuing membership of the EU is in no way tied to its entry into the single currency.

We are not ruling out British membership of the single currency forever. We concede that economic and political circumstance might change, making the euro more attractive. However, currently the economic and political case against membership of the euro is overwhelming.

Our commitment to the EU is reflected in our continued focus on issues such as enlargement and democratic accountability in the EU. All we seek is a modern, democratic and inclusive European Union. That is not a guise.

Navtej Dhillon
Head of research, neweurope

 I read with wonderment Hugo Young's criticism of writers who have backed the No campaign and thus "crossed the line between activism and journalism with an insouciance that is further proof of the capacity of the European question to deform many kinds of professional behaviour". The idea that it is unprofessional for journalists to have opinions is a new one on me. I have never noticed any shortage of them in Mr Young's columns, or in the Guardian in general

Nigel Farage MEP
UK Independence party

fields.headline: Hauliers cut France's fuel lifeline
fields.trailText: Petrol stations around France ran dry yesterday as a countrywide blockade of refineries and fuel depots by road hauliers choked off supplies.
fields.body:
Petrol stations around France ran dry yesterday as a countrywide blockade of refineries and fuel depots by road hauliers choked off supplies.

Drivers queued bumper-to-bumper at the dwindling number of stations still open by late afternoon, on the second day of the blockade, or drove miles looking for top-ups. In many regions, the authorities imposed a £15 limit per vehicle, or ordered attendants to serve only doctors, firefighters and the emergency services.

"It's mayhem and it's been like it all day," said Christophe Dupuis, a weary pump attendant at a supermarket petrol station in Stains, in the northern suburbs of Paris.

"Usually people spend about £15, now its £30 or £40. We're already out of unleaded. We've sold 12,000 litres since lunchtime, when the normal average would be 3,000."

As the beleaguered transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, headed into late afternoon talks in Paris with the haulage firms, who are demanding a backdated 20% cut in fuel taxes to offset soaring world prices, oil company Total said that 70% of its 6,000 petrol stations were dry and the figure could reach 90% by the end of the evening.

The blockade is supported in many areas by taxi drivers, farmers, ambulance firms, driving schools and removal companies. "This is my fourth attempt to fill up," said Eric Bouchet, a plumber, queuing at the Stains station. "The others had run out of diesel. No fuel means no work."

Mr Gayssot had earlier said that the EU and the European central bank should signal to oil producers their discontent at prices that have hit a 10-year high of more than $30 a barrel.

"Europe as a bloc - and the ECB as well, because I'd like to hear it on this issue and not just on plans to raise interest rates - should show its determination to discuss the matter, including with the Opec countries," he said. "Things cannot carry on as they are."

The blockade of some 80 depots and refineries was inspired by the success of a fishermen's blockade of most French ports that stranded thousands of British tourists last week. That ended when the government agreed to generous compensation for fishermen, including cutting social security charges.

The lorry owners dismissed out of hand an offer of a 10% cut in state fuel taxes, made late on Monday night. "We can keep going for at least a week," said René Petit, head of the National Federation of Road Hauliers. "Hundreds of firms will go out of business before the year end unless their fuel bills fall."

The oil industry federation said the protesters, who needed only to park a couple of articulated lorries and a tractor or two outside a fuel depot's gates to cut off supplies, had blocked off all sources of wholesale fuel.

The blockade hit regional airports too, with officials at Nice and Mulhouse-Basel saying they had only enough aviation fuel left for one more day. Orly and Roissy-Charles de Gaulle airports in Paris were not affected as they are supplied by pipeline.

The hauliers say France's heavy fuel taxes, second only to Britain's in the EU, and high world prices mean they cannot compete internationally.

webTitle: Letter: Why Mo felt she had to go

fields.headline: Why Mo felt she had to go
fields.trailText: It was worth buying Tuesday's Guardian simply for Roy Hattersley's piece on Mo Mowlam's impending departure (Mowlam's mistakes, September 5). His article is the only comment I've come across which seems credible. What's more, Hattersley provides analysis of Mowlam's strengths and weaknesses as a member of the cabinet, as opposed to the mindless "Saint Mo, Blair Assassin" approach of pretty much everyone else, including the Guardian Diary. I'd have thought that Mowlam dislikes, and is certainly ill-served by, this pap which ignores her actual political skills.
fields.body:
It was worth buying Tuesday's Guardian simply for Roy Hattersley's piece on Mo Mowlam's impending departure (Mowlam's mistakes, September 5). His article is the only comment I've come across which seems credible. What's more, Hattersley provides analysis of Mowlam's strengths and weaknesses as a member of the cabinet, as opposed to the mindless "Saint Mo, Blair Assassin" approach of pretty much everyone else, including the Guardian Diary. I'd have thought that Mowlam dislikes, and is certainly ill-served by, this pap which ignores her actual political skills.

There's a neat parallel between the nonsense about her cabinet demise being because she is "too popular". The late great Tony Hancock was criticised for allegedly demanding that Kenneth Williams be sacked from Hancock's Half-Hour because he was "too funny." In fact, what Hancock was trying to do was to make comedy which didn't rely on funny voices and one-liners. Williams did both. He was great, but not anyone's idea of a team player.

Chris Beer
Bath chrisbeer@cix.co.uk

 The Guardian was creditably even-handed in dealing with the departures of populist Mo and socialist Audrey (Leftwing Labour veteran Audrey Wise dies at 65, and obituary, September 5). Although it won't tell us anything we don't already know, the Friday Editor comparison of column inches devoted to both in the press at large should be interesting. Please get measuring.

Geoff Woollen
Glasgow

 When Mo Mowlam made her remarks about the wisdom of the royal family moving out of Buckingham Palace I wrote her a short letter of support, as I knew she'd be vilified for her stand. I was keen to show her that many shared her views. As I'm not one of her constituents, I didn't expect a reply but I received a sweet letter from her, by return, signed by her own hand simply: Mo.

I feel great sadness at her going. Not so much for her as a politician but because it is, I believe, the death knell of any chance that the Labour party could call itself inclusive. This is a mean-spirited boys' club that detests real women (note the gagging of Clare Short) and admits the female species only if they look and act like the little boys who run the cabal.

I don't blame Mo for leaving. But I wish she hadn't felt the need to.

Laura Marcus
Leek, Staffs Lawls@compuserve.com

 Whatever the rights and wrongs behind Mo Mowlam's departure - and I am sure that there is a great deal of truth in Roy Hattersley's assessment - it is still a kick up the "heartlands" for the ordinary voter.

Mo Mowlam and Frank Dobson were the "acceptable faces" of New Labour, politicians whose eyes, mouth and hands all said the same thing. Now we are left with career politicians who seem to spend much of their time watching their backs and where they place their feet.

Alan Pearman
Rotherham apearman@cableinet.co.uk

 Can we now move to a republic quickly so Mo can be president?

Alistair Richardson
Stirling

webTitle: Letters: Hot air, self-interest and broken promises at the UN

fields.headline: Hot air, self-interest and broken promises at the UN
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting places the blame for the failures of the United Nations over the past 55 years with the organisation itself (Nearly useless, September 4). While noting that the World Bank and IMF are far less democratic than the UN, she criticises the organisation for doing little more than "drawing up idealistic conventions" and being "near useless at getting them translated into political reality". Yet it is the governments of the world, focusing too often on narrow self-interest rather than on what is best for the world as a whole, that ensure the UN is more hot air than practical action.
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting places the blame for the failures of the United Nations over the past 55 years with the organisation itself (Nearly useless, September 4). While noting that the World Bank and IMF are far less democratic than the UN, she criticises the organisation for doing little more than "drawing up idealistic conventions" and being "near useless at getting them translated into political reality". Yet it is the governments of the world, focusing too often on narrow self-interest rather than on what is best for the world as a whole, that ensure the UN is more hot air than practical action.

Five years ago, at the 50th anniversary celebrations of the UN, the leaders of the world made 50 commitments. A report released by Charter 99 last week highlights the fact that 20 of these promises were broken outright and real progress was made on only 17 of them.

These were not arcane global political commitments; these were commitments which would have made a real difference to the lives of the poorest people in the world who currently suffer abject poverty, environmental degradation and appalling conflict.

The millennium summit will be business as usual unless the leaders of the world develop real mechanisms to ensure that all the nations of the world are able to hold international institutions and governments to account against the crucial UN development targets.

Unless this happens, the UN will continue to be the fall guy for the failings of its member states.

Simon Burall
Director, Charter 99

 If the UN is "nearly useless", one could start by changing the attitude of the United States towards it. As the world's remaining superpower and UN host nation, the US exercises a disproportionately large influence on the international body - when it wants to.

This is evident from the selection of secretary generals to the process of UN reform. The US attitude, however, has been to treat the UN as a rubber stamp for its foreign policy ambitions. When it comes to being bound by UN treaties or the International Criminal Court, exemptions rather than acceptance seem to be the rule for the US.

This, combined with the contempt of US lawmakers towards the UN, has not endeared it to other member states. The row over the US refusal to pay its overdue $1.8bn brought the conflict between the US and the UN into sharp relief.

Only when threatened with the withdrawal of its voting rights did the US finally act. Even then, the Senate foreign relations committee, led by its UN-phobic chairman, Jesse Helms, attached two dozen conditions to the payment of the dues. Now the richest nation in the world wants its contribution to the UN reduced. Hardly music to the ears of the world's poor.

The US retreat from internationalism and sidelining of the UN is clearly out of step with the mood of its people. A large majority of Americans are in favour of increased international cooperation and a stronger United Nations. Most also support the International Criminal Court and international labour standards.

If the "US problem" at the UN is to be solved, the government will need to listen more to the voices of its citizens and less to the nay-sayers in Congress. The world could be a better place for it.

Malini Mehra
London malinimehra@aol.com

The US retreat from internationalism and sidelining of the UN is clearly out of step with the mood of its people. A large majority of Americans are in favour of increased international cooperation and a stronger United Nations. Most also support the International Criminal Court and international labour standards. If the "US problem" at the UN is to be solved, the government will need to listen more to the voices of its citizens and less to the nay-sayers in Congress. The world could be a better place for it. Malini Mehra London malinimehra@aol.com

fields.headline: Fuelling fear of flying
fields.trailText: I have twice been on BA flights from New York to Heathrow when we did not have enough fuel to complete our journeys due to minor delays at London (BA wants to cut ammount of emergency fuel on flights, September 5). In both cases the alternative Americal Airline flights had no such problems, and completed their identical journey without having to stop. On one occasion there were four BA 747s waiting to re-fuel at Cardiff airport.

fields.headline: Don't forget the peasants
fields.trailText: Like Leanda de Lisle (We troubled Tories, September 4), I knew Daniel Hannan when he was an Oxford undergraduate, but thought rather more highly of him than she did. He took Firsts, spoke very good Spanish, and had a reputation for getting things done. If, as an undergraduate politician, he did not have much time for "one nation" Toryism, that is because the memory of the fiasco of the Heath government was still fresh, as was the inflation to which it gave such a boost (which did far more damage to Leanda de Lisle's countryside life than anything else, because her peasants couldn't afford cottages).

fields.headline: Cricket's day to celebrate
fields.trailText: I was one of the lucky ones to get into the Oval on Monday, and it was a tremendous experience (Now cricket's come home, after 31 years, September 5). I only wish I could have bottled and sold the atmosphere: fervent support for the home side without (as far as I could tell) xenophobia or drunken loutishness; strangers on the tube to and from the ground talking to one another; children, who couldn't find their seats in the packed stands after a visit to the loo or to buy an ice cream, being ushered back by unknown grown ups who had noticed them on the steps.
fields.body:
I was one of the lucky ones to get into the Oval on Monday, and it was a tremendous experience (Now cricket's come home, after 31 years, September 5). I only wish I could have bottled and sold the atmosphere: fervent support for the home side without (as far as I could tell) xenophobia or drunken loutishness; strangers on the tube to and from the ground talking to one another; children, who couldn't find their seats in the packed stands after a visit to the loo or to buy an ice cream, being ushered back by unknown grown ups who had noticed them on the steps.

All right, being generous in applause to members of the side your team is beating doesn't cost, but the reception given to Ambrose and Walsh was quite something. I came up from the sticks just for the day, and will never forget it.

After all the nastiness which has emerged this summer, day five of the final Test was balm to the soul.

Jill Mortiboys
Stowmarket, Suffolk

 I cannot understand why you have not applied the Chris Woodhead A-levels theory to England's victory in the Test match.

The English side have not won a series against the West Indies for 31 years. It must follow under the Woodhead rules for education that either the players the West Indies fielded were so poor that England couldn't lose or they took pity on England and let them win. There can be no other explanation

Ray Johnston
Doncaster, South Yorks Ray@newbigg.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Lib Dems strive to fill £3bn gap

fields.headline: Lib Dems strive to fill £3bn gap
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats have been struggling to plug an embarrassing £3bn gap in their tax and spending plans ahead of today's launch of their pre-election manifesto, internal party documents leaked to the Guardian show.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats have been struggling to plug an embarrassing £3bn gap in their tax and spending plans ahead of today's launch of their pre-election manifesto, internal party documents leaked to the Guardian show.

The documents were prepared by Matthew Taylor, the party's economics spokesman, for private seminars with the party's shadow cabinet.

The spending plans overall are intended to show that the Liberal Democrats are willing to be more radical than Labour in tackling poverty, but the treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, claimed the leaked documents simply revealed "the confusion at the heart of the Liberal Democrats".

The 11 pages of detailed costings show Mr Taylor casting around for new revenue streams, including restricting the personal tax allowance to the basic rate, cutting pensions tax relief for the rich or imposing an airports landing slots tax of £1-2bn every few years. The paper also asks rhetorically whether any cash can be raised by attacking benefits fraud or tax dodges.

The tax and spend issue is highly sensitive to Liberal Democrats, since many of their marginal seats are held against Conservatives.

Liberal Democrat sources conceded that the paper had been presented to a meeting of the shadow cabinet at the end of July following the government's comprehensive spending review, but denied it damaged the credibility of the party or its costings. They insisted the gap had been identified at the shadow cabinet meeting and will be shown to have been filled when the full costings paper is published today alongside the manifesto.

Overall, the paper admits that the party's net extra annual spending plans add up to between an extra £7.165bn to £11.165bn.

The precise range, the paper states, "depends on whether we cut the 10p tax rate". The Liberal Democrats today will announce they are indeed planning to abolish the 10p tax rate, "taking 1.4m people out of tax".

But the paper then goes on to admit the party has identified new revenue streams of only £8.42bn, leaving an annual gap in tax and spending plans of £2.7bn. The paper then asks which tax proposals are acceptable to bridge the funding gap.

The main extra cash, the papers show, would be raised from 1p on the basic rate of income tax raising £3bn, a new 50p rate of income tax for those earning £100,000, raising £3.1bn, reforms to capital gains tax, raising £1.4bn, and £200m from a new tobacco tax.

The paper then shows the party plans to spend an extra £3bn on education, an extra £4bn relieving poverty mainly by top-ups on the basic pension of £5 and £10 a week, according to age. The party also plans to spend an extra £650m on other pensions reforms, £50m extra on carers, £140m on restoring benefits to 16 and 17-year-olds and £80m on increasing housing benefit to under 25s.

Health would be allocated an extra £1.2bn mainly to extra nursing staff. This would be paid by spending brought forward.

An extra £400m a year would be handed to the aid budget, all paid by reduction in military research and development spending. The police would be allocated an extra £150m, but the paper says no specific revenue stream has yet been allocated.

webTitle: Diana's ex-bodyguard working in East Timor

fields.headline: Diana's ex-bodyguard working in East Timor
fields.trailText: Trevor Rees-Jones, former bodyguard of Diana, Princess of Wales, has taken up a job with the United Nations in East Timor in an attempt to put his turbulent experiences of the past three years behind him.
fields.body:
Trevor Rees-Jones, former bodyguard of Diana, Princess of Wales, has taken up a job with the United Nations in East Timor in an attempt to put his turbulent experiences of the past three years behind him.

The sole survivor of the crash in August 1997 that killed the princess and her lover, Dodi Fayed, is being employed as a security officer. He told the Guardian he "wanted to get away from England for a while" to "have a life where people would not know me".

He was speaking on a military flight from the East Timorese capital, Dili, to his new base in the town of Suai, on the border with West Timor, where he is working as a UN civilian security officer.

He admitted he did not choose East Timor as his posting. "I just applied to the UN for a job and they decided where to send me," he said. "I just wanted to get away from England."

Life in Suai could not be further from guarding the most photographed woman in the world. But while there are no paparazzi, there are enemies of a far more violent kind. The town and its surroundings are one of the main centres of the Indonesian militia's attempt to destabilise the territory that won its independence in a referendum last August.

The only two UN peacekeepers that have been killed in action since international forces occupied East Timor last September died near Suai. And local civilians are regularly taken hostage.

"It wasn't quite what I was expecting and it will certainly be a challenge," said Mr Rees-Jones, 32.

He has certainly achieved his goal of wanting anonymity. None of the dozens of people thronging Dili's half-rebuilt airport or the handful of soldiers on the flight recognised the former paratrooper, who underwent massive facial reconstructive surgery after the crash. Only a few people in the UN headquarters in Dili are aware he is one of their colleagues.

Not wanting to talk about the past, Mr Rees-Jones's thoughts on the plane were all focused on his new job in Suai, where he is responsible for protecting the couple of dozen UN and non-governmental organisation staff.

"It isn't exactly the sort of work I've done in the past, particularly working with people from so many nationalities," he said.

While conditions in Suai are a far cry from the cappuccino and T-bone steak existence the UN employees in Dili enjoy, Mr Rees-Jones is not doing badly for himself, earning several thousand pounds a month tax free, and a daily allowance of about £60.

A spokeswoman for the UN said his job would be "basic security work". Mr Rees-Jones will not be part of the peacekeeping operation, but will offer extra protection to some of the UN's 2,000 soldiers from Australia, New Zealand, Pakistan and Fiji.

webTitle: Dump N-waste on local tips, says watchdog

fields.headline: Dump N-waste on local tips, says watchdog
fields.trailText: Nuclear waste should be dumped in domestic rubbish tips to save money so hospitals can use more radioactive sources to diagnose and treat patients, according to a government safety watchdog.
fields.body:
Nuclear waste should be dumped in domestic rubbish tips to save money so hospitals can use more radioactive sources to diagnose and treat patients, according to a government safety watchdog.

Patients may be denied treatment for such illnesses as cancer because hospitals are having to spend as much as £100,000 to dispose of a single item, the committee says.

The report by the radioactive waste management advisory committee says: "Small reductions in radiation exposure of the public are so expensive to achieve that the benefit is outweighed by the cost."

Hospitals have to dispose of swabs, vials, syringes, gloves, dressings, and overalls as well as x-ray machines and chemotherapy machines at the nation's one low level radioactive dump operated by British Nuclear Fuels at Drigg in Cumbria.

Small users, as they are known, "discharge more small short lived liquid radioative waste to the environment than the nuclear operators," according to the report.

Hospitals, universities and research labs, all of which use extensive quantities of radioactive materials have to encase their waste in concrete and transport it to Cumbria.

Once there the cost of disposal can be as little as between £200 and £2,000 a tonne depending on the content, but the expense of packaging and transport has to be borne by the waste producer.

The RWMAC report says 72 hospitals were surveyed for its report and many of them reported a backlog of items like radium needles used in past treatments kept in stores for which they had no disposal budget. To get rid of the material they would have to find funds by stopping treatment of patients.

Charles Curtis, chairman of the committee, said it was often forgotten that radioactive materials were used extensively in hospitals, universities, and such things as smoke alarms.

"The benefits to the public are immense, but the difficulties experienced by these small users, particularly dealing with radioactive wastes, should not be underestimated."

The committee, the government's official adviser on waste policy, says money should be specifically allocated to the national health service and higher education sectors to allow effective management of waste.

"Quite large numbers of [radioactive] sources, have had to be retained on premises long after their useful life has ended because of the currently high cost of ensuring their safe disposal."

The alternative is for the government to set up a suitably funded body to collect and dispose of these sources, a system that operates successfully in France.

To prevent the situation getting worse in the future, the committee recommended that the cost of the ultimate disposal of radioactive sources should be covered by the purchase price at the outset. Safe disposal in domestic rubbish tips is likely to cause local objections.

But the committee says that in properly regulated dumps the extra dose to the public would be about 1% of the average that everyone in the UK receives every day from natural background sources.

Unlike plutonium and other long lived materials from the nuclear industry, which last for thousands of years, technetium-99m, the most widely used isotope in medicine, begins to lose its radioactivity within hours.

The committee said that compulsion on private to take low-level nuclear waste might not be necessary, but the government should make sure that such facilities were available. This would represent a large national saving in waste disposal costs for the 5,600 registered small users of radioactivity, and extend the life of the Drigg respository, which is rapidly filling up.
