fields.headline: Shortage of teachers 'papered over'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Schools are papering over the cracks to cover up the full extent of teacher shortages, the biggest teachers' union claimed yesterday, amid growing evidence of the worst recruitment crisis for two decades.
fields.body:
Schools are papering over the cracks to cover up the full extent of teacher shortages, the biggest teachers' union claimed yesterday, amid growing evidence of the worst recruitment crisis for two decades.

The National Union of Teachers published research revealing the increasingly desperate measures that heads of schools in England and Wales were being forced to take to ensure that children starting the academic year this week have a teacher.

They include using unqualified and untrained teachers including technicians, appointing staff without even interviewing them, using overseas staff from Australia, New Zealand and Canada, modifying the curriculum to fit the staff available, and raising class and group sizes to unacceptable levels.

The research was carried out for the NUT by Alan Smithers and Pamela Robinson of the department of education of Liverpool University. Their researchers talked at length to 50 primary heads and 57 secondary heads, as well as 21 independent school heads, who revealed the extent of their problems anonymously.

One headteacher said: "When push comes to shove you've got to put a body in front of the class. So long as you know they are not going to kill a child or maim them, what choice do we have?" And another said: "I was in great danger of losing the teachers of the other two classes due to stress and violence, so we took this lady on after a 20-minute interview on the phone to Australia. It was an act of faith".

Professor Smithers and Dr Robinson carried out a parallel study, which was designed to explain why when there have been continuing shortfalls in recruitment to teacher training, government figures show that the schools are apparently fully staffed.

"The survey found that about 10% of all posts in the schools questioned fell vacant, and of those 4% [0.4% of all posts] remain unfilled", Prof Smithers said.

But teacher shortages were not showing up in the vacancies figures because heads were adopting increasingly desperate "coping strategies" to cover posts that became vacant.

Commenting on the survey, the NUT general secretary, Doug McAvoy, said: "For three years this government has presided over a decline in recruitment to teacher training. But it is the heads and the teachers in our schools who are bearing the brunt.

"They are papering over the cracks, and forced to take on ever-increasing burdens to ensure no child has to be sent home for lack of teachers. Quick fixes are not enough."

He added: "The answer is decent, competitive salaries, smaller class sizes and more support time during the school day."

Research also showed that shortages are hitting schools across England and Wales, not just in London.

It came after the Guardian revealed details of a study by London University's Institute of Education claiming that the growing shortage of qualified maths teachers could ultimately lead to a whole generation being innumerate.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, admitted yesterday that there were "recruitment difficulties" but said the government was taking practical steps to overcome them.

"They are papering over the cracks, and forced to take on ever-increasing burdens to ensure no child has to be sent home for lack of teachers. Quick fixes are not enough." He added: "The answer is decent, competitive salaries, smaller class sizes and more support time during the school day." Research also showed that shortages are hitting schools across England and Wales, not just in London. It came after the Guardian revealed details of a study by London University's Institute of Education claiming that the growing shortage of qualified maths teachers could ultimately lead to a whole generation being innumerate. The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, admitted yesterday that there were "recruitment difficulties" but said the government was taking practical steps to overcome them.

fields.headline: University challenge
fields.standfirst: Your starter for £39bn... Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Tory proposal for endowing the universities is more throat-clearing than elaborated policy. A capital fund producing their current annual grant income would cost (back-of-the-envelope) £39bn. No word on where this money is to be found; the yield from the telecommunications spectrum yet to be auctioned is limited.
fields.body:
The Tory proposal for endowing the universities is more throat-clearing than elaborated policy. A capital fund producing their current annual grant income would cost (back-of-the-envelope) £39bn. No word on where this money is to be found; the yield from the telecommunications spectrum yet to be auctioned is limited. Perhaps Mr Hague is working to a long timetable: it took Harvard, everyone's pet model for the free-standing university, 250 years to build up its fabulous endowment. Still, the Tories have evidently been listening to the vice-chancellors, among whom they can still count some friends. Their wheeze has the merit of responding to the elite universities' own recent bid to be "set free".

From Tory oppression, presumably. It was of course Mr Hague and pals who squeezed the universities, encouraging their expansion while restricting their public support; it was, of course, his blessed Margaret on whose watch "research assessment" was introduced, as if academic quality could be measured by counting contributions to journals. But now, with Labour pretty much continuing the same policy, Mr Hague wants to liberate the senior common rooms. Free Magdalen, and Gordon Brown would no longer have any right to criticise admissions. Free the University of Nottingham (which seems to have taken on the role St Andrews once had in pushing a right-wing policy agenda), and end external inspection of gender or ethnic balance.

So with his latest idea Mr Hague sets the universities a finals question. Are you public institutions, crown of a government-backed education system, or are you private corporations, Oxbridge colleges writ large? Because universities play such a role in transmitting (social, intellectual) capital between generations, they are too important to be prised free of accountability through state to society. Freedom for a few might work, but not for all. The great glory of oligarchic Harvard is that it accounts to no regime; the bulk of American higher education is carried on by state institutions, some of them world-class, paid for by tax dollars. In recent years UK universities have done a lot of moaning about underfunding and under-appreciation, much of it justified. Now the Tories have given them at least a theoretical alternative. It might suit Nottingham; Oxford, too. But Luton, North London and Nottingham Trent, Salford, Sunderland and Kent may take a different view. It is time to hear it.

fields.headline: Hackney schools chief quits
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Education services in the London borough of Hackney were thrown into fresh turmoil yesterday, after the director of education and two senior members of staff announced their resignation in the face of further reorganisation of one of the country's most disadvantaged inner city areas.
fields.body:
Education services in the London borough of Hackney were thrown into fresh turmoil yesterday, after the director of education and two senior members of staff announced their resignation in the face of further reorganisation of one of the country's most disadvantaged inner city areas.

Elizabeth Reid, who was director of education for two and a half years, is credited with having overseen significant improvements to the east London borough's schools and to have successfully resisted the threat of large scale privatisation. But Mrs Reid was understood to be unhappy about further changes to the council's education services proposed by the council's new managing director, Max Caller.

The deputy education director, Michael Daniels, and head of finance, Andrew Rennison, are also leaving.

In a statement released yesterday, Mr Caller, who joined the council in June from Barnet council in north London, confirmed that he had received Mrs Reid's resignation.

"I am very disappointed that Elizabeth has chosen to resign, although I understand her need for a new challenge" he said. "Our task now will be to find a successor to build on the solid foundations she has laid over the past two and a half years."

Mrs Reid was yesterday unavailable for comment. Sources claimed she had clashed with Mr Caller about his plans for a return to a more traditional structure for the council's education and other school services.

Recognising the need for more change across the board, Mr Caller and leaders of the Labour and Conservative groups on the council last month agreed that a 10-strong taskforce would be sent in to avoid government intervention.

webTitle: Moving on: Greenham women call it a day after 19 years

fields.headline: Moving on: Greenham women call it a day after 19 years
fields.trailText: There were emotional scenes at Greenham Common yesterday when women peace campers finally left the site after exactly 19 years of continuous presence.
fields.body:
There were emotional scenes at Greenham Common yesterday when women peace campers finally left the site after exactly 19 years of continuous presence.

A group of about 40 campaigners gathered to watch the last caravan leave on the back of a lorry.

There will no longer be a permanent presence at the site, but the work of the peace camp will continue - members are trying to raise £100,000 for a memorial site to commemorate their battle against the nuclear weapons based there.

Sarah Hipperson, a member of the project's commemorative fund appeal collective who has been part of the camp since 1983, said: "It has been wonderful. Our time at Greenham is an experience I'd never want to have missed. I feel very privileged. I don't think I could have spent this part of my life in a better way."

Greenham Common was requisitioned for use as an airbase in 1941 and from 1968 was occupied by the United States Air Force.

The site gained notoriety in 1980 when the Americans were allowed to store 96 cruise missiles there.

The missiles were removed in 1992 but the women stayed to ensure the land was handed back to the people.

It was subsequently passed back to the local council for £1.

webTitle: Exmoor claims Lorna's been Doone in

fields.headline: Exmoor claims Lorna's been Doone in
fields.trailText: With its romantic heather-covered moors, rolling hills and smugglers' inns, Exmoor has long been a haven for Lorna Doone devotees.
fields.body:
With its romantic heather-covered moors, rolling hills and smugglers' inns, Exmoor has long been a haven for Lorna Doone devotees.

The lush Devon landscape draws thousands of fans of the 19th century novel, keen to relive the moment Lorna is felled by a bandit's bullet at the altar.

But the popularity of the area has proved its downfall in the eyes of the BBC.

Drama executives making a Christmas special featuring Lorna's love affair with sweetheart John Ridd have spurned the novel's setting in favour of the Brecon Beacons in Wales.

They blamed the huge number of tourists on the moors, fearing the film set would be disrupted by ramblers or a speeding Mondeo.

Exmoor villagers say the tourism industry, which relies heavily on the Lorna Doone connection for income, will suffer as tourists switch to Wales.

Farmers say the decision made a mockery of government calls for them to move into more lucrative areas such as tourism and holiday lettings.

George Layton of the tourist office in Lynton, the heart of "Doone Valley", said the county was shocked by the snub, the second in five years.

"We had McDoone a few years ago when it was filmed in Scotland and now we have got Welsh Doone," he said. "People will go to Brecon after the film is shown and they will ask, 'Where are all the places in the story such as the Waterslide where Lorna and John fell in love?' It is a terrible blow for the area.

"You wouldn't film something like Titanic in the desert, so I think Lorna should have been filmed down here.

"We are right in the middle of Lorna Doone country, going to Brecon is wrong."

The National Parks and the Devon tourist board also hoped Devon would be chosen for the remake. Attractions such as Lorna Doone Farm offer tea rooms and a souvenir shop, and the local riding school runs treks along "Doone Valley".

Natalie Jeune, 22, whose family owns the 14th century Rising Sun Hotel at Lynmouth, where RD Blackmore reputedly stayed and wrote some chapters of Lorna Doone, which is set in the 17th century during the Monmouth rebellion, added: "Farmers are really suffering round here and many have gone into tourism as an alternative source of income. I think the decision is a real kick in the teeth for local people. The BBC should reconsider."

But a BBC spokeswoman said it stood by the decision to film in Wales.

"There were simply too many tourists on Exmoor. We think this would have caused problems with filming.

"It was a long process and in the end we settled for the Beacons."

fields.headline: Jill Selbourne
fields.trailText: Jill Selbourne, who has died aged 54 after a spirited resistance to cancer, was a Labour councillor in Conservative Westminster and one of the leaders of the campaign against gerrymandering there.
fields.body:
Jill Selbourne, who has died aged 54 after a spirited resistance to cancer, was a Labour councillor in Conservative Westminster and one of the leaders of the campaign against gerrymandering there. A radical campaigner among London's poor and underprivileged over several decades, she had represented the impoverished Harrow Road ward since 1986.

Selbourne was an inspirational woman of great charm and humour and a tenacious and imaginative political fighter along the difficult urban frontiers of race and class. She had a capacity for creating friendships and getting people together socially as well as politically.

Like so many people in the Labour Party, she could be categorised neither as "Old Labour" nor as "New Labour": she perceived herself simply as a socialist, an anti-racist, an internationalist and someone who thought for herself. Her politics was rooted in community activism, working with black and refugee groups in the north of the borough, and helping to galvanise local communities.

Further afield, a visit to the Caribbean island of Dominica, where many of north Paddington's inhabitants come from, left her with a permanent enthusiasm for its way of life. She would often return there, and helped to set up the Frontline Cooperative Bookshop in Roseau, the capital, in 1982, the island's first - and still surviving - independent bookshop.

Selbourne was born in Devon but her family later farmed along the Ridgeway on the Wiltshire Downs, where she spent much of her childhood and frequently returned to recharge her batteries in later life. She was educated in Norfolk and in Somerset, and joined the sixth form of Marlborough grammar school before graduating with a first in anthropology from Sussex University.

Travelling in India inspired an interest in the sub-continent's religions, a commitment to the politics of the wider world and a zeal to effect change, both in Britain and abroad. On her return, she completed her formal education by studying for an MA at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London, and then in 1969 began working with the Community Development Project in Southwark.

Moving to north Paddington in 1973, she worked as a community development officer with Voluntary Action Westminster, finding in community regeneration and the empowerment of deprived and dispossessed people her own reason for existence. She relished the area's multi-racial, multi-cultural life, and for many years at the Notting Hill carnival would appear in carnival costume during the day and then dance furiously behind the floats until closing time.

For many years her spare time was spent working with YaaAsantewa, the black arts centre off the Harrow Road named after the great Ashanti queen. Started in 1973, and originally known as the Factory, it occupied former industrial premises which Jill campaigned to acquire for use as a community centre. She was its indefatigable supporter through several crises.

As a councillor in 1986 and chairwoman of the Labour group on the Westminster council housing committee, she was the prime mover, successfully opposing plans to sell off the council's housing estates. Helping to channel the creative energies of the people involved, she was instrumental in starting the resident-controlled Walterton and Elgin Community Homes housing association, which assumed responsibility for some of the old estates.

More recently, as developers made plans for the gigantic site once occupied by Paddington station's goods yards, Selbourne took a lead in organising the local community to demand a say in what would happen there. The result was the creation of the Paddington Development Trust, which involves schools and colleges, health trusts and residents' associations and secured a £13m government grant, the largest new funding ever brought into one of central London's most deprived areas.

Late in 1998, at the height of her powers and with many ambitions still unfulfilled, Selbourne was diagnosed with malignant melanoma, and she resisted it with characteristic determination. Eventually, when it became clear that this was one battle she would not win, she accepted her fate without fear and drew great strength from her many friends and family, and from her own deep spiritual reserves.

She leaves two daughters, Jane and Sally, and two granddaughters, and her long-time partner, Neale Coleman, whom she married two weeks before her death.

Jill Selbourne, political campaigner, born February 25 1946; died August 31 2000

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: On Hague's pre-election manifesto

fields.headline: Tory faithful do not want to eat apple pie at any cost
fields.standfirst:
Hague's pre-manifesto is vapid nonsense from Republican America

Special report: Tories in opposition
William Hague's Believing in Britain
fields.trailText: Hague's pre-manifesto is vapid nonsense from Republican America.
fields.body:
"Faith in politics and politicians is at all time low," declared yesterday's Conservative pre-manifesto, while duly adding extra good cause for popular politico-phobia.

How most people's hearts must sink as we enter a party conference season that will slide straight into a long election campaign, dragging on until the day is done. (If only the prime minister would call it for October, how much pain and suffering he would save us all.)

The politicians don't get it. They don't realise how their stunted lexicon of empty phrases no longer conveys anything more than its own aridity. William Hague's speech yesterday launching his piffling potpourri of policies was typical of the species - but Labour politicians can and do seize every chance to talk much the same vapid nonsense from any podium to any captive audience.

Maybe they all have some special key on their computers that spews it out, like Hague yesterday: "We want a Britain where communities thrive and public services serve... We are not just interested in a healthy and strong economy but also in a healthy and strong society too... We will ensure that Britain is one of the most admired and influential countries in the world... We want a Britain the people of Britain are themselves crying out for... an ambitious, self-confident, prosperous, decent..." Blah, blah, blah. All anyone wants is for politicians to stop talking at them like idiots.

When people say to despairing canvassers that they don't vote because "they're all the same", they are partly right. Most politicians do talk the same brand of high-flown tosh. The very few who don't are loved, regardless of politics - the rare Mo Mowlam or Ken Clarke. Minds numbed by such dross turn instead to the more serious questions of whether or not they prefer the way Tony Blair says "Y'know" or Hague's shiny pink baldness.

As a result only the trained ear (one paid not to fall asleep) deconstructs the crucial policy differences hidden within these forests of verbiage. It's only the misleading blather that makes them sound the same, for at this election the great left-right divide will be as deep and wide as the Atlantic ocean.

Believing in Britain is a flimsy thing printed on flimsy paper, an interim stop-gap while the Conservatives struggle behind the scenes to work out their true tax-and-spend policies. With no costings it's all fantasy policy-making. So we get odd things thrown in - a minimum speed limit on motorways (no, that's not a misprint); "Get rid of the worst towerblocks and large estates" (just like that); give religious broadcasters national licenses (hello, Pat Robertson); a full day's work for every prisoner in self-financing prison workshops, (every prison governor's dream, but forget "self-financing"); and privatise universities so they can all be like the Ivy League. All this smacks of desperation from worried young policy-wonks told to come up with something, anything new and eye-catching - never mind if it works, is being done anyway or will cost a fortune once costed.

At the heart of its most important policies lies one consistent strand - America and George W Bush. They've all been over there for fact-finding summer holidays, including Two Brains David Willetts, and they've come home star-struck by Republican ideas, policies and even the language. Tax cuts lie at the heart of the strategy - though Hague's £16bn cut looks a little weak beside George W Bush's stonking great $1.3 trillion. (No, it may not be £16bn when they've done their sums, Portillo says, though that is what they'd have to cut by 2003 to meet their pledge of cutting taxes while not spending above a 1.3% lower estimate of trend growth.)

Britain Works, copying America Works, will replace the New Deal with a "can work must work" guarantee. As in the US, the unemployed will be handed over to private companies to find them jobs, making profits out of any social security saving. Conservatives say it will save 25% by cutting out expensive training, illiteracy and drug treatment programmes that currently succeed in getting many of the unemployable back on their feet. A new plan to force lone parents to work is purely American: promised savings of £3bn on social security include an extraordinary projection that every single lone mother on income support will get a job in year one. And, of course, US-style private health "will be encouraged to grow".

A new privatised pensions policy is also borrowed from the George W Bush campaign. It's a good example of how far the Conservatives' ideology has blown a hole in their costings. They will let young people opt out of the state pension. Instead of paying into national insurance each week, they can pay into a private pension fund of their own. But there is no notional sum each person pays towards his or her own old age pension. All the money paid in now goes to pay today's pensioners. If large numbers stop paying in, a huge hole opens up in national insurance.

So what will they cut to fill that gap? Willetts pretends that by fiddling public accounting systems he can claim to be saving a future government in 40 years time. But that just won't wash: from the look in his eye, he knows it too.

How will all this sound to the voters? Odd, alien and very American. Tory voters, especially older ones, are not particularly enamoured of American rightwing ideology. Margaret Thatcher and her advisers flirted with the US right, but she was canny enough to know it wouldn't play back here. Her brand of rightwingery was very English, but Hague doesn't have Thatcher's ear for the timbre of English conservatism. Anything that smacks of privatising universities, health and pensions will do him no good. It may excite his coterie but it will alarm his own blue-rinses almost as much as those crucial Middle Englanders.

Why the infatuation with America? Because it isn't Europe. Here lies the one coherent and resonant thread that runs right through this document, its only true theme: no to Europe, now and for ever. So Hague will take "reserved powers" to stop further EU intrusion, push for an alliance with Nafta and support the US national missile defence system, trying to tilt us westwards.

In 10 years, he thundered yesterday, "our country that so many of our countrymen lived for and sweated for and died for, could have disappeared". On one side the Atlantic is "freedom" (as in freedom to dine at Marco Pierre White's), while on the other is the hidebound socialist old Europe of welfare states. The Conservatives will ensure that the ideology of Europe versus America runs right down the electoral fault line, reaching into every crevice of social policy. Despite the odd maverick in each party, left versus right and Europe versus America is what this election will be all about.

Minds numbed by such dross turn instead to the more serious questions of whether or not they prefer the way Tony Blair says "Y'know" or Hague's shiny pink baldness. As a result only the trained ear (one paid not to fall asleep) deconstructs the crucial policy differences hidden within these forests of verbiage. It's only the misleading blather that makes them sound the same, for at this election the great left-right divide will be as deep and wide as the Atlantic ocean. Believing in Britain is a flimsy thing printed on flimsy paper, an interim stop-gap while the Conservatives struggle behind the scenes to work out their true tax-and-spend policies. With no costings it's all fantasy policy-making. So we get odd things thrown in - a minimum speed limit on motorways (no, that's not a misprint); "Get rid of the worst towerblocks and large estates" (just like that); give religious broadcasters national licenses (hello, Pat Robertson); a full day's work for every prisoner in self-financing prison workshops, (every prison governor's dream, but forget "self-financing"); and privatise universities so they can all be like the Ivy League. All this smacks of desperation from worried young policy-wonks told to come up with something, anything new and eye-catching - never mind if it works, is being done anyway or will cost a fortune once costed. At the heart of its most important policies lies one consistent strand - America and George W Bush. They've all been over there for fact-finding summer holidays, including Two Brains David Willetts, and they've come home star-struck by Republican ideas, policies and even the language. Tax cuts lie at the heart of the strategy - though Hague's £16bn cut looks a little weak beside George W Bush's stonking great $1.3 trillion. (No, it may not be £16bn when they've done their sums, Portillo says, though that is what they'd have to cut by 2003 to meet their pledge of cutting taxes while not spending above a 1.3% lower estimate of trend growth.) Britain Works, copying America Works, will replace the New Deal with a "can work must work" guarantee. As in the US, the unemployed will be handed over to private companies to find them jobs, making profits out of any social security saving. Conservatives say it will save 25% by cutting out expensive training, illiteracy and drug treatment programmes that currently succeed in getting many of the unemployable back on their feet. A new plan to force lone parents to work is purely American: promised savings of £3bn on social security include an extraordinary projection that every single lone mother on income support will get a job in year one. And, of course, US-style private health "will be encouraged to grow". A new privatised pensions policy is also borrowed from the George W Bush campaign. It's a good example of how far the Conservatives' ideology has blown a hole in their costings. They will let young people opt out of the state pension. Instead of paying into national insurance each week, they can pay into a private pension fund of their own. But there is no notional sum each person pays towards his or her own old age pension. All the money paid in now goes to pay today's pensioners. If large numbers stop paying in, a huge hole opens up in national insurance. So what will they cut to fill that gap? Willetts pretends that by fiddling public accounting systems he can claim to be saving a future government in 40 years time. But that just won't wash: from the look in his eye, he knows it too. How will all this sound to the voters? Odd, alien and very American. Tory voters, especially older ones, are not particularly enamoured of American rightwing ideology. Margaret Thatcher and her advisers flirted with the US right, but she was canny enough to know it wouldn't play back here. Her brand of rightwingery was very English, but Hague doesn't have Thatcher's ear for the timbre of English conservatism. Anything that smacks of privatising universities, health and pensions will do him no good. It may excite his coterie but it will alarm his own blue-rinses almost as much as those crucial Middle Englanders. Why the infatuation with America? Because it isn't Europe. Here lies the one coherent and resonant thread that runs right through this document, its only true theme: no to Europe, now and for ever. So Hague will take "reserved powers" to stop further EU intrusion, push for an alliance with Nafta and support the US national missile defence system, trying to tilt us westwards. In 10 years, he thundered yesterday, "our country that so many of our countrymen lived for and sweated for and died for, could have disappeared". On one side the Atlantic is "freedom" (as in freedom to dine at Marco Pierre White's), while on the other is the hidebound socialist old Europe of welfare states. The Conservatives will ensure that the ideology of Europe versus America runs right down the electoral fault line, reaching into every crevice of social policy. Despite the odd maverick in each party, left versus right and Europe versus America is what this election will be all about. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

webTitle: Eight police face disciplinary action over football match beatings

fields.headline: Eight police face disciplinary action over football match beatings
fields.trailText: Eight police officers are to face disciplinary charges after a Merseyside riot squad beat soccer fans with batons following a football game between Liverpool and Manchester United.
fields.body:
Eight police officers are to face disciplinary charges after a Merseyside riot squad beat soccer fans with batons following a football game between Liverpool and Manchester United.

The police complaints authority announced yesterday that the officers, including two inspectors and a sergeant, would face internal censure after more than 70 complaints were filed by members of the public. The allegations against the force included serious criminal assaults, incivility, unlawful arrest and neglect. But no Merseyside officers will face criminal charges after the crown prosecution service ruled there was insufficient evidence.

Eleven charges of assault were upheld by the PCA but the officers involved could not be identified because their badge numbers were not visible, and some were wearing black balaclava "flash hoods". The eight officers who will be disciplined were not directly linked to assaults.

Merseyside police has already paid out thousands of pounds to fans in out of court settlements.

Yesterday Rex Makin, a Liverpool solicitor representing 17 fans, denounced the decision not to bring criminal prosecutions as a cover-up.

The charges relate to a disturbance in Liverpool city centre on September 11, after Liverpool were beaten 3-2 by Manchester United. Fans spilled into the city centre after the match, which had kicked off early to avoid trouble. Trouble flared in the Slater Street area around 5pm when Merseyside police's operational support group, in full riot gear, was sent in to clear the streets and several pubs

Angered by the arrival of the riot squad, some fans began to throw bottles and glasses. Police then drew batons and charged the crowd. The worst violence is said to have occurred when 20 officers attempted to clear a pub.

Recommending disciplinary charges, the PCA said: "It is evident that both offenders and innocent customers have been subjected to assaults by police officers."

Yesterday Merseyside police announced operational changes for policing flashpoint incidents.

fields.headline: Sami al Minais
fields.standfirst: Kuwaiti politician and human rights advocate
fields.trailText: The radical journalist and politician Sami al Minais, who has died of a stroke aged 68, was one of Kuwait's most articulate modernisers.
fields.body:
The radical journalist and politician Sami al Minais, who has died of a stroke aged 68, was one of Kuwait's most articulate modernisers.

After studying pharmacy at Cairo university, he became in 1961 editor-in-chief of the newspaper AgGamaheer (the Masses) and from 1965 to 1985 edited At Talieaa (the Vanguard) magazine. In 1965, he was a founding member of the Arab Journalists Union, later its deputy chairman and, from 1996, head of its human rights committee.

He was elected six times between 1963 and 1999 to Kuwait's exclusively male Majlis Al Umma, the only elected parliament in the Gulf states. Political parties are not allowed in Kuwait, but after the country's liberation in 1991 Al Minais and many radical intellectuals formed the Democratic Forum. This resulted from the October 1990 people's conference held, in exile, in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.

Al Minais had raised the stakes at that gathering by insisting that liberation should go hand in hand with reform. This included a restoration, with amendments, of the 1962 constitution which the emir had suspended in 1986 - when he had also dissolved parliament - a clampdown on rampant corruption and full suffrage for women, most of whom stayed in the country and resisted the Iraqi occupation heroically, while the ruling establishment fled.

The emir and the crown prince promised to carry out the reforms; which were also in line with hints from the western allies. Post-liberation, in 1991, elections were duly held; but on May 4 1999 the emir again dissolved parliament and, in an act of political shrewdness, set a date for elections and signed a decree on May 16 1999 granting women full suffrage as part of a reform package. The "Islamists" and traditional tribal MPs joined forces to defeat the emir's suffrage decree on November 30 1999 by the narrowest of margins - 32 to 30 votes.

When he died, Al Minais was locked in a bitter confrontation with the "Islamist-tribal alliance" which wants to impose segregation of the sexes on the university - where a woman is vice chancellor. His life and trials were not merely Kuwaiti. The issues he raised touched raw political nerves all over the Gulf states - especially in the Wahhabi-dominated kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Sami al Minais's death leaves a void; but the causes he championed will dominate the national agenda for years to come. In 1984 he became one of a handful of Arab journalists honoured by the International Union of Journalists for his contribution to press freedom.

The title of his only book, The Battle For Democracy, sums up his life. He is survived by his Egyptian wife and four sons.

Sami al Minais, journalist and politician, born February 5 1932; died August 23 2000

webTitle: 'Jerusalem should be a unified world capital'

fields.headline: 'Jerusalem should be a unified world capital'
fields.standfirst:
Top Palestinian calls for special status if no deal is struck

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: On the eve of a last attempt by President Clinton to untangle the most vexing problem in the Middle East - the status of Jerusalem - one of Yasser Arafat's most trusted lieutenants said yesterday the Palestinians would be willing to make bold compromises on their claims to the holy city.
fields.body:
On the eve of a last attempt by President Clinton to untangle the most vexing problem in the Middle East - the status of Jerusalem - one of Yasser Arafat's most trusted lieutenants said yesterday the Palestinians would be willing to make bold compromises on their claims to the holy city.

In a speech to the European parliament in Strasbourg, Ahmed Qureia said the Palestinians would support internationalising all of Jerusalem - including Arab East Jerusalem, occupied illegally by Israel since 1967 - should the two sides fail to reach a final settlement in the crucial weeks ahead.

"Unless we can reach an agreement on Jerusalem, I have to declare that both parts of Jerusalem east and west should be a unified international Jerusalem ... not just the capital of Israel or Palestine, but a capital of the world," said Mr Qureia, who is speaker of the Palestinian parliament.

The proposal revives a formula put forward by the UN in 1947 and since repeatedly rejected by Israel, and opposed by the Palestinians, though it still remains part of European foreign policy.

President Clinton is to begin talks today with Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and Mr Arafat, meeting each separately on the sidelines of the millennium summit in New York.

The meetings at the Waldorf Astoria have caused some to hope that during the hubbub of the three-day summit of 150 world leaders, Mr Clinton will somehow produce the miracle that eluded him in two weeks of concentrated negotiations at Camp David last July.

Mr Clinton has likened the experience of those talks to having teeth extracted without painkillers, and strongly criticised Mr Arafat for his unwillingness to match Israeli compromises on Jerusalem.

Some Palestinians hope that yesterday's proposal from such a senior figure as Mr Qureia, popularly known as Abu Ala and seen as a possible successor to the ailing Mr Arafat - could relieve some of the pressure on the Palestinian leader during his New York talks.

"He said it to try to throw forward an idea that would be acceptable among Europeans and internationally," said Nabil Khatib, director of the media centre of Bir Zeit University in the West Bank town of Ramallah.

"The Palestinians have a feeling that Israel is trying to give the impression that they [the Israelis] are the only ones who are making concessions. Abu Ala is trying to show that the Palestinian people are also ready for concessions, but not one-sided, and not concessions to Israel. The concession is to have a new kind of solution."

Accepting current Israeli proposals on Jerusalem, which would restrict Palestinian sovereignty to a few outer neighbourhoods of the city, would be impossible for Mr Arafat to justify to his people.

"Mr Barak wants everyone to comply with his version of how things should be: occupiers' law," said Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the Palestinian legislative council. "But the issue is not just the holy sites, the issue is Jerusalem as a city." Real solutions were needed, not just symbolic ones.

Mr Clinton is to use the meetings with Mr Arafat and Mr Barak to see whether to hold a second summit, possibly in October. But American officials say they first need to see signs of further progress since July's Camp David talks. "Unless there is forward progress, unless we see a decisive way forward from this week ... this [reaching a deal] gets more and more difficult," the US national security adviser, Sandy Berger told reporters.

So far signs of progress do not appear forthcoming. Israeli and Palestinian officials have tried to dampen expectations of a breakthrough before September 13, the latest deadline for a final settlement.

Israeli officials say it is up to Mr Arafat to react to proposals since Camp David which blur the issue of sovereignty over the holy places in the old walled city of Jerusalem. "Arafat's moment of truth has come and the Palestinian leader must make political decisions rather than turn the negotiations into a bickering match," the Israeli foreign ministry said on Monday.

Instead, they are trying to press Mr Arafat to accept a dispensation for Jerusalem, offered since Camp David, that would dodge the question of ownership over the sanctified ground in the old walled city by declaring God the sovereign of holy places.

The US version of these proposals would have Israel controlling the Wailing Wall, the holiest shrine of Judaism, and the Palestinians in control of the Haram al-Sharif, the third holiest site in Islam, with God the sovereign of the passage between them.

Mr Arafat has come under mounting pressure from the US and Israel to accept the proposals, which are endorsed by Egypt and Jordan. After the last Camp David talks ended without agreement, Mr Arafat went to more than two dozen countries looking for support but found himself being urged to hold off on declaring a Palestinian state on September 13. On that, Mr Arafat appears to have yielded, and a meeting of Palestinian legislators in Gaza at the weekend is likely to support postponing such a declaration until later in the year. "September 13 is not a sacred date," said Faruq Qaddumi, a senior Palestinian official.

But time is working against a settlement. The US presidential election campaign is expected to occupy much of Mr Clinton's energy from now until the vote in November, and Mr Barak is barely hanging on to power. Stripped of a parliamentary majority, his government is surviving thanks to the summer recess in the Israeli knesset.

If Mr Barak fails to reach a deal with Mr Arafat, he may resort to a new coalition with the rightwing Likud party, which opposes the compromises he offered at Camp David. Yesterday Mr Barak was hedging his bets, telephoning the Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, from New York even as he awaited today's meeting with Mr Clinton.

webTitle: Rebecca Smithers on the school 'fresh start' scheme

fields.headline: School's out
fields.standfirst:
Closing failing schools and reopening them with new staff and a different name has not proved the bright idea it seemed to be in 1997, reports Rebecca Smithers.
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Closing failing schools and reopening them with new staff and a different name has not proved the bright idea it seemed to be in 1997, reports Rebecca Smithers.
fields.body:
Among the thousands of pupils returning to their classrooms today, the 400-odd teenagers attending Firfield community school face a grim future. Their Newcastle-upon-Tyne secondary school is under a death sentence. After being given a second chance as the first secondary school to reopen under the government's flagship "fresh start" scheme, it will close for good by September 2002.

The mixed comprehensive, known in its previous incarnation as Blakelaw, was one of 11 secondary schools to have been closed and reopened under the scheme with a new name, new staff, a lick of paint and the chance of a bright new future.

At the time, Blakelaw had one of the worst examination performance rates in the country, with high pupil truancy levels and demoralised staff. Now it is to be closed, then, along with another local comprehensive, reopened next September as yet another school, in a ground-breaking partnership with Newcastle University.

Confirmation of the closure - supposedly still subject to "consultation" - came with the latest GCSE results showing a disappointing lack of improvement across the board. The chart shows some of the other fresh start schools, the data collected by the Times Education Supplement. The Department for Education and Employment's official line has been that exam results alone are a poor indicator of improvement. Three of the schools have been placed on special measures, indicating that the office for standards in education believes they are failing.

Firfield hit the headlines in the glory days of the new Labour administration as the first to be rescued under the fresh start, announced by the incoming government as a drastic measure for turning around failing schools in inner-city areas. But the failure of the new-look school - the result of plummeting numbers of pupils on its roll and financial problems - highlights the problems of the fresh start scheme itself.

Experts, teachers and parents have rightly been asking whether it is simply a gimmick or a last-ditch opportunity for a genuinely new beginning. Like so many of Labour's grand new initiatives, fresh start seemed like a good idea at the time, and a way of giving youngsters a new start with the backing of new government cash.

But teachers' unions have denounced it as an ill-thought-out, cheap-and-nasty option, a quick-fix solution that puts the spotlight on head teachers, who are then under pressure to achieve a quick turnaround in the full glare of publicity. They say that Labour ministers, who unashamedly took credit for the scheme in its early days, subsequently distanced themselves when it started to run into problems.

In Islington, north London, David Blunkett personally attended the opening of the former George Orwell school, renamed Islington Arts and Media, with its new head teacher Torsten Friedag in the glare of the cameras. Less than a year later, Mr Friedag announced that he was packing it in. Last week he broke his silence to blame a lack of support from governors and the local education authority as the reason for his decision.

Like playing cards in a pack, the heads of three other fresh start schools also resigned. The irony was that all four had been paid huge salaries - at least £70,000 a year - to turn around the schools, as the first of the "superheads" (another New Labour initiative). At the same time, even the local education authorities, which have largely run the schemes, felt they had been left to pick up the pieces after the first difficulties surfaced. Not surprisingly, the remaining heads went to ground and refused to discuss the problems in public.

Since then Mr Blunkett has himself acknowledged the difficulties, admitting that more of the schools might fail. During a recent visit to Fir Vale in Sheffield - the only one of the schools to have achieved a significant rise in pupils gaining five or more good GCSEs - he signalled a dramatic new approach, which will involve his department making the scheme more structured. New funding of £60m was announced for the fresh start schools and the new city academies in this year's budget, for example.

Mr Blunkett has been keen to ensure that some of the money gets directly to head teachers. The amount will vary, depending on the size and type of the school, and will be linked to performance targets. He is restructuring the scheme as four more primary and five more secondary schools join this month, bringing the total up to 25. There is a recognition that there needs to be a differentiation between schools genuinely going into fresh start with DfEE backing and those that have simply adopted a new look.

It is clear from the exercise that fresh start is not an overnight solution, and its ultimate success will be determined by the attitude of the head teachers in charge. One head of a fresh start school that achieved broadly the same GCSE results as it did last year said he was not going to give up. He said the scheme would work but local communities and parents needed to see signs that things were going to change.

"You can't just tell people that things are going to be different. They want to see some sort of force to bring about that change. We are turning the corner but it will take time. Parents were thanking me for not resigning, but I have no intention of doing that."

Rebecca Smithers is the Guardian's education correspondent rebecca.smithers@theguardian.com

Not surprisingly, the remaining heads went to ground and refused to discuss the problems in public. Since then Mr Blunkett has himself acknowledged the difficulties, admitting that more of the schools might fail. During a recent visit to Fir Vale in Sheffield - the only one of the schools to have achieved a significant rise in pupils gaining five or more good GCSEs - he signalled a dramatic new approach, which will involve his department making the scheme more structured. New funding of £60m was announced for the fresh start schools and the new city academies in this year's budget, for example. Mr Blunkett has been keen to ensure that some of the money gets directly to head teachers. The amount will vary, depending on the size and type of the school, and will be linked to performance targets. He is restructuring the scheme as four more primary and five more secondary schools join this month, bringing the total up to 25. There is a recognition that there needs to be a differentiation between schools genuinely going into fresh start with DfEE backing and those that have simply adopted a new look. It is clear from the exercise that fresh start is not an overnight solution, and its ultimate success will be determined by the attitude of the head teachers in charge. One head of a fresh start school that achieved broadly the same GCSE results as it did last year said he was not going to give up. He said the scheme would work but local communities and parents needed to see signs that things were going to change. "You can't just tell people that things are going to be different. They want to see some sort of force to bring about that change. We are turning the corner but it will take time. Parents were thanking me for not resigning, but I have no intention of doing that." webTitle: Abortion issue stirs up Mexican emotions

fields.headline: Abortion issue stirs up Mexican emotions
fields.standfirst: As fundamentalists push for tougher laws, one of the country's greatest taboos is being openly debated
fields.trailText: For months Angelica Ramirez hoped against hope that the changes in her body were caused by the shock of the rape. Eventually, when she could fool herself no more, alone and frightened, she tried to induce an abortion.
fields.body:
For months Angelica Ramirez hoped against hope that the changes in her body were caused by the shock of the rape. Eventually, when she could fool herself no more, alone and frightened, she tried to induce an abortion.

"I thought if I don't eat, it will die. I thought if I do the exercises and take pills and special herbs I will abort the baby, but nothing worked. Nothing happened."

Desperate, she approached a doctor, who agreed to do the operation. But she could not afford his fee; so, with her mother's help, she left her small-town home to have the baby in a city orphanage, so that her father would not find out.

"I know it's not the child's fault, but every night I ask the baby why it had to be born, why I had to have it. That's why I want to give it up for adoption. That's why I don't want the baby ever to know that I am its mother," she said, a shy teenager shaking in a failed attempt to control her tears.

The taboo that led her to pretend her pregnancy was not happening has deterred politicians on all sides from touching the abortion issue.

Women's groups estimate that 850,000 Mexican women abort every year, and about 1,000 are thought to die from botched jobs. These statistics do not even recognise cases such as Angelica's.

But in the past few months Mexico has been taken by storm by a national debate on unwanted pregnancies and abortion which, although begun by the religious right - newly emboldened by its links to the president elect Vincente Fox's National Action party (Pan) - has given the pro-choice camp a public platform it was previously denied.

"We have the opportunity to do something different," said Ricardo Sheffield, one of the Pan deputies who passed an amendment to the penal code in the state of Guanajuato designed to make abortion, even in cases of rape, punishable with prison.

"The damage of rape can be repaired, but killing by abortion - there is no resolving that."

Rosario Taracena, an activist for reproductive rights, said the extreme right posed a very real threat, but the feminist movement had long been pushing for the chance to talk openly about abortion and the restrictive laws and cultural taboos which ensured that the most abortions were performed in secret.

The Guanajuato bill caused a furore, not only because rape is one of the very few conditions under which abortion is legal in all Mexican states but also because it brought to the surface the deep contradiction between Mexico's Catholic sensibilities and its strong anti-clerical tradition, which abhors mixing religion and politics.

It also came soon after the case of Paulina, a 13-year-old rape victim whose attempt to get a legal abortion was blocked by politicians, lawyers and doctors in the northern state of Baja California ,where the Pan is also very strong. The case was given extensive and sympathetic treatment by Mexico's main television network, Televisa.

It also deeply embarrassed Mr Fox. A previous governor of the particularly religious state, he had worked hard to distance himself from Pan's rightwing image. But his victory breathed new life into the fundamentalists in the party.

The new aggressiveness of the pro-lifers prompted left-leaning parties to pass liberalising amendments to the abortion laws of Mexico City and the state of Morelos. Although hardly radical, they indicated a readiness to pick up the gauntlet thrown down by the extreme right in Pan.

Under pressure to calm the situation, the governor of Guanajuato, a close associate of Mr Fox, vetoed the reform at the end of last month. But the state's deputies have vowed to raise the issue again at a later date.

"The debate has only just begun," s Mr Sheffield said. "Mr Fox says this will go no further, but he is not a congressman. We have been raised as opposition, and it is in our blood."

"It was to be expected that the religious right would do something like this," said Edgar Gonzalez, a researcher, who stressed that the Pan, founded in 1939, had its roots in the Cristera war 10 years earlier between a reactionary church and the new revolutionary anti-clerical state.

Pan has broadened its appeal over theyears, but Mr Gonzalez said the fundamentalists had remained, awaiting the right opportunity to push their agenda.

"There is nothing to indicate that they are going to give up so easily now,"he said

There is also nothing to suggest that those who want women to be free to chose abortion will simply accept a quiet return to the status quo.

"What we want is for the debate to continue until we get a national referendum," said Veronica Cruz, a leading Guanajuato feminist, encouraged but not satisfied by the veto of the rape reform bill.

Meanwhile nobody doubts that whatever the law says, women will seek out ways to abort. For those with money and contacts it can be as simple as a visit to a discrete doctor, but for many it is a matter of noxious concoctions and sharp objects.

And it is business as usual in Mexico City's Sonora market.

"How many weeks?" a vendor asked to gauge the required dose of a herbal remedy he promised would start the bleeding within five hours.

"I only sell to women who are up to three months late, after that it gets dangerous, but for enough money you can always get someone to help you out."

fields.headline: Milburn steps into resuscitation row
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday stepped into the controversy over the resuscitation of frail and elderly patients by ordering hospital trusts to produce a document stating their policy, which must be available to families and patients.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday stepped into the controversy over the resuscitation of frail and elderly patients by ordering hospital trusts to produce a document stating their policy, which must be available to families and patients.

There was outrage in April when Age Concern revealed that doctors sometimes mark very elderly, terminally ill patients' notes DNR (do not resuscitate) without consulting the patient or relatives. In the event of a heart attack, no attempt is made to keep the patient alive, on the basis that prolonging treatment will only lead to further suffering.

The charity said it had since been inundated with calls from distressed families who had discovered that doctors unilaterally decided their relatives were beyond help. It was putting together a dossier of more than 100 cases, which would go to the government.

Age Concern welcomed Mr Milburn's move but said it was vital to reach individual hospital doctors, who sometimes took these life and death decisions in the mistaken belief that the patient and family would not want to know.

"Despite this announcement, the evidence of ageism in the NHS goes further than this," said Gordan Lishman, the charity's director general. "The NHS is too often guilty of undervaluing older patients. Our fear is that only when this culture is fully challenged will scandals such as DNR become a thing of the past."

Mr Milburn said he wanted every trust to state its policy on DNR orders, to safeguard the rights of patients and stamp out ageism. "Decisions on non-resuscitation should only be made following a discussion with the patients and their relatives."

Policies will have to be based on guidance set out by the British Medical Association, the Royal College of Nursing and the Resuscitation Council, which have established four circumstances in which a DNR order is acceptable: if resuscitation is unlikely to succeed; if a mentally competent patient has consistently stated or recorded that he or she does not want to be resuscitated; if there is advance notice or a "living will" which says the patient does not want to be resuscitated; or if resuscitation would not be in the patient's best interest because it would lead to a poor quality of life.

The NHS inspectorate - the commission for health improvement - has also been asked to look at hospital resuscitation policies. Mr Lishman said patients, carers and relatives would be reassured by the auditing and monitoring of the policies.

webTitle: Chiefs call for more police in uniform

fields.headline: Chiefs call for more police in uniform
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Home Office is being urged to set "visibility" targets which will compel police forces to put more officers in uniform, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The Home Office is being urged to set "visibility" targets which will compel police forces to put more officers in uniform, it emerged yesterday.

The idea is part of a package of controversial measures recommended by the Police Superintendents' Association in a report which challenges many practices currently regarded as sacrosanct.

It says forces in England and Wales should resist "double crewing" and send out officers on patrol on their own.

Other recommendations include cutting the number of unmarked patrol cars and encouraging officers to eat in cafes instead of staff canteens.

This is common practice in the US but has been frowned on by officers in Britain.

The report, which is due to be sent to the home secretary, Jack Straw, next week, said many plain clothes officers should return to uniform.

"The public would see an enormous increase in the number of officers immediately, and the service would benefit as a result.

"We have reached the situation where an innocent member of the public could be standing next to a police officer without realising it, yet a criminal who invariably knows the identity of the unmarked car and its driver, would realise who the plain clothes officer was."

The Superintendents' Association believes police must tackle a perception within the ranks that being a beat officer in uniform is "the lowest of the low".

"A visible presence on the streets provides deterrence and reassurance, key factors in the concept of policing by consent," the report continued.

"Those elements should not be sacrificed in the race to top the leagues of measurable indicators."

The case for double crewing has been championed by officers on patrol, who argue they feel safer working in pairs.

However, studies have shown officers are less likely to be assaulted if they patrol on their own.

The report, entitled What the Public See is What They Think They Get, quotes from a thesis written by a Thames Valley officer which found double crewed cars "present the biggest risk factor as far as assaults are concerned".

The association's president, Peter Gammon, said: "We want to challenge and generate debate about the way officers work.

"The double crewing of police vehicles has become the norm and we are saying that there should be operational reasons for that, rather than just being routine practice."

He added: "There's a lot more police officers out there than people think. Some 17% are in plain clothes and if we reduce that by just 5% you would have another 6,000 extra officers in uniform. This is all about being accessible to the public."

The reluctance of officers to eat in public had to be challenged, he said.

"They do it on the continent and in America so why not here? Would people really feel threatened if they saw an officer eating in McDonald's?"

Mr Gammon said the association consulted various organisations, including the Home Office, the Association of Chief Police Officers, and the inspectorate of constabulary.

"We want forces to read the report and get ideas for the future," a spokeswoman for the association said. "We believe the Home Office should make visibility a performance indicator, telling forces they have to improve by X amount every year."

The Police Federation, which represents rank and file officers, said it supported the general thrust of the report.

It said many forces were already using single crew patrols, but warned this was only safe in certain situations.

The report will be published at the association's annual conference next week.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Libya accuses CIA of murder
fields.body:
Libya accuses CIA of murder

Libya accused the CIA and the Israeli security service Mossad yesterday of assassinating its ambassador to the Central African Republic last Tuesday. Awad Sanussi was shot by an unidentified man at his home in the capital.

"Mossad and CIA agents are responsible for masterminding and executing that criminal and cowardly act," the African unity ministry said. It would "spare no effort to follow through the investigation into the crime to uncover the perpetrators, who will be punished".
Reuters, Tunis

Airbus crash 'human error '

Evidence from the investigation of the Gulf Air Airbus crash a fortnight ago points to human error as the cause, a Bahraini aviation official said.

"It doesn't look like anything else but human error. The pilot came in too high and too fast. He got it wrong. "

The official added that he did not expect a definitive statement on the cause of the accident to be released before the end of the year.
AFX, Manama

Thousands flee Congo fighting

More than 20,000 people have sought refuge in Congo-Brazzaville to escape renewed fighting in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a UNHCR official said yesterday.

The Congo government declared an end to its offensive against rebels of the Movement for the Liberation of Congo last month.

Nevertheless, in the past two weeks there have been increasing reports of renewed fighting.
Reuters, Kinshasa

webTitle: Piece by piece, pillaged art is sent home to Nepal

fields.headline: Piece by piece, pillaged art is sent home to Nepal
fields.standfirst: Stolen from the Katmandu valley, a 13th-century carving held by a Berlin museum adds to a handful of returned works
fields.trailText: The Berlin Museum of Indian Art has returned an 800-year-old carving to Nepal after concluding that it had been stolen from the Katmandu valley. It is the latest of a handful of works returned to Nepal in the past year by conscience-stricken holders.
fields.body:
The Berlin Museum of Indian Art has returned an 800-year-old carving to Nepal after concluding that it had been stolen from the Katmandu valley. It is the latest of a handful of works returned to Nepal in the past year by conscience-stricken holders.

The stone relief shows the Hindu god Shiva and his wife Parvati, surrounded by their family and other deities in their abode on Mount Kailash. This Uma Maheshwor theme has been popular with the valley's carvers for more than a thousand years

The carving was smuggled out of the country after being stolen in 1982 from the tiny village of Wotol, near Dhulikhel, about 15 miles from Katmandu on the rim of the valley. When it was put up for sale in Germany in 1985, the Museum of Indian Art bought it.

A proposal to give the work to the Patan Museum in Katmandu was made to the Nepalese government earlier this year. Accompanying the work back to Nepal, the director of the Berlin museum, Mariane Yaldiz, was greeted with applause by the reception committee in the square beside the Patan Museum.

"Once we knew the image was stolen," she told them, "we did not hesitate in deciding to return the relief to Nepal. We will miss this beautiful couple from our museum, but it was the only correct decision."

Seated in front of her was the man who made the homecoming possible.Lain Singh Bangdel,an eminent Nepali artist and art historian, published a book in 1989 called The Stolen Images of Nepal, giving photographic evidence of carvings work stolen from the valley from the 1960s to the 1980s.

This has already led to the restitution of four other stone carvings. They were handed to the National Museum by a private American collector who did not want to be named.

The scale of art theft from the Katmandu valley since the area was opened to the outside world in the 1950s has been huge, according to opponents of the trade. Jürgen Schick, a German researcher whose book The Gods are Leaving the Country, was published at the same time as Professor Bangdel's, estimates that 50% to 60% of the valley's works of art have been stolen and that what is left is of a lesser order.

Images used to be placed outside temples, on street corners or even in the middle of fields - all easy to steal from. Once stolen, they were taken across Nepal's almost open border with India and shipped to the west, where their craftsmanship brought high prices from museums and private collectors.

The director of Patan Museum, Jal Krishna Shrestha, says the museum has about 300 pieces - 20% of its collection - which were stolen but recovered by the police or customs officers before they left the country.

Protecting the country's works of art continues to be a preoccupation, though the scale of theft has declined in the past 10 years, so the returned Uma Maheshwor is not going back to the people of Dhulikhel, where it was venerated daily for 800 years. It may be returned to them one day, but only if its safety can be guaranteed.

Mr Shrestha hopes more works will be returned to Nepal. Campaigners say, for example, that an 11th-century Uma Maheshwor at the Musée National des Arts Asiatiques-Guimet in Paris vanished from the city of Bhaktapur in 1984.

fields.headline: Guatemalan rights worker attacked
fields.trailText: A human rights worker investigating massacres by the Guatemalan army during the country's civil war has been kidnapped, drugged, beaten and interrogated about his inquiries.
fields.body:
A human rights worker investigating massacres by the Guatemalan army during the country's civil war has been kidnapped, drugged, beaten and interrogated about his inquiries.

The attack coincided with attempts to prosecute former presidents and military leaders responsible for the mass killing of villagers suspected by the army of helping guerrillas during the 36-year war, which had claimed up to 200,000 lives when it ended in 1996.

Celso Balan, 38, who works for the Centre for Legal Action on Human Rights (CALDH) in Guatemala, was seized at the beginning of August. He made a confidential complaint to the United Nations mission, Minigua, shortly after the attack.

Mr Balan, who has worked for CALDH for four years, was walking towards the local court-house when two men pulled up in a pick-up and called him by name, a CALDH spokesman said. They said that they were journalists, showed him press cards, and offered him a lift. Once in the truck he was forced to the floor at gunpoint and driven off.

The two men questioned him about the exhumation of a mass grave where an army massacre occurred in the village of Chipastor in 1982.

He was then forced to take his attackers to the CALDH office, where he was hit over the head with the butt of a gun while the two men ransacked the room for information.

Before being dumped in the local cemetery, Mr Balan was forced to drink a liquid containing a strong sedative, which, doctors say, could have produced paralysis or even death in a slightly stronger dose.

Mr Balan has promised to continue his work.

CALDH is the leading organisation behind an attempt to prosecute the former president Romeo Lucas Garcia and others for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

In a separate action, the Nobel peace laureate Rigoberta Menchu is attempting to have the former president Efrain Rios Montt prosecuted in Spain.

webTitle: Race-hate rock CDs seized in east Germany

fields.headline: Race-hate rock CDs seized in east Germany
fields.standfirst: Police impound neo-Nazi music after killing shocks country
fields.trailText: The German police said yesterday that they had seized 7,500 CDs in their first strike against one of the most visible - and audible - manifestations of eastern Germany's neo-Nazi youth culture: race-hate rock.
fields.body:
The German police said yesterday that they had seized 7,500 CDs in their first strike against one of the most visible - and audible - manifestations of eastern Germany's neo-Nazi youth culture: race-hate rock.

Some of the discs impounded during raids in the hours before dawn had cover photographs of Adolf Hitler. Others had pictures of hanged Turks.

On one a group sang about killing blacks. "You've got 30 seconds to run for your life, nigger," the lyric ran. Then, after the sound of a machine gun, the group continued: "Oh. That feels good. That feels good - to kill a nigger."

Last week a court in the eastern city of Halle convicted three young neo-Nazis of beating and kicking a Mozambique-born immigrant so savagely in June that he died of his injuries.

Alberto Adriano was the latest victim of the kind of far-right barbarity which Germany's centre-left government has said it is determined to stamp out. But the scale of the task it has set itself was underlined by some of the details released yesterday by the police.

They said they had disrupted the activities of two distributors of far-right rock music in the state of Saxony-Anhalt, but that between 50 to 70 others were still operating in other parts of Germany. There is also a flourishing cross-border trade in neo-Nazi CDs put on sale in Poland.

The government's main initiative so far has been to announce that it will be applying for a ban on the most radical of Germany's legal rightwing groups, the National Democratic Party of Germany (NPD). It has also promoted a campaign urging ordinary people to stand up to the extreme right.

Experts in the field, including sociologists, voluntary workers and officials of Germany's internal intelligence service, have all argued that the true problem is a rejectionist skinhead culture, which is particularly prevalent in the formerly communist east.

The sort of music sought in the raids reported yesterday is an important underpinning of that culture, and Saxony-Anhalt is the part of the east where the culture seems to be most embedded.

It has the highest rate of violent and far-right crime, and the capital, Magdeburg, is one of the few cities in Germany where extreme rightwingers have seats in the council chamber.

The raids occurred last week, but the police said they had held back details until yesterday because the investigation was continuing. They said they had swooped on 11 locations in the early hours of August 30.

The confiscated items included computers with mailing lists of customers, videos and posters showing swastikas, and neo-Nazi paraphernalia. They said the material clearly violated German laws prohibiting the incitement of racial hatred and the use of emblems linked with anti-constitutional movements. But only one arrest was made. The suspect was later released on bail of 25,000 marks (£8,400).

The army, which has been struggling to stamp out racism in its ranks, said earlier that it was investigating a non-commissioned officer suspected of making racist remarks. The tabloid daily Bild had reported that a staff sergeant was accused of sending messages to the cellphone of a recruit of Turkish origin.

One read: "When Ali is swinging from the oak tree, when Mehmet staggers through the gas chamber, when the swastika is once again used to tar our streets, that's when Germany will be worth living in again."

webTitle: Sonata for front parlour:  International piano competition

fields.headline: Sonata for front parlour:  International piano competition
fields.trailText: More than 70 pianists from all over the world today begin the final stages of the Leeds international piano competition, which has launched some of classical music's finest soloists on successful careers.
fields.body:
More than 70 pianists from all over the world today begin the final stages of the Leeds international piano competition, which has launched some of classical music's finest soloists on successful careers.

This year's contest, the 13th, has already proved unlucky for some. Six pianists arrived minus their luggage; one could not leave Russia because she had to take her son to hospital; another shut her finger in a car door.

Those not affected by disaster were yesterday practising on some of the 104 pianos in the homes of contest supporters. Some are specially supplied Steinways. But Oliver Kern, 30, who studies in Salzburg, rehearsed Haydn's last sonata on a century-old Broadwood grand. "This piano is warm," he said. "It was made with love."

The Broadwood and the practice space were provided by Valerie Richmond, a piano teacher, and her husband James. Up to 15 other competitors will follow Mr Kern into the Richmonds' front room and organisers have devised a military-style transport schedule to ensure they arrive on time, in the right place. "We love piano music and this is a fantastic opportunity to hear musicianship of this quality," said Mrs Richmond.

She remembers the "magical" playing of Alexander Madzar, who came third in the last contest, as he rehearsed the 12 Debussy etudes. Then there was Piotr Anderszewski, a 21-year-old Pole who suddenly left the platform during a semi-final and failed to return.

Last year Mr Kern was runner-up in a competition in Beijing. He is hoping this time to scoop the Leeds top prize. If he gets to the concerto final he will play Brahms's first concerto with the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra; if he wins, it is a £12,000 cheque and a presence on a roll of honour that includes Rafael Orozco, Murray Perahia, John Lill, and Jon Kimura Parker.

This year Cristiano Burato returns. In 1996 he slipped and dislocated his shoulder minutes before he was due to appear before the adjudicators for the first time. He went home to Italy without having played a single competitive note.
