webTitle: Clinton backs reform of UN peacekeeping role

fields.headline: Clinton backs reform of UN peacekeeping role
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton will give his backing today to a proposal to reform the UN's peacekeeping activities after their disastrous failures in Rwanda, Srebrenica and Sierra Leone.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton will give his backing today to a proposal to reform the UN's peacekeeping activities after their disastrous failures in Rwanda, Srebrenica and Sierra Leone.

In the opening speech of the three-day UN millennium summit he will tell the leaders of more than 150 countries that the US endorses the establishment of a permanent peacekeeping high command to replace the present slow, ad hoc arrangement.

But wrangling over who will meet the peacekeeping bill continued behind the scenes. The changes will run into millions of pounds and the US is desperately trying to reduce its share of peacekeeping costs.

The US endorsement virtually guarantees acceptance of the peacekeeping reforms, published last month, drawn up by a UN panel headed by Lakhdar Brahimi, a former Algerian foreign minister.

In Srebrenica, the UN was humiliated when its peacekeepers stood by while more than 7,000 men and boys were massacred by Serbs. A more catastrophic failure occurred in Rwanda, where up to a million were massacred.

In Sierra Leone this year, 500 UN peacekeepers were taken hostage by a rebel force.

As well as a permanent high command, the reform includes giving peacekeepers clearer-cut mandates and "robust" rules of engagement. Such changes might have helped in the Balkans, where UN peacekeepers found themselves unable to intervene because they did not have a mandate.

But the UN reforms are in danger of being overshadowed by a series of meetings Mr Clinton is holding on the sidelines to try to revive the Middle East peace talks. Today he will have separate meetings with the Palestinian authority president, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak.

Sporadic demonstrations were held on the eve of the summit. Four Iranians were arrested for throwing yellow paint and another for disorderly conduct outside the hotel of the Iranian president, Mohammad Khatami.

The city has given permits for 91 demonstrations during the summit, but there has been no sign of a repeat of the protests by anti-globalisation activists which caused mayhem in Seattle last year and in Washington earlier this year.

Many of the leaders of the trade unions and environmental groups involved in those clashes have laid down their banners and teargas masks for the weekand are talking to representatives of big business and government at an alternative conference being staged in the city.

More than 1,000 representatives from round the world gathered at the New York Hilton, about a mile from the UN headquarters, yesterday for the opening of the State of the World Forum.

It is a diverse gathering, bringing together politicians, academics, soldiers, New Age spiritualists, representatives of multinational companies, as well as the trade union leaders and the environmental lobby.

Jim Garrison, its organiser, said the Seattle protests had been beneficial in bursting the euphoria about globalisation.

Mr Garrison, 49, an American academic and veteran campaigner against the nuclear arms race, said the forum was about channelling the protests which had been useful in focusing attention on the problems of globalisation.

He added: "We have to move from protest to engagement."

The opening day of the forum brought together figures such as John Sweeney, president of the AFL-CIO trade union organisation, George Soros, the financier, and Mikhail Gorbachev, the former Soviet president.

Helen Clark, the New Zealand prime minister, who will speak at the UN millennium summit, made the trip across Manhattan to address the alternative forum.

Other leaders scheduled to attend include Thabo Mbeki, the president of South Africa, and Olusegun Obsanjo, the Nigerian president.

Mr Garrison said globalisation was ruthless, and questions such as the unequal distribution of wealth and the impact on the environment had to be discussed. He added that talks did not mean that future protests were ruled out.

 North Korea announced yesterday that it had pulled out of the UN summit after a confrontation between its delegation and US security officials while they were passing though Frankfurt airport.

The deputy foreign minister, Choe Su-hon, said the delegation decided to return home after "rude and provocative" treatment by US security staff, whom he accused of strip-searching members of the presidential entourage.

www.worldforum.org

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Good, The Bad And The Ugly | Ulee's Gold | The Last Picture Show
fields.body:
The Good, The Bad And The Ugly
(Sergio Leone, 1966)
11.40pm, FilmFour

Leone had more money to play with after the success of the two Dollars movies, so this third adventure of Clint Eastwood's Man with no Name is on a much larger scale: it takes in a full-scale civil war battle. The picaresque plot has Clint, the Good, vying with the Bad killer (Lee Van Cleef) and the Ugly bandit (Eli Wallach), for treasure buried in a cemetery: the three-way showdown is an epic. Tonino Delli Conte's photography is superb; he went on to shoot Leone's masterpiece, Once Upon a Time in the West.

Ulee's Gold
(Victor Nunez, 1998)
12.25am, Sky Premier

Peter Fonda's Ulee, a middle-aged Vietnam veteran, is quietly making honey and caring for his granddaughters in rural tranquillity . But shattering the peace comes a call for help from his convict son (Tom Wood), who is suddenly involving Dad with hidden loot and cheap crooks. A low-key, emotionally resonant gem of a movie about family ties, ephemeral riches and the real treasure of the honey, with Fonda making the most of his best role since Easy Rider.

The Last Picture Show
(Peter Bogdanovich, 1986)
3.15am, Carlton Cinema

In a little 50s Texas backwater it's all Desolation Row, a dusty limbo for the teenagers who congregate at the local cinema ' which is closing down. Among the apathetic youngsters Ben Johnson has his finest hour as picture-house owner Sam the Lion; he and Cloris Leachman won Oscars, and Larry McMurtry deserved one for his adaptation of his own novel, a restrained but moving study in smalltown nostalgia.

webTitle: Rangoon tells London to mind its own business

fields.headline: Rangoon tells London to mind its own business
fields.standfirst: No freedom in sight for anti-junta leader padlocked inside her house
fields.trailText: Burma's representative in Britain has told the Foreign Office that western envoys may be allowed access within a fortnight to the democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been padlocked inside her house.
fields.body:
Burma's representative in Britain has told the Foreign Office that western envoys may be allowed access within a fortnight to the democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been padlocked inside her house.

But his emollient words in London were counter-balanced in Rangoon by junta tongue-lashings of Britain and the British ambassador in the Burmese capital.

The Foreign Office minister John Battle said in London that he had summoned the Burmese ambassador, Kyaw Min, to protest at the military regime's crackdown on Ms Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD).

He said the ambassador had admitted that there was "a crisis" in Rangoon, and then conceded that diplomatic access to Ms Suu Kyi might be granted "within the next two weeks".

Amnesty International has expressed grave concern for the safety of Ms Suu Kyi and seven of her colleagues who are being held under house arrest. She has not been seen since September 2, when Burmese security forces ended her 10-day attempt to travel outside Rangoon, breaking up her roadside camp in the dead of night.

Ms Suu Kyi is believed to be in her house in Rangoon but - with phone lines cut and the main gate padlocked - that has not been confirmed. Food is being handed in over the garden railings.

A junta statement said that "certain quarters of the NLD have been conspiring with some armed outlawed youth organisations [and] an armed terrorist group, God's Army. The group has its base on the Thai border.

The statement said that while senior NLD members were not under arrest, they had been "requested to stay at their respective residences and to cooperate with the government during the course of investigation".

Human rights groups say that allegations of terrorist links have been made in the past to justify the mass arrest of NLD supporters.

The US charge d'affaires in Rangoon, Priscilla Clapp, called the allegations a "malicious fabrication".

The head of military intelligence, General Khin Nyunt, restated the regime's assertive nationalistic line in a speech shortly before Ms Suu Kyi was forced to return home after trying to travel in her homeland.

Foreign countries, he said, were "using every pretext from forced labour and narcotic drugs, to [complaints about] health and education conditions to interfere in internal affairs". He also accused "two big western countries" of trying to "destroy" Burma's international relations.

Britain and the US are the two culprits in the regime's eyes, a message reinforced yesterday when the junta accused London's ambassador to Rangoon, John Jenkins, of overstepping "universal diplomatic norms" by trying to reach the house of the NLD's deputy chairman, Tin U, on Monday.

Tin U was forcibly removed with Ms Suu Kyi from the encampment and has been confined to his home since then. A government statement said that Mr Jenkins had tried to "force his way" into Tin U's house before being blocked by a plainclothes security officer.

"It is difficult to understand why a foreign ambassador was so adamant to intrude into the internal affairs of an independent and sovereign nation," the aggrieved statement said.

The restrictions placed on the NLD were no concern of the outside world, it said. "The people who are involved are purely Myanmar [Burma] citizens and not British."

British and US diplomats were not invited to a meeting on Monday when the Burmese deputy foreign minister, Khin Maung Win, met other envoys to give the junta's version of its crackdown on Ms Suu Kyi's party. He accused young NLD activists of conspiring with terrorists to smuggle five remote-controlled bombs into the capital.

fields.headline: £1.2bn plan 'unlikely to speed up traffic'
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Journey times on England's main roads are unlikely to improve over the next 10 years -despite the £1.2bn plan to curb congestion announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Journey times on England's main roads are unlikely to improve over the next 10 years -despite the £1.2bn plan to curb congestion announced yesterday.

The best motorists can hope for is that travel times on England's motorways and trunk roads will be no longer than they are today, Richard Eastman, the highways agency's new technology project director for roads, admitted. "I don't think journeys will be faster over the next 10 years."

The admission came as the agency announced measures to improve traffic management and provide better information for drivers as part of the government's £180bn, 10-year transport strategy.

New technology will also be introduced in an attempt to reduce congestion - although the agency admitted it lacked the staff to implement the hi- tech plans. But they would be found, it promised.

The agency hopes congestion will be reduced by 5% over 10 years - in contrast to the estimated rise of 28% - but journeys are not expected to take any less time because of increasing volume of traffic.

Among the plans announced were the installation of traffic automatic hold-up warning systems on 30% of all motorways by 2004 to reduce pile-ups; and 200 extra motorway monitoring cameras to help emergency services respond more quickly. Variable message signs on national roads will be tripled to 1,500 by 2003, to suggest alternative routes and avoid delays.

A national control centre will give more reliable journey times - and offer alternative route advice; and the M25 controlled motorway project will be extended, with controlled motorways on routes around Manchester and Birmingham.

fields.headline: Night of the hunters
fields.trailText: Manhunt - Evil Calling | One Day In September | Brookside
fields.body:
From the makers of The Search For The Yorkshire Ripper came Manhunt - Evil Calling (ITV), about Michael Sams, the man who killed Julie Dart and abducted Stephanie Slater nine years ago. Along with the usual mix of middle-aged policemen talking and black-and-white reconstructions of key moments, Manhunt - Evil Calling used real footage of Sams being interviewed and the tapes made of phone calls he made to the police. While the tones of Janet Suzman were suitably gravitas-laden when describing the discovery of Dart's body, it was the sound of Sams' own voice that was the most chilling. The reason was simple: he didn't sound like "evil calling" at all. Actually, he sounded more like an irate Alan Bennett, perhaps after an argument with Mrs Gupta at the newsagent's ("I told her I wasn't paying for last week's Radio Times because it was delivered in a condition verging on the papier-mché. That caused quite a commotion amongst the Pan Drops."). He used words like "monies" and "small penalties" in his threatening letters, writing out in full the amount of money he was demanding. Excellent grammar doesn't an angel make, and Sams was a reminder of the banality of evil.

Ransom notes pass through the Sooty-coloured gloves of unsuspecting post-office workers, milk floats amble absent-mindedly past the house of an abducted woman's family, communications with murderers are placed in the small ads above an advertisement for oatcakes: the details of the case were so frighteningly ordinary, evidence that badness doesn't come signposted, booming voice and hooded claw. Were Alan Bennett ever to write a police procedural thriller, this would be it. It would be called Blood On The Anaglypta.

One Day In September (BBC2) will probably be remembered as the film which beat Buena Vista Social Club to the Oscar for best documentary at this year's Academy Awards, earning its place as a pub-quiz answer for robbing Wim Wenders of a prize it was assumed he deserved. This would be unfortunate, since One Day In September deserves its place in posterity for being an intelligent, exquisitely made, moving and dramatic documentary. Charting the events of the 5th of September at the Munich Olympic Games which led to the deaths of 11 Israeli athletes at the hands of Palestinian terrorists, it was genuinely epic in its sweep and so emotionally powerful, it had you desperately willing a happy ending to the film in the face of the bloody documented history.

It began with the fond reminiscences of one woman, Ankie Spitzer, whose husband was one of the Israelis who was first held hostage and eventually killed. She was articulate and poetic as only the bereaved are, and, as she talked, footage from her wedding home-movie warmed the screen. From this already auspicious start, the film got more involving, wrapping up the personal with the political, and widening its horizons to encompass every aspect of the 1972 tragedy. From its use of sunny tourist-board films full of beer froth and busty blondes designed to emphasise the wholesome, diverse (and non-Nazi) nature of Munich, to the insensitivity of Olympic officials and the fact that it was a tragedy played out live on television, making it a spectator sport, One Day In September was a carefully carved sculpture, every shot and every beat of the exceptional soundtrack making the story all the more compelling. The result was a slowly building tension worthy of the best drama.

Down Brookside (C4), a sinister-looking dolly has appeared in the Corkhill's lounge. With its staring glassy eyes and peculiar dress sense, it could easily be mistaken for Lindsey - she does have a touch of the wind-up doll about her - but rather it's one of those porcelain mannequins that are forever being possessed by malevolent spirits and terrorising their owners (mainly in horror films, it has to be said). So not that different from Lindsey at all.

A vicious ghostly presence would certainly explain Jimmy's run of bad luck (that, and his various addictions) and his coming-along-nicely obsession with cleaning. Before you know it, he'll be up to his elbows in Mr Muscle, going bananas with a Swiffer. Indeed, were Kylie to stand still long enough, he'd give her a good going-over with a chamois leather. And rumours like that are what got Sinbad in all his trouble.

webTitle: Tv and radio: What lorry drivers are watching on TV

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What lorry drivers are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What lorry drivers are watching on TV
fields.body:
Henry Pope:
"I only watch TV when I need to relax after a long drive. It sends me to sleep. I just turn it on and within a minute I'm out. What do I like? Well it's a long time since I kept my eyes open! I like The Bill, that sort of thing. Morse? Nah, not that. Used to watch Cracker, but that was years ago. Do I watch the porn? I should think not, hehehehe! Thing I'd most like to turn off? Would have to be... [thinks] wildlife programmes. I don't like them."

Shawn Louther:
"Sports - football, the cricket now it's on, snooker, racing. I like sport. I don't see a lot, I get to hear it on the radio though. Very good. Radio Five, saves my life. Love it. I think the last time I watched any other TV was when Diana died. Everyone's forgotten about her, haven't they? It's all Posh Spice and Anthea Turner now. I get my telly from reading the paper. I know all about Anthea but I couldn't tell you what programme she's on. Could you? No? Hahahaha! You're meant to be a professional."

James Neightley:
"What was that you wanted, love? Telly?? Don't see it. Last thing I watched was the Coronation. No, all right, probably Christmas. Who's that bloke who wears that yellow suit and sounds black? Ali G! Yeah, all the family sat round the telly to watch his Christmas message. I thought he was very funny, actually, I had a laugh. I must say I'd been at the cooking sherry, but he's very good. Friend of Madonna's? Lovely. "

Isaac Ford:
"I like the racing and sports. I usually listen to the radio when I'm driving. I like Radio Two and Magic FM in London. If I get tired I listen to one of the dance stations to wake me up. Have I ever fallen asleep at the wheel? No, not really. If I start to go, I pull over at the services. I have heard of people doing that, yes, but not me. Favourite TV personality that would keep me awake at the wheel? Catherine Zeta-Jones , the Darling Buds Of May. I think she should come back to Britain to raise her child."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to lorry drivers at services on the M6.

webTitle: 'Secret' history of EC talks to be published to counter Eurosceptics

fields.headline: 'Secret' history of EC talks to be published to counter Eurosceptics
fields.trailText: The classified history of Britain's negotiations to join the European Community, which has been locked away for almost 30 years, is being published by the government tomorrow with the message that membership was a good deal in 1973 and is a good deal now.
fields.body:
The classified history of Britain's negotiations to join the European Community, which has been locked away for almost 30 years, is being published by the government tomorrow with the message that membership was a good deal in 1973 and is a good deal now.

Britain's Entry into the European Community was written in 1972 by Con O'Neill, chief negotiator for two years of intensive talks with the then six founding members of the EC.

Originally sent only to named and numbered recipients in Whitehall, the 464-page in-house history is being released before the usual 30-year period to meet pledges on more open government.

Foreign Office officials admit they hope to send a positive signal to the most Eurosceptic public in the 15-member union that this is still a club worth belonging to. It contains little in the way of dark secrets, but there are some undiplomatic indiscretions and intriguing insights into the political and economic problems of membership, including a tough negotiating stance by the French, who had previously opposed British entry on the grounds that they would be "a Trojan horse for the US".

"The French take an unusual satisfaction in the conduct of negotiations for its own sake," Sir Con wrote. "They like the tensions it can engender and the careful orchestration of innumerable themes. For the French, negotiation is an art form or even a sport."

Holland, a founder member of the EC in 1957, expressed concern that British entry would mean an influx of Pakistanis and other "coloured Commonwealth citizens" invading the Netherlands in search of jobs. New Zealand, as a member of the Commonwealth, had Britain "over a barrel" on the vexed question of lamb.

Fisheries issues, an area where Sir Con admits making a major mistake - were a matter of "economic peanuts, but political dynamite".

Some of Sir Con's history has already surfaced in This Blessed Plot, Guardian columnist Hugo Young's book on Britain's ever ambivalent relationship with Europe. But it will now be available in full to general readers and scholars.

Sir Con's insider's text is replete with references to the lost opportunities of the 1950s and the advantages of joining a new entity at the beginning - an observation many feel is relevant to the continuing debate about the single currency.

"What mattered was to get into the community and thereby restore our position at the centre of European affairs which, since 1958, we had lost," he wrote. "The negotiations were concerned only with the means of achieving this objective at an acceptable price."

He added: "None of its policies was essential to us; many of them were objectionable. We had to get terms which could be publicly shown to be reasonable, advantageous, and not too onerous."

In another passage with a contemporary echo, he wrote: "One of the main problems with public opinion in this country during the negotiations was to convince sceptics that matters not finally settled in black and white during the negotiations but left over for future settlement by the institutions of the enlarged community would in fact, when it came to the point, be capable of being settled satisfactorily.

"This was partly of course because opponents of entry seized on every deferred issue to prophesy eventual disaster."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Ocean Planet | On The Job
fields.body:
In 1991 the Peruvian health minister tried to counter public alarm about a cholera epidemic by eating a local raw fish delicacy on television. It probably ranks as the most expensive snack in history. The minister's resulting cholera wiped out $270 millions' worth of shrimp exports and $750 millions of that year's tourist revenue. It is now evident, as Professor Jacquie McGlade explains in The Ocean Planet (9.0pm, Radio 4), that the effects of global warming are drastically widening the seaborne spread of cholera.

In On The Job (11.0pm, Radio 4)author James MacLoughlin fires some well-aimed shafts at the Home Office, town-hall jacks- in-office, political correctness, and almost every analogous target. The Chief Constable of North Rawtonshire (Tony Haygarth) is about to be ousted by his new political boss (Caroline Pickles) after 42 years' service. However, he still has a card or two up his sleeve. Also starring Jeff Rawle and David Yip.

webTitle: Arts:  Lyn Gardner on the remarkable comeback of The Soho Theatre

fields.headline: Miracle on Dean Street
fields.standfirst: The Soho Theatre gave us some of the great names of British drama. But a few years ago it looked doomed.  Lyn Gardner on a remarkable comeback
fields.trailText: The Soho Theatre gave us some of the great names of British drama. But a few years ago it looked doomed. Lyn Gardner on a remarkable comeback
fields.body:
When Abigail Morris was named artistic director of the Soho Theatre in 1992, some of her friends advised her against taking the job. The Soho, originally called the Soho Poly and founded as a lunchtime theatre by Verity Bargate and Frederick Proudin 1968, was one of London's first fringe venues and gave many famous writers their big break, from Barrie Keefe to Sue Townsend. But by the early 90s the company appeared to be in freefall. If Morris took the job, she might see her fledgling career go down with it.

Now Morris sits in the meeting room at the top of a new £10.5m theatre in Dean Street in the heart of Soho, having guided the company through its first season in its purpose-built home. At least 80% of seats have been sold for each production; a remarkable 73% of audience members were under the age of 35; the final play, Stop Kiss, had its run extended by two weeks; and Amanda Whittington's Be My Baby, about life in a home for unmarried mothers in the 1960s, is heading for the West End.

This is not the first time Morris has pulled a rabbit out of the hat. In 1993, against the advice of those who predicted a marketing disaster, she followed her instincts and programmed Diane Samuels's Jewish refugee drama Kindertransport, which became a hit both in the West End and on Broadway. The same year, when she accepted a production of Jonathan Lewis's soldier drama Our Boys, theatres that had rejected it phoned her up to inform her that she was mad. Our Boys later transferred to the Donmar Warehouse. Even the decision to open the Dean Street theatre not with fanfares but with a low-key season of new work has paid off.

But perhaps her greatest coup was persuading her bosses that a company with barely two pennies to rub together should buy its own building. In just eight years the Soho has gone from bust to boom, and Morris, whose only previous experience was running the feminist theatre company Trouble and Strife in the late 1980s, has become a major player in Britain's new-play culture. Any list of those most likely to shape Britain's theatre in the 21st century would be incomplete without Morris and the Soho's administrative director, Mark Godfrey. Some predict that this is a partnership to match that of Richard Eyre and David Aukin, who worked together in regional theatre before running the National. By coincidence, Aukin chairs the Soho's board.

"I had nothing to lose," Morris says of her decision to take the job at the Soho. Yet within weeks of arriving she found herself having to persuade the Arts Council not to withdraw its funding. Two years later the end once again appeared imminent when the company faced eviction from the Cockpit Theatre, an unlovely venue in north London where it had moved after being pushed out of the centre of the city in 1990.

But Morris, small and wiry, is as tenacious as a terrier. She suggested to the board that the company find and convert its own building in central London. Someone spluttered that they'd probably need £100,000 - way beyond the ambitions and pocket of a small company like Soho. If the board members had known that the final cost would be 100 times as much, they would probably all have had heart attacks.

But the timing could not have been better. Capital grants were just becoming available via the Lottery, and the Soho seized on the old synagogue in Dean Street, snatching it from the clutches of a company that wanted to turn it into a lap-dancing club. Then, when property prices in the capital went through the roof, the Soho did a deal with a developer that gave it a 200-seat theatre and writers' centre in return for the right to build flats above the venue. A restaurant covers the theatre's running costs, putting the company in the rare position of spending its subsidy on producing work rather than keeping the toilets clean.

At £253,000, the Soho's grant is less than Hampstead Theatre's or the Bush's, and insufficient for a theatre with such an ambitious new writers' programme. But the company's first season in its new home has already had a major impact on the delicate ecology of new writing, and Morris's distinctive taste has provided a refreshing counter to the brutalism of so much new work.

"In the end choosing a play is very much like choosing a friend. You have a hunch," says Morris, whose "hunches" last season included eight plays, all box-office hits, of which six were written by women. There was no specific plan in this, but Morris may once again be ahead of the crowd. In the mid-90s she was one of the first programmers to realise that the modern theatre-goer has a preference for 90-minute mini-dramas rather than four-hour epics. (She claims only to have been reflecting her own short attention span.)

Taken as a group, the astonishing thing about the plays in the first Soho season is that they pulled in audiences simply by focusing on the pain and pleasures of ordinary people leading ordinary lives. Morris is not afraid of the kind of violence that has become fashionable in the theatre (Alex Jones's Noise, staged when the Soho was camping out in the Dean Street synagogue before building was completed, was as uncomfortable and brutal as theatre gets) but the plays she chooses are less about shocking and more about telling stories. Even Noise sprang from that most common of situations - neighbours arguing about noise levels.

Morris is reluctant to talk about either motherhood (she has two girls under five, making her that rarest of creatures, a female artistic director with small children) or religion (she is a practising Jew and won't work late on Fridays). But both seem to influence her choice of plays and her desire to tell stories. "Telling stories is such a good way of drawing people in. It engages people on a deep level. It creates a dialogue and enables people," says Morris, who cites the story of her friend's parents, Polish Jews, who were hidden throughout the war by a woman who was anti-Semitic. "I am interested in those kinds of stories, and theatre is a really good way of exploring the contradictions in people - their very many facets. People are complicated. It is not as simple as saying that Iago is more interesting than Othello."

Certainly it is not the case in Morris's latest production, Navy Pier, a play about writing, ambition and creative and intellectual ownership, which opens the Soho's second season this week. Like almost all of the Soho's plays, this is theatre that approaches its subject slightly off centre but with a nose for accessibility. The chances are that it will be yet another hit. But Morris is taking no bets. "In the theatre you can't ever second-guess, and in a way that is great. It means that however successful you become, you should never lose the freedom to go out on a limb, to say, 'That's the play that speaks to me, and that's the one I'm going to put on.' "

 Navy Pier is at the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), from Thursday.

In just eight years the Soho has gone from bust to boom, and Morris, whose only previous experience was running the feminist theatre company Trouble and Strife in the late 1980s, has become a major player in Britain's new-play culture. Any list of those most likely to shape Britain's theatre in the 21st century would be incomplete without Morris and the Soho's administrative director, Mark Godfrey. Some predict that this is a partnership to match that of Richard Eyre and David Aukin, who worked together in regional theatre before running the National. By coincidence, Aukin chairs the Soho's board. "I had nothing to lose," Morris says of her decision to take the job at the Soho. Yet within weeks of arriving she found herself having to persuade the Arts Council not to withdraw its funding. Two years later the end once again appeared imminent when the company faced eviction from the Cockpit Theatre, an unlovely venue in north London where it had moved after being pushed out of the centre of the city in 1990. But Morris, small and wiry, is as tenacious as a terrier. She suggested to the board that the company find and convert its own building in central London. Someone spluttered that they'd probably need £100,000 - way beyond the ambitions and pocket of a small company like Soho. If the board members had known that the final cost would be 100 times as much, they would probably all have had heart attacks. But the timing could not have been better. Capital grants were just becoming available via the Lottery, and the Soho seized on the old synagogue in Dean Street, snatching it from the clutches of a company that wanted to turn it into a lap-dancing club. Then, when property prices in the capital went through the roof, the Soho did a deal with a developer that gave it a 200-seat theatre and writers' centre in return for the right to build flats above the venue. A restaurant covers the theatre's running costs, putting the company in the rare position of spending its subsidy on producing work rather than keeping the toilets clean. At £253,000, the Soho's grant is less than Hampstead Theatre's or the Bush's, and insufficient for a theatre with such an ambitious new writers' programme. But the company's first season in its new home has already had a major impact on the delicate ecology of new writing, and Morris's distinctive taste has provided a refreshing counter to the brutalism of so much new work. "In the end choosing a play is very much like choosing a friend. You have a hunch," says Morris, whose "hunches" last season included eight plays, all box-office hits, of which six were written by women. There was no specific plan in this, but Morris may once again be ahead of the crowd. In the mid-90s she was one of the first programmers to realise that the modern theatre-goer has a preference for 90-minute mini-dramas rather than four-hour epics. (She claims only to have been reflecting her own short attention span.) Taken as a group, the astonishing thing about the plays in the first Soho season is that they pulled in audiences simply by focusing on the pain and pleasures of ordinary people leading ordinary lives. Morris is not afraid of the kind of violence that has become fashionable in the theatre (Alex Jones's Noise, staged when the Soho was camping out in the Dean Street synagogue before building was completed, was as uncomfortable and brutal as theatre gets) but the plays she chooses are less about shocking and more about telling stories. Even Noise sprang from that most common of situations - neighbours arguing about noise levels. Morris is reluctant to talk about either motherhood (she has two girls under five, making her that rarest of creatures, a female artistic director with small children) or religion (she is a practising Jew and won't work late on Fridays). But both seem to influence her choice of plays and her desire to tell stories. "Telling stories is such a good way of drawing people in. It engages people on a deep level. It creates a dialogue and enables people," says Morris, who cites the story of her friend's parents, Polish Jews, who were hidden throughout the war by a woman who was anti-Semitic. "I am interested in those kinds of stories, and theatre is a really good way of exploring the contradictions in people - their very many facets. People are complicated. It is not as simple as saying that Iago is more interesting than Othello." Certainly it is not the case in Morris's latest production, Navy Pier, a play about writing, ambition and creative and intellectual ownership, which opens the Soho's second season this week. Like almost all of the Soho's plays, this is theatre that approaches its subject slightly off centre but with a nose for accessibility. The chances are that it will be yet another hit. But Morris is taking no bets. "In the theatre you can't ever second-guess, and in a way that is great. It means that however successful you become, you should never lose the freedom to go out on a limb, to say, 'That's the play that speaks to me, and that's the one I'm going to put on.' "  Navy Pier is at the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), from Thursday.

webTitle: Arts: Steven Mackintosh tells  Brian Logan  why he is so nervous about appearing at the Royal Court

fields.headline: 'Theatre is not something that I know much about'
fields.standfirst: Steven Mackintosh tells  Brian Logan  why he is so nervous about appearing at the Royal Court
fields.trailText: Steven Mackintosh tells Brian Logan why he is so nervous about appearing at the Royal Court
fields.body:
Steven Mackintosh is one of the more impressive film and TV actors at work in Britain today, but you would be forgiven for not immediately recognising him. Mackintosh submerges himself in his parts: the spliffy student Winston in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels; the farm hand lusted over by Rachel Weisz, Anna Friel and Catherine McCormack in Land Girls; the hero with a troubled past in the BBC's Our Mutual Friend. Mackintosh is practically invisible, too, as a player in the drama of his own life. He is not a man given to self-aggrandisement.

This week he returns to the stage for the first time in eight years, starring alongside Julia Ormond and Tom Wilkinson in David Hare's My Zinc Bed at the Royal Court. Mackintosh, who plays a young poet involved with the wife of an entrepreneur for whom he works, is typically guileless about the project. "I don't read a lot of plays, but I was deeply affected by this one," he enthuses, with something approaching holy respect for Hare. "So to be asked to appear in it as well... I felt incredibly honoured and at the same time petrified."

He is all too aware of the years that have passed since he last trod the boards. "It's daunting having to deal with such a complex text and get accustomed to the ways of theatre acting again. I have no qualms about the writing, just about whether I can do it justice.

"Theatre," he maintains, "is not something I know much about."

That's a contrast to the screen, where Mackintosh has had a succession of high-profile roles since his rise to prominence in Hanif Kureishi's Buddha of Suburbia. This autumn sees him assume leading-man status - as the star of the TV drama Care, directed by Antonia Bird, about a man living with the consequences of child abuse, and the film The Criminal, in which he acts alongside his wife, Lisa Jacobs, and Eddie Izzard.

But Mackintosh has never had an easy relationship with the theatre. Twenty years ago, at the tender age of 12, he starred in The Number of the Beast, Snoo Wilson's play about the satanist Aleister Crowley. "I had to dash a mouse's brains out," he recalls. "Then I had to shove it in my mouth and run round the stage shouting abuse at people."

Small wonder, perhaps, that by his mid-20s Mackintosh was disillusioned with stage work. "I don't feel I was particularly accomplished at it. I didn't like the productions I was doing, and I didn't like what I was doing in them. I'm just not an actor who thinks he can do absolutely everything. I know that there are some who can. But I can't."

He tried Shakespeare under Peter Hall at the National Theatre in the 1980s, and has believed ever since that he "can't do the classics on stage". He doesn't watch them, either, blaming "past experiences when I've come away from the theatre thinking about little else than how uncomfortable I was".

And Mackintosh does believe in being comfortable. In an industry that is characterised by self-destructive excess, he is famously domesticated: married at 21, he is now father to two daughters.

"Having a very settled home life is perfectly natural and exactly right. Anything wilder and more confusing I would find tiring and dull. I've done the wild lifestyle thing in the past - and it just makes you feel really bad."

Mackintosh suggests his life is still being shaped by his early years in the theatre. "Children can't make decisions about careers. Part of me wishes I'd got to a certain age and thought, 'Yes, this is what I want to do with my life.' People who just fall into it one day find themselves going, 'Oh, right, here I am, this is what I seem to be doing then.' I've always felt as if I'm riding a wave.

"Your attitude towards the job changes over the years. I've had times when I've felt very lost within it and felt, 'Maybe this isn't for me.' " He doesn't feel that at the moment. "I'm proud of where I'm at," he says. "And if that carries on, it'll be great. But it goes through phases. Sometimes you sit at home thinking it's gone a bit quiet. Then suddenly something fantastic springs from nowhere. You've just got to roll with it."

 My Zinc Bed is in previews at the Royal Court, London SW1. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

fields.headline: My brilliant career
fields.standfirst: Andrew Weatherall helped to invent both dance music and the superstar DJ. Then, burnt out and disillusioned, he went underground. As he emerges with a new album, he talks to  Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: Andrew Weatherall helped to invent both dance music and the superstar DJ. Then, burnt out and disillusioned, he went underground. As he emerges with a new album, he talks to Dave Simpson
fields.body:
Deep in the heart of London's Rotters Golf Club studios, the man who helped shape the sound of modern music greets me with his most sophisticated piece of equipment. This is not one of the samplers Andrew Weatherall used on Primal Scream's 1991 album Screamadelica, nor one of the studio consoles he used to work with Bjork. The "gadget" has four legs, a sharp snout and a ferocious bark.

Weatherall admits to a reputation as a difficult interviewee, but this is ridiculous: I am granted an audience with him only if I can pacify a ferociously snapping Jack Russell. "That's Morton," explains Weatherall. "He's our wanker detector."

It is difficult to imagine many people in the music business coming out with that sort of line, but then there aren't many people around like Weatherall. He now records (with partner Keith Tenniswood) as Two Lone Swordsmen, but his influence stretches back 10 years. Back in 1990 Weatherall - then one of the first acid-house DJs, at the London club Shoom - began fooling around with an obscure Primal Scream album track called I'm Losing More Than I'll Ever Have. Beginning with a now famous sample from Easy Rider, he mixed the song out of all recognition. The resulting anthem - renamed Loaded - moulded dance from rock and shaped a generation.

After Screamadelica won the first Mercury music prize, Weatherall was tagged "the Phil Spector of techno". For much of the 90s, his was the name to drop as his blistering dance/rock/dub/ambient interfaces triggered off all sorts of new music. He remixed everybody from New Order to Happy Mondays to That Petrol Emotion.

Weatherall also worked as a producer - notably with Beth Orton. At the same time, he was continuing his career as a DJ (although he apparently never thought of it as a career - "I hate all that shit," he says). It's a wonder that he found time to be an artist - but he did, with the massively acclaimed Sabres of Paradise. Then there was his label, Sabresonic, and the London club of the same name where he virtually defined the term "superstar DJ".

But more remarkable than any of this was that Weatherall chose to walk away. While many of his contemporaries were making millions, he started turning down remixes and productions. Then he was fired from his DJ job at Kiss FM for being, he says, "too anarchic and eclectic". After that he abandoned Sabres of Paradise and Sabresonic and in 1998 even left his beloved London - for a rented 18th-century vicarage five miles outside Pontefract. He just grew "tired of dealing with wankers", he says, and had grown to resent "making music by committee, watering myself down".

Weatherall was born 37 years ago in suburban Windsor. As a boy, he searched for anything that proved the world "wasn't as sterile as my surroundings". He was a natural rebel. When his parents told him that punk, tattoos and staying out at night were bad, he plunged into all of them. He still wears the Clash's name on his arm. "They were a big, big thing for me. They got me into reggae... stopped me from rigging up my school tie to the banisters," he says. In his late teens and early 20s Weatherall drifted. He got into scrapes and lived alone. He followed the early, culty New Order. There were several unfortunate haircuts, even a disastrous period as lead vocalist in a pre-acid groove band. "We were called A Fractured Touch," he chuckles. "How shite is that? Still, we always got a good turnout."

Far more important - although he didn't realise it at the time - was a dalliance with the notorious Temple of Psychick Youth, the mysterious youth cult set up by Genesis P-Orridge of Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV. Although Weatherall only communicated with the temple ("I never got as far as the devil worship or posting bodily fluids") they opened up his mind to all sorts of artforms. It was, he says, "a subversive library".

After spells in bricklaying, Weatherall came to DJing more or less by accident. "I always had a good record collection," he says. "Looking back, I was probably the slightly anal child who would turn up when everyone else was getting off with birds, saying, 'Have you heard this B-side - it's really good?' "

As acid house exploded across Britain, club culture and Primal Scream changed his life. He remembers tiny, sweaty acid gigs "buzzing with excitement". He met the Scream at Shoom; however, Weatherall insists that Screamadelica is not his own creation. "I like to think I lit the match," he says. "They had all the ingredients but didn't know how to put them together. But they had beautiful tunes. It was their record."

Screamadelica brought him many things, but mostly the enormous pressure of following up one of the most influential albums of the 90s. "Tell me about it!" he suddenly erupts. "How much pressure is that?" Weatherall veered away from rock bands and plunged into dance. "I now had more money," he says. "Also, I was now taking drugs. I had people putting a microphone in front of me. All the magazines I'd revered for years as a kid living in the suburbs wanted to know my opinion. Add ecstasy, cocaine and acid, what you gonna get? A bit of a loose cannon."

At the height of his mania, he was prone to leaping around in a greatcoat, wielding a cutlass. "You know you're in trouble when you're a DJ and you keep taking off the record that's actually playing," he chuckles. However, somewhere in the fug, the young punk in Weatherall came back and told him that he was turning into one of the wankers. He walked away.

The sojourn in Yorkshire achieved its purpose. Now, clearer of head, Weatherall has re-emerged as one of the few truly important underground artists in Britain. The way Two Lone Swordsmen work (isolated from the mainstream, recording almost daily, selling singles by mail order) is rooted in punk and DIY. Indeed, Tiny Reminders, their darkly mischievous, refreshingly uncompromising album, was influenced by listening to Throbbing Gristle's live box set. "Not the whole thing, obviously. That would be foolish."

Weatherall is still massively influential. A recent album he compiled of 80s industrial dance tunes, 9 O'clock Drop (Nuphonic), led to an surge of those sounds on the dancefloor. He still does the odd carefully vetted remix and has returned to sympathetic clubs, but views mainstream club culture from afar.

He is mostly dryly funny but still brims with punk-rock anger. He rants against dance contemporaries who sell their music to advertising agencies, and he admits to occasionally shouting at the television. But he prefers to vent his spleen in the studio - hence Tiny Reminders' anti-advertising industry track Death to Culture Snitches. But, importantly, Weatherall is comfortable with his status and himself. "Our creativity is high. What I'm doing now won't make as big a cultural impression as Screamadelica, but hopefully it'll have a similar impact on someone. Tiny ripples, but they all get there in the end." Perhaps Weatherall's greatest achievement is that he hasn't lost his edge. Neither has Morton, who gives me a tiny reminding nip as I leave.

 Tiny Reminders is out now on Warp. Two Lone Swordsmen play Brighton Volks (01273 682828), tonight; Creation, Bristol (0117-945 0959), on Friday; and the Welsh Club, Cardiff (029-2023 2199), on Saturday.

fields.headline: GM crops 'worse than N-waste'
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Genetically modified crops pose a greater threat to the environment than nuclear waste or chemical pollution, the executive director of Greenpeace told a court yesterday.
fields.body:
Genetically modified crops pose a greater threat to the environment than nuclear waste or chemical pollution, the executive director of Greenpeace told a court yesterday.

Lord Melchett, head of Greenpeace UK, was speaking on the second day of a retrial at Norwich crown court in which he and 27 others are charged with causing criminal damage to a farm scale trial of genetically modified herbicide resistant forage maize.

Questioned by Owen Davies QC, defending, Lord Melchett said that he thought genetic modification represented the most serious threat to the environment.

"Because it is alive it's not like chemical pollution which you can clean up or even nuclear waste. It might take thousands of years, as in the case of Chernobyl, but it will eventually disappear. GM, if it gets into the environment in a way that causes a problem is probably impossible to stop or recall.

"The other element is that it is capable of going everywhere. Chernobyl was contained to a large area of Europe including Britain but it could not go all over the world. GM because it's alive can ... and could affect generations to come. You can't sweep it up, pull it in, it has not got strings attached."

All 28 defendants deny the charges, which arose from action at a field at Lyng, Norfolk, last July, claiming they acted to protect other crops from imminent contamination by GM pollen. At the original trial they were cleared of theft but the jury was unable to reach a verdict on the criminal damage charges.

Lord Melchett, 52, said the group had intended to uproot six acres of maize and return it to its owner AgrEvo (now Aventis) at its headquarters in Kings Lynn.

"I believe the crop when it flowered would release GM material widely into the environment around the field and further afield.

"When that was released it would cause damage to other agriculture, organic crops and honey, conventional crops, soil and wildlife. Once that GM material was released it was alive and it would remain alive and continue to spread and would be unstoppable."

Lord Melchett denied the attack on the field was a publicity stunt and said they had acted because the danger of contamination was imminent. He said he was horrified to learn that at the conclusion of the trial the GM maize had been ploughed back into the soil rather than removed.

"It never crossed my mind that in July 1999 they [AgrEvo] would simply spread the stuff and plough it in. I was horrified, it seems very irresponsible to me. It was obviously the cheapest method but the most dangerous I can imagine as a farmer."

William Brigham, the owner of the land on which the crops were being grown, had given an interview to Farmers Weekly in which he said the GM maize was about to flower releasing its pollen.

"We realised that if we were to protect the environment we would have to move in the next few days," said Lord Melchett.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Nato bombs 'still killing' in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The Red Cross has called on Nato to stop using cluster bombs after a survey revealed that they caused a disproportionate number of civilian casualties during and after the conflict in Kosovo.
fields.body:
The Red Cross has called on Nato to stop using cluster bombs after a survey revealed that they caused a disproportionate number of civilian casualties during and after the conflict in Kosovo.

The situation has been amplified by the high failure rate of cluster bombs, used exclusively by Nato during airstrikes on Kosovo last year, according to the Red Cross report.

It shows that unexploded bomblets were found up to 1km from their intended targets and that their failure rate was higher than stated in public.

The report quoted a K-For ordnance disposal expert as saying that an average of 15% of cluster bombs, rising to 26%, failed to explode completely.

Cluster bombs contain dozens, or hundreds, of small bomblets which are released and spread over a wide area before they hit the ground. The sub-munitions are meant to explode on impact.

In the year after Nato's bombing campaign ended in June last year , 151 people in Kosovo were killed or injured by unexploded bomblets.

The Red Cross also found that cluster bombs killed or maimed five times more Kosovan children than landmines.

"This may be due to the fact that such sub-munitions are often brightly coloured, lying on the ground and assumed to be 'duds'," the report said. It calls for a moratorium on the use of cluster bombs.

More than a third of peacetime casualties in Kosovo were caused by the munitions, the Red Cross said.

About 30,000 unexploded bomblets are thought to have been left around Kosovo. About 4,000 have been confirmed cleared: a figure which does not include disposals that may have been carried out by K-For troops. Nato has been accused of failing to provide sufficient information on where cluster bombs were dropped.

The Red Cross is calling for cluster bombs to be ranked alongside incendiary weapons, prohibiting their use in populated areas.

"Anti-personnel landmines were doing what they were meant to do, but were not being used properly. Cluster bombs are causing this problem because they're not doing what they were designed to do, so it's a bit more difficult to argue on humanitarian grounds," Peter Herby, the head of the Red Cross anti-mines unit, said.

fields.headline: No: 1715
fields.standfirst: Keano
fields.trailText: Keano
fields.body:
Age:
Two weeks.

Height:
17 inches.

All clothes made by:
Top sportswear manufacturer Diadora.

That's nice. What did they make him? A romper suit? A pretty pair of booties?
I'm afraid you might have got the wrong end of the stick. Keano is not a baby.

That's a relief: I was worried that he would suffocate under all that plastic.
No chance of that. Keano is in fact a plastic effigy of Manchester United captain Roy Keane. A doll, to be exact.

What's so interesting about a plastic doll shaped like a footballer?
How does £18,000 grab you?

By the throat.
Glad to hear it, because that's how much they say Keano is worth.

Flipping heck. All that money for a toy?
Keano is not your average toy. He's one of a kind. The doll was created for a magazine advert by Diadora, the sponsor of Roy Keane's boots. With a grizzled look, a distinctive growl and an "easy wind-up action", the toy fitted perfectly with Diadora's "Passione Italiana" campaign (apart from the Italian bit). In fact it fitted so well that people immediately wanted to buy it.

And Diadora has been inundated with offers?
Apparently so, with bids peaking at £18,000 (more than £1,058 per inch). The managing director of Diadora UK, Andrew Ronnie, says: "We're astonished at the reaction. Some of the offers have really made us think."

Think what?
About making millions of Keanos and cleaning up, I would expect.

So if Keano is a rip-roaring success, what other great sporting dolls can we expect?
How about a Michael Owen with acrobatic tumbling action? Or the Nasser Hussain doll with disposable wicket? Then there's Dress Me Becks and Action Patrick Vieira (press a button and he loses his head!), not to mention Tiny Tears Gascoigne. Let's face it, we're in the money.

Not to be confused with:
The real Roy Keane (after all, he's about a fifth of the size).

fields.headline: New logo for London Transport
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The roundel symbol of London Transport, designed early last century, may have reached the end of the line.
fields.body:
The roundel symbol of London Transport, designed early last century, may have reached the end of the line.

Since London Transport was renamed Transport for London in July, marketing people have questioned the suitability of the bisected circle, despite its being among the top six most recognised logos - alongside Coca-Cola, Nike and McDonald's.

But Chris Bailey, public affairs officer for Transport for London, said: "We do need to establish a new identity for Transport for London, and while the chances of the roundel disappearing altogether are slim, we are looking at finding a corporate logo which incorporates everything from black cabs to riverboats to ensure that we have a coherent branding structure."

webTitle: Science and the soul rendezvous at the Vatican

fields.headline: Science and the soul rendezvous at the Vatican
fields.trailText: Having marked the turn of the millennium by apologising to many of its historic enemies, the Roman Catholic church has begun this week building bridges with one of the most obdurate: the world of rational thought and science.
fields.body:
Having marked the turn of the millennium by apologising to many of its historic enemies, the Roman Catholic church has begun this week building bridges with one of the most obdurate: the world of rational thought and science.

Thousands of scientists will attempt to plumb the depths of the human soul and the mysteries of outer space in the quest for an amicable meeting of mind and matter.

The week-long Jubilee of the Universities reaches its climax on Saturday, when the Pope will meet the delegates.

Neuroscientists will have a chance to delve into the organic seat of the immortal soul when a three-day conference begins in the Vatican this morning.

Entitled Architectures of the Mind, Architectures of the Brain, the gathering will be addressed by luminaries such as Professor Richard Frackowiak of the Institute of Neurology in London and Professor Steven Pinker of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Those hoping for a final solution in the battle between Hobbesian materialists, who recognise the soul only as an epiphenomenon of organised matter, and the Idealists, who deny the existence of the material world except as a creation of the knowing mind, may be disappointed.

"Studies of the soul are still in a pioneering stage," said Gabriele Miceli, a professor of neurology at the Catholic University in Rome, the organiser of the conference.

"These topics don't lend themselves to an experimental approach. We will be dealing with much more modest matters, such as the mechanisms and transformations of the brain and where they occur. We are a long way from understanding the soul or higher, philosophical thought."

Researchers attending a conference in Bologna - Science and Knowledge: Towards What Rationality? - will go even more boldly to the edges of the universe. The meeting will be addressed tomorrow by Professor Duccio Macchetto, director of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, on the possibility of finding life outside our planet.

Prof Macchetto, who is responsible for the Hubble space telescope programme, said a powerful enough telescope would eventually give scientists the chance to travel into the past and probe for the "Big Bang" origins of the universe.

A sufficiently potent instrument 2,000 light years away would be able to record the birth of Christ, he told the Rome daily La Repubblica.

"I'm afraid though you would need a lens as large as the solar system to get a good image of the child Jesus."

webTitle: Factory goes from Renault to Rothko

fields.headline: Factory goes from Renault to Rothko
fields.standfirst: Billionaire to show collection at scene of past labour battles
fields.trailText: One of France's richest men plans to build a modern art museum to rival Bilbao's Guggenheim centre in a disused industrial complex on an island in the middle of the Seine.
fields.body:
One of France's richest men plans to build a modern art museum to rival Bilbao's Guggenheim centre in a disused industrial complex on an island in the middle of the Seine.

The outstanding collection of François Pinault, a multi-billionaire capitalist whose business empire includes the auction house Christie's, will go on display on the Ile Seguin, a former Renault car factory which has seen some of the country's most violent labour battles.

Mr Pinault, who started life as a humble Breton timber merchant and is now worth well over £3bn, will set up a foundation to receive the modern and contemporary art collection he started in earnest 10 years ago.

In consultation with Louis Schweitzer, Renault's boss, and Jean-Pierre Fourcade, the mayor of the run-down western Paris suburb of Boulogne-Billancourt, he will also oversee the selection process to find an architect to design the 30,000 square metre museum, due to open some time in 2004.

"Everyone's happy," Mr Fourcade said yesterday.

"Renault has sold most of the island to Pinault, Pinault gets a unique site for his collection, I get a world-class attraction in my town, and the culture ministry gets a brand-new modern art museum at no cost whatsoever to the state."

Mr Pinault's several hundred paintings, sculptures, photographs and videos, mainly from the past half-century, are reputed to form one of finest private collections of modern and contemporary art in Europe.

They include works by such modern masters as Mondrian, Picasso, Brancusi, Modigliani, Rauschenberg, Rothko and Warhol, and photographs by such as Cindy Sherman, videos by contemporary creators such as Bruce Nauman and Gary Hill, and installations by British and American artists such as Damien Hirst and Matthew Barney.

His latest acquisition, finalised in Avignon in May, was Jeff Koons' Split Rocker, a giant half-rockinghorse half-dinosaur, which is almost certainly destined to form the centrepiece of the museum.

The only comparable work, Mr Koons' Puppy, currently guards the entrance to the spectacular Guggenheim museum in Bilbao, Spain.

In parallel with his arch-rival Bernard Arnault of the luxury-goods giant Louis-Vuitton-Moet-Hennessy, Mr Pinault, 64, has built up one of France's biggest personal fortunes in the past 40 years.

A consummate corporate predator, he controls a vast and varied empire headed by the flagship Printemps department stores but including La Redoute, the mail-order giant; Fnac, the music, electronics and books chain; a Bordeaux vineyard, Chateau Latour; the luxury jeweller Boucheron; Samsonite, the luggage firm; Le Point magazine; a first division French football club; and the Vail ski resorts in Colorado.

Having left college at 16 with no qualifications, Mr Pinault began snapping up dozens of small undervalued companies to expand the family timber business. The methods he used to turn them around were said to be ruthless.

His rivals also credit him with an almost supernatural commercial instinct. He once summed up his business strategy as "the Breton-pig syndrome - when pork is selling well, you build pigsties. When it isn't, you stop."

But Alain Minc, the banker, philosopher and writer who is one of Mr Pinault's closest advisers, says his business sense is "poetic".

Mr Pinault's first major art purchase, in 1990, was Mondrian's 1925 Tableau Losangique II. He paid £5.7m for it, double the annual acquisitions budget of the national modern art museum at the Pompidou centre in Paris, and confided to his biographer: "On that day I knew I could afford the summits of contemporary art."

Now the collection of one of France's most successful living capitalists will be on public display in a spot that for decades was synonymous with communist-dominated trade union militancy.

Renault's Boulogne-Billancourt site, whose future has been uncertain since the company abandoned it a decade ago, was the scene of countless confrontations between workers and riot police, including the sit-in that sparked the May 1968 national strike.

The Pinault Foundation museum will form the hub of a major redevelopment.

webTitle: Europe asked to foot bill for new Chernobyl

fields.headline: Europe asked to foot bill for new Chernobyl
fields.trailText: The European Commission, led by Chris Patten, its foreign policy commissioner, is pushing for two new nuclear power plants to replace the reactor at Chernobyl when it closes at the end of this year, 14 years after the world's worst environmental disaster.
fields.body:
The European Commission, led by Chris Patten, its foreign policy commissioner, is pushing for two new nuclear power plants to replace the reactor at Chernobyl when it closes at the end of this year, 14 years after the world's worst environmental disaster.

In defiance of growing concern in western Europe about nuclear energy, the commission meets today to approve far-reaching recommendations which call on European taxpayers to subsidise the completion of two nuclear plants in Ukraine and one in Russia, the countries with the worst safety records in Europe.

Ukraine finally agreed this summer to close the last of the four Chernobyl reactors in December in return for US and European help in dismantling it. Although it no longer insists that a new reactor must be built to make up for the energy loss, the European commission is pressing for this.

A report to today's meeting - the first full discussion of nuclear power since the forming of the new commission last year - recommends loan support for completing two mothballed Soviet nuclear plants at Khmelnitsky and Rivne (known as K2R4). The report was authorised by Chris Patten and Günther Verheugen, the commissioner in charge of EU enlargement.

"The commission is considering a Euratom loan with complimentary financing from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development [EBRD] and bilateral export credit agencies," says the report, obtained by the Guardian. It proposes to go on with the project "to ensure, through constant political dialogue with Ukraine, that these two reactors are completed to the highest possible safety standard".

When support for nuclear power is falling in western Europe, and Germany is committed to phasing it out, analysts find it surprising that the commission should still be pressing for its expansion in eastern Europe.

"It's extraordinary that this is happening when no member country of the European Union is building or has any plans for new nuclear plants. The last one opened in February at Civaux in France," Tobias Munchmeyer, a nuclear expert with Greenpeace, said.

"It looks like the last effort by the ailing nuclear industry in France and Germany to get contracts in Europe. China is the only remaining country with potential, since other states in Asia like South Korea and India are looking to buy from Asian companies."

The report from Mr Patten and Mr Verheugen calls for "a more proactive policy with Russia". This would include support for Russian requests for Euratom financing for completing a reactor known as Kalinin 3.

If the recommendations are adopted, Greenpeace and other anti-nuclear campaigners fear it could set a precedent for a whole new generation of nuclear plants to be built in eastern Europe. Until now, the EU has been moving in the opposite direction by urging applicant countries, in particular Bulgaria, Slovakia, and Lithuania, to close down their Chernobyl-type reactors.

The commission's recommendation also raised eyebrows yesterday because Ukraine already has spare nuclear capacity.

"It has large installed excess capacity," an industry analyst said. "But its problem is that it does not have the money to buy gas or nuclear fuel from Russia. Last winter there was a heating crisis because four of the 13 reactors in Ukraine didn't operate because of cash difficulties."

Mr Patten and Mr Verheugen seem to be motivated by a cold-war-era conviction that Ukraine should not depend on Russia for its energy supplies.

Even if their recommendations get past the other commissioners today, they will still have to be approved by member governments in the council of ministers. The European parliament is also likely to put up strong resistance.

Another hurdle is EBRD approval. Under its statutes the bank can only approve the lowest-cost option for any project loan, and it may be hard to prove that completing the plants is cheap.

"Euratom, which is pushing this loan, supports the nuclear industry. It is an anomaly that this one energy lobby has a treaty-based existence within the EU's structures," Antony Froggatt, an independent energy consultant, said.

Mr Patten's spokesman, Gunnar Wiegand, said he could not deny that there was a policy dilemma, but added: "It's good to remember that a commitment was made to Ukraine in the G7's memorandum of understanding in 1995. The west promised then to help to provide Ukraine with alternative energy capacity when Chernobyl was closed. That doesn't exclude nuclear power."

webTitle: Great giveaway:  Saatchi sheds works of art

fields.headline: Great giveaway:  Saatchi sheds works of art
fields.trailText: A gallery curator was stunned by Charles Saatchi's generosity when one of dozens of pieces of contemporary British art which the collector has given to regional museums collapsed on her as it was being erected.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A gallery curator was stunned by Charles Saatchi's generosity when one of dozens of pieces of contemporary British art which the collector has given to regional museums collapsed on her as it was being erected.

"I'm fine, no harm done to me or the piece," Jennifer Melville, keeper of fine art at Aberdeen art gallery, said yesterday of her brush with Keith Wilson's Untitled, a stack of drawers and window casements.

Aberdeen was one of nine cash strapped British museums where Christmas came early, as the Art Fund, the independent art charity, distributed 39 pieces, together conservatively valued at over £200,000, on behalf of the collector Charles Saatchi.

Mr Saatchi is renowned for buying the entire studio contents of artists who take his fancy.

His collection was the basis of the exhibition entitled Sensation, which made young British artists such as Damien Hirst international superstars.

His annual clearout is becoming an eagerly awaited event - last year he gave 100 works, valued at £600,000, to the Arts Council collection.

The previous year he sold works by Hirst, Chris Ofili and Sarah Lucas, and raised £1.6m to create bursaries for young artists.

He gave the latest batch away through the Art Fund, which offered museums and galleries with a particular interest in contemporary art a list including works by Jordan Baseman, Marcus Taylor, Richard Woods and Katherine Dowson. "It really was like Christmas as the crates arrived and we began unpacking our presents," said Robert Dickinson, principal curator at Swindon museum and gallery, which got a piece by Jeffrey Dennis and a nobly entitled work by John Greenwood: Rings & Strings & Things (No Wings but there is some Jelly as Always).

All the museums and galleries on yesterday's list have seen acquisition budgets cut hard in local authority spending cuts, which have left many museums in crisis.

Aberdeen's purchase fund was slashed from £24,000 to £2,000, and as Ms Melville learned at a meeting yesterday, is now zero. The 10 Saatchi works fill an increasingly gaping hole in her collection.

David Barrie, director of the Art Fund, said: Charles Saatchi's gift is a tremendous boost to these collections, at a time when most are desperately short of money, and have little or nothing to spend on art."

fields.headline: Reinstated gay sailor attacked
fields.trailText: A gay sailor who was reinstated by the Royal Navy is in hospital after a homophobic attack in which he was left for dead. Richard Young, 26, was sacked from the navy a year ago because of a Ministry of Defence ban on homosexuals but in May became the first openly gay sailor to be reinstated.
fields.body:
A gay sailor who was reinstated by the Royal Navy is in hospital after a homophobic attack in which he was left for dead. Richard Young, 26, was sacked from the navy a year ago because of a Ministry of Defence ban on homosexuals but in May became the first openly gay sailor to be reinstated.

He was set upon by two men as he walked through Plymouth with a friend at the weekend. He suffered a fractured skull, broken jaw and broken eye sockets. Doctors told him that had he not been kept conscious by his friend he could have died.

He is in Plymouth's Derriford hospital facing surgery to rebuild his face.

Devon and Cornwall police said the attack on Mr Young was a serious assault and was being treated as a homophobic incident.

Two men had been arrested and released on police bail.

Mr Young was sacked from his job as a navy chef last August. Days later the European court of human rights ruled the banning of gays in the armed services was illegal.

Mr Young said he wanted to speak about his attack to encourage other victims to come forward.

"The more people get done for this the less it is going to happen. We are here, we are a major community and we are not going to go away."

fields.headline: Army denies widespread drug abuse
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The army yesterday denied it had a widespread drugs problem after 10 soldiers tested positive for illegal substances while in Germany.
fields.body:
The army yesterday denied it had a widespread drugs problem after 10 soldiers tested positive for illegal substances while in Germany.

The soldiers from the Royal Highland Fusiliers, who are based at Fort George, near Inverness, were caught during a random sample of 262 soldiers of all ranks on a tour of duty near Hamburg.

They are in the process of being discharged, but have the right of appeal.

It is the latest in a series of drug incidents in the armed forces, many concerning Scottish regiments.

In June, 11 soldiers of the Black Watch, also based at Fort George, were discharged after failing drugs tests, and a month earlier eight soldiers with the 1st Battalion Royal Scots, and seven from the Queen's Dragoon Guards, were dismissed.

The Ministry of Defence introduced a drug testing programme and zero tolerance policy in 1995. Since then 323,000 male and female soldiers have been tested, 2,500 have tested positive for drugs, and 1,800 have been discharged.

The tests, which are carried out with less than 24 hours notice, are for any illegal substance, including cannabis, heroin and cocaine.

Yesterday, a spokeswoman for the army in Scotland confirmed that soldiers from the Royal Highland Fusiliers had been disciplined, but denied there was evidence of widespread drug misuse.

She said a rigid testing procedure had been responsible for bringing offenders to light and there was no deep-seated problem.

The MoD has declined to comment on reports that the Royal Highland Fusiliers had tested positive for cocaine and ecstasy.

An MoD spokesman said the forces were aware of drug abuse issues and intended to remain on top of the situation.

The spokesman added: "There is a careful screening programme at the recruitment stage and an ongoing programme of drug awareness."

webTitle: Drive to cut smoking at work

fields.headline: Drive to cut smoking at work
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Employers came under renewed pressure to protect workers from passive smoking yesterday when the health and safety executive approved a code of practice.
fields.body:
Employers came under renewed pressure to protect workers from passive smoking yesterday when the health and safety executive approved a code of practice.

The code spells out a number of steps businesses can take to ensure non-smokers breathe clean air in offices, shops and factories, ranging from improving ventilation to setting aside smoking rooms.

The guidelines flesh out the existing legislation which requires employers to safeguard the welfare of their staff.

Failing to abide by the code of practice will not be an offence in itself, but would leave an employer vulnerable in a court case.

However, pubs and clubs will be exempt from the provisions of the code. Instead, the hospitality industry has been asked to sign up to the public places charter, a voluntary agreement which encourages introduction of no-smoking zones.

Anti-smoking campaigners said the new rules were "good news" for an estimated 3m non-smokers exposed to tobacco smoke at work.

A spokesman for the HSE said the code stopped short of a total workplace ban, and would leave employers the right to work out the solution that suited them.

However, Simon Clark, director of the smokers' rights group Forest, said: "If you don't want to work in a smoky atmosphere, don't work in a pub, work at McDonald's."

Forest also fears the code might encourage discrimination against smokers at job interviews.

webTitle: Rock tries to curb 'upper class yobs'

fields.headline: Rock tries to curb 'upper class yobs'
fields.trailText: The Cornish village of Rock, a summer retreat for Prince William and Prince Harry, is set to curb the drinking antics of visitors from public schools.
fields.body:
The Cornish village of Rock, a summer retreat for Prince William and Prince Harry, is set to curb the drinking antics of visitors from public schools.

Councillors in North Cornwall have recommended the introduction of an alcohol-free zone along the quarter of a mile village seafront to prevent young drinkers taking their booze outside.

Last month Paul Tyler, Liberal Democrat MP for North Cornwall, said the village had become a holiday haven for "upper class yobs" who poured into the area during the summer.

Local people have complained about rowdy behaviour and litter.

John Lugg, chairman of the council's environmental services committee, which recommended the ban, said: "There has been a worrying increase in loutish behaviour from privileged hooray Henrys from outside Rock who have a lot of money to spend on drink.

"The hotels and the parish council are in favour of the ban and the chances are the bylaw will be passed within two weeks."

However, Eddie Miller, landlord of the Mariners hotel, said that a ban would be difficult to enforce.

"The police would have to be outside the pub every night. My concern is that they will expect me to enforce it, which I won't."

Mr Miller said problems with teenagers had been exaggerated by people who retired to live in Rock.

"The young people who come here are a smashing crowd. They are pussy cats who go home when they are asked."
