webTitle: Initiative by NSPCC hits cash snag

fields.headline: Initiative by NSPCC hits cash snag
fields.standfirst:
NSPCC
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: NSPCC, the children's charity, is scaling down an ambitious programme to eradicate child abuse after failing to meet a £250m fundraising target within the expected timescale.
fields.body:
NSPCC, the children's charity, is scaling down an ambitious programme to eradicate child abuse after failing to meet a £250m fundraising target within the expected timescale.

The Full Stop initiative was launched in March 1999. NSPCC managers set a target of £250m in donations and pledges within 12 months and prepared plans to increase spending on services for children to more than £7.5m a month.

But the charity told its staff yesterday: "The rapid growth of children's services is to be slowed down to reflect a revised cashflow."

In the first 18 months of the appeal the NSPCC raised £70m in cash and pledges. Appeal organisers said a further £100m was forthcoming, but not firmly committed.

That projected income of £170m over 18 months falls well short of the £250m target over 12 months.

But the charity said it was confident it would reach £250m by the end of this year in cash, firm pledges and anticipated "secure income streams".

David Prescott, chief operating officer, said the appeal should not be regarded as a failure. "Over the last three years or so, expenditure on children's services has risen by about 60%. We have reached the point where we are cautious about further growth in expenditure until the appeal starts to accelerate again."

Mr Prescott rejected allegations that extension of the NSPCC appeal until the end of this year would squeeze out the fundraising efforts of other children's charities.

fields.headline: SPD backs return of referendum
fields.trailText: Germany's main governing party, the Social Democrats (SPD), said yesterday that it would produce proposals to amend the constitution to allow referendums. They are banned by the post-war constitution because of the way   they were used by the Nazis to tighten their grip.
fields.body:
Germany's main governing party, the Social Democrats (SPD), said yesterday that it would produce proposals to amend the constitution to allow referendums. They are banned by the post-war constitution because of the way they were used by the Nazis to tighten their grip.

The idea of reviving them was floated last weekend by the EU commissioner on enlargement, Günter Verheugen, a German, who said his countrymen should be able to vote on expanding the union.

The chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, and his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, were quick to rule out a popular vote, arguing it could become a focus for xenophobic populism - and even delay EU expansion.

But the fact that Mr Schröder's party has endorsed the idea reviving referendums is bound to add to the suspicion that the Germans are playing a double game. Berlin has long been suspected of trying to put back the accession of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

The SPD secretary general, Franz Münterfering, said in a newspaper interview that the government would push through the necessary laws before the 2002 election.

A spokesman for the SPD, which is in coalition with the Greens, said the issue was not linked to EU enlargement, but a party committee would make proposals this autumn for a bill to allow referendums on a variety of other issues. The Greens say EU enlargement could be excluded from permitted referendum issues.

fields.headline: Something for everyone, except surprises
fields.trailText: The BFI's list of the top 100 television shows is like the guest list for a wedding written by the bride's mother. It has, thanks to familial protocols and social convention, everyone you would expect on it, but much to the horror of the happy couple, it seems rather dull, rather predictable.
fields.body:
The BFI's list of the top 100 television shows is like the guest list for a wedding written by the bride's mother. It has, thanks to familial protocols and social convention, everyone you would expect on it, but much to the horror of the happy couple, it seems rather dull, rather predictable.

There, at the top table, is the usual band of dramatic aunties and gentle, comedic uncles. While no one would deny them a place at the feast, their inclusion seems to stem from duty rather than choice, as if not inviting them would have cause raised eyebrows and tut-tutting.

Cathy Come Home was undoubtedly a watershed in television, addressing issues that had never been tackled, opening up avenues of possibility and firing imaginations, but it is impossible to say whether it should be judged on its impact, its result, rather than solely as a discrete work of TV drama? On those purely artistic terms, does it still qualify as great television? If it does - I haven't met anyone under 40 who has actually seen it - the BBC should show it again, instead of repeating Casualty.

Currently being repeated, Fawlty Towers still stands as an extremely funny sitcom, probably the best British sitcom - and certainly leagues ahead of the hugely overrated Only Fools and Horses. But the best British programme of all time? Like Waldorf Salad, it's all a matter of taste, and I take mine, like all surveys of this kind, with a pinch of salt.

And there's the rub. The BFI's list says more about the age of the broadcasting bigwigs who responded than the quality of the programmes. After all, it wouldn't take Carol Vorderman to work out the average age of those who favoured Dad's Army and The Naked Civil Servant.

That said, the nineties are reasonably fairly represented. While more modern dramas fared less well, sitcoms boosted the percentage of shows on the list from the past 10 years.

The joys of Absolutely Fabulous still elude me. But since everyone else in the country liked it, its appearance is, again, oh-so-predictable. Even the inclusion of the Teletubbies is hardly a surprise, since there can't be anyone who doesn't think it is educational, good television for children. And what's a wedding without some entertainment for the kids?

Landmark documentaries, like serious cousins, earned their places simply for being worthy, with Walking With Dinosaurs, the young pretender sneaking in, akin to a dot.com entrepreneur at a table full of lawyers.

Like the best weddings though, there is always someone uninvited. Poor EastEnders is missed off in a terrible miscarriage of justice, while Doctor Who, bizarrely, rates as the third best British programme ever made.

Sorry Den and Angie, Ian and Cindy, Ethel and Dot, Grant and Sharon, you simply don't compare to invaders from the spider planet. What a disappointing reception.

Gareth McLean is the Guardian's TV critic

webTitle: What is left to laugh at now that England have won?

fields.headline: What is left to laugh at now that England have won?
fields.standfirst: Paul Weaver on the passing of an English tradition
fields.trailText: "If Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain had widened the M25, or towed this island into the warmer waters of the Mediterranean, they could not have inflicted greater damage on the national psyche." Paul Weaver on the passing of an English tradition.
fields.body:
Any day now someone will put a death notice in the Times. "In affectionate remembrance of English humour which died at the Oval on 4th September, 2000. Deeply lamented by a large circle of sorrowing comedians, satirists and piss-takers. RIP."

Someone might even burn the bails from the recent Test match, put the ashes in a small urn and place it on a shelf at the Comedy Store. These are historic times.

The butt stops here, in London SE11 5SS, known otherwise as the Kennington Oval. Suddenly everyone has stopped telling jokes about English cricket and is taking it most seriously. It feels a little like Harry Enfield reading the main evening news; it is a smashing idea but, somehow, it does not feel right.

It was a long time ago, 1962 to be precise, that the American statesman Dean Acheson famously remarked that "Great Britain has lost an empire and not yet found a role".

The observation struck a raw nerve, probably because of its biting accuracy, and it still holds good today. But we no longer wring our hands over Suez; and if you remember the full, pre-first world war pomp and power of the British empire, you are very wrinkly indeed.

We have, however, developed a nice little line in self-deprecatory humour, even if it is a market stall where there once stood a major department store.

And somehow a bunch of miserable cricketers were wonderfully symbolic of lost lands, of a nation that had had its bowler hat blown off and its brolly turned inside out by the winds of change.

If Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain had difficulty in sleeping on Monday night it is little wonder. They have much to answer for. You may seek solace sniggering at Tim Henman's next result or guffawing when Britain's four-by-four drop the baton in Sydney. But it will just not be the same.

Just as we have a need to hate some people, be they fictional, as in JR Ewing, or real, as in Big Brother's Nasty Nick, we also need people to moan about and make fun of.

That elegant and darkly humorous writer Hector Hugh Munro, otherwise known as Saki, once wrote a short story in which the hostess of a popular annual house party would always invite someone the others could not abide.

"Why, in God's name, did you invite so-and-so along?" she would be asked every year.

"Oh, to give you all something to talk about after dinner," she would reply.

Even in the middle of a notably successful government, with Labour still on target for another convincing victory at the next election, we feel more comfortable laughing at Tony Blair than when we took him seriously in his honeymoon period.

You cannot always get a giggle out of football. Too many people take it seriously. Xenophobia gets in the way. But cricket, somehow, fits the bill perfectly.

When England lose at cricket it is possible to cast a bleak eye not only in the direction of the players but also the coach, the selectors, the blazers at Lord's and even the education system plus the government of the day, with a bit of the climate thrown in. There is so much more to discuss in the pub afterwards.

It was that most intelligent of actors Walter Matthau who once said, with a typical Lower East Side growl, that he enjoyed losing when he gambled. Perhaps he could afford it more than most. But he explained that losing, with its associated feelings of remorse, self-pity, self-loathing and even penury, was a far richer emotional experience than the rather ephemeral glee of winning. It is why sad poets outnumber happy ones.

All told, then, if Fletcher and Hussain had widened the M25, or towed this island into the warmer waters of the Mediterranean, they could not have inflicted greater damage on the national psyche.

It is enough to make you feel a warm glow of nostalgia for the former England coach David Lloyd and any one of a long list of hopeless England captains you care to name.

At least there is a difficult winter tour to negotiate, followed by the Australians next summer. Do not give up on English cricket just yet.

The observation struck a raw nerve, probably because of its biting accuracy, and it still holds good today. But we no longer wring our hands over Suez; and if you remember the full, pre-first world war pomp and power of the British empire, you are very wrinkly indeed. We have, however, developed a nice little line in self-deprecatory humour, even if it is a market stall where there once stood a major department store. And somehow a bunch of miserable cricketers were wonderfully symbolic of lost lands, of a nation that had had its bowler hat blown off and its brolly turned inside out by the winds of change. If Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain had difficulty in sleeping on Monday night it is little wonder. They have much to answer for. You may seek solace sniggering at Tim Henman's next result or guffawing when Britain's four-by-four drop the baton in Sydney. But it will just not be the same. Just as we have a need to hate some people, be they fictional, as in JR Ewing, or real, as in Big Brother's Nasty Nick, we also need people to moan about and make fun of. That elegant and darkly humorous writer Hector Hugh Munro, otherwise known as Saki, once wrote a short story in which the hostess of a popular annual house party would always invite someone the others could not abide. "Why, in God's name, did you invite so-and-so along?" she would be asked every year. "Oh, to give you all something to talk about after dinner," she would reply. Even in the middle of a notably successful government, with Labour still on target for another convincing victory at the next election, we feel more comfortable laughing at Tony Blair than when we took him seriously in his honeymoon period. You cannot always get a giggle out of football. Too many people take it seriously. Xenophobia gets in the way. But cricket, somehow, fits the bill perfectly. When England lose at cricket it is possible to cast a bleak eye not only in the direction of the players but also the coach, the selectors, the blazers at Lord's and even the education system plus the government of the day, with a bit of the climate thrown in. There is so much more to discuss in the pub afterwards. It was that most intelligent of actors Walter Matthau who once said, with a typical Lower East Side growl, that he enjoyed losing when he gambled. Perhaps he could afford it more than most. But he explained that losing, with its associated feelings of remorse, self-pity, self-loathing and even penury, was a far richer emotional experience than the rather ephemeral glee of winning. It is why sad poets outnumber happy ones. All told, then, if Fletcher and Hussain had widened the M25, or towed this island into the warmer waters of the Mediterranean, they could not have inflicted greater damage on the national psyche. It is enough to make you feel a warm glow of nostalgia for the former England coach David Lloyd and any one of a long list of hopeless England captains you care to name. At least there is a difficult winter tour to negotiate, followed by the Australians next summer. Do not give up on English cricket just yet.

webTitle: Gough ignores the hate mail to revel in life without injury

fields.headline: Gough ignores the hate mail to revel in life without injury
fields.standfirst: Rage at central contracts leads Yorkshire fans to target their own fast bowler
fields.trailText: Rage at central contracts leads Yorkshire fans to target their own fast bowler.
fields.body:
Darren Gough, acclaimed as England's player of the series after a rousing victory against the West Indies at the Oval, has received hate mail from Yorkshire supporters resentful about his prolonged absences from the county.

The introduction of central contracts, which gives England licence to rest key players when they see fit, ensured that Gough remained fit throughout an international summer for the first time in his career.

The benefits were obvious: a revitalised Gough took 25 wickets as he rediscovered the bounce that had been gradually deflated by an overloaded fixture list and a succession of injuries.

"It is the first time that I have got to the last Test of a summer without breaking down and that has been a lot to do with central contracts," Gough said. "I can now put my feet up for three weeks before we go to Kenya and I think I've deserved it.

"But I've taken a lot of stick from Yorkshire members. I got another letter during the Oval test saying that Yorkshire should terminate my contract and that no one should put money in the collection buckets when they are passed around for my benefit next year.

"Well, I'm not having any buckets, so it shows how much he knows. And he didn't leave his home telephone number or address, so I couldn't send anyone round to kneecap him. I have given my all for Yorkshire and England for the last 12 years, and obviously it hurts to get letters accusing me of not pulling my weight."

Gough's disgust might be one of the reasons why he has been seen househunting in Buckinghamshire, although he has no immediate intention to change counties.

England resisted Yorkshire's requests last month that they should release Gough for the climax to the championship, insisting that he must be allowed the rest and recuperation that would be granted to other leading fast bowlers the world over.

With Yorkshire's championship challenge in disarray anyway, the issue has become less intense, but the county will still press this winter for a re-examination of the central contracts system in the belief that its over-use will bring about a damaging fall in standards at county level.

Yorkshire might also consider whether it is just coincidence that while Gough has remained fit this summer, under sympathetic handling, their own highly-rated group of fast bowlers have been badly hit by injury.

Gough, swinging the ball at 90mph and a fullish length, and the more angular, taller figure of Andrew Caddick became the first England new-ball pair to bowl throughout a series since Fred Trueman and Brian Statham against South Africa 40 years earlier.

"We have had four good pace bowlers for England this summer, and now we are going out to Pakistan to learn how to bowl there," said Gough. "From what I've read, the pitches do get uneven in bounce and hopefully we can exploit that."

"Three of us can reverse swing the ball and Andy Caddick can expect his usual uneven bounce. If we can stay fit, we've got a chance."

webTitle: Floodlights bring the best out of Fleming to scupper Yorkshire

fields.headline: Floodlights bring the best out of Fleming to scupper Yorkshire
fields.standfirst:
Kent 217 Yorkshire 153
Kent win by 64 runs
fields.trailText:
Kent 217 Yorkshire 153
Kent win by 64 runs
fields.body:
A disciplined team performance by Kent, who began this game second from bottom in the National League's First Division, denied Yorkshire any chance of the title under the Canterbury floodlights.

The Kent club made cautious predictions for the appeal of razzmatazz cricket in this conservative corner, anticipating a normal one-day crowd, but the ancient St Lawrence ground was packed to bursting point for its first floodlit match.

One of the ECB lighting towers did indeed burst, reducing the arena to three-quarter light. But, with screwdriver and fuse swiftly located, the delay to the Yorkshire innings lasted 10 minutes and no adjustment of the target was deemed necessary.

Kent's former captain Steve Marsh opened the innings with his successor Matthew Fleming for his last knock at Canterbury, on the day that he announced his retirement from first-class cricket. He was the junior partner in a spirited stand that put up 76 at five an over, with Fleming exploiting the early space in the outfield. It took an Exocet of a throw by Michael Vaughan from the deep to unseat him, run out on 79 scored in 85 balls.

The habitually elegant Rahul Dravid also hit out in an attempt to maintain the rate, and Paul Nixon provided punch down the order. When Matthew Hoggard returned late in the piece to complete his allocation, Nixon greeted him with two steepling sixes over mid-wicket. Hoggard's revenge was swift, bowling Nixon as he attempted the shot for a third time, and disciplined bowling at the death kept the target within manageable bounds.

For Yorkshire, though, it often takes Darren Lehmann to define what is manageable. When the prolific Australian followed David Byas back into the pavilion with 17 on the board the visitors needed one backbone innings to maintain their run of five wins in a row. Vaughan, Gavin Hamilton and Richard Blakey tried but failed too soon.

For Kent the main worry was when Dravid finger-tipped a vicious clout by Vaughan at cover point. The Indian dislocated a finger in mid-season and has not resumed his customary slip position since.

Having left the field briefly, however, he demonstrated that all was well by taking two catches on the boundary as the Kent march continued. As is so often the way when the asking rate mounts by the over, the end came swiftly and Kent climbed with relief to mid-table.

fields.headline: Giddins set for crisis talks
fields.trailText: The Warwickshire coach Bob Woolmer is to hold showdown talks today with the unsettled England seamer Ed Giddins.
fields.body:
The Warwickshire coach Bob Woolmer is to hold showdown talks today with the unsettled England seamer Ed Giddins.

Giddins' current contract expires at the end of this season and there has been speculation linking him with a move back to his former county Sussex.

Woolmer wants to thrash matters out with Giddins, who has struggled for fitness this summer and whose financial demands are considered unrealistic by Warwickshire.

Giddins, who played in two Tests against Zimbabwe this summer, will not play in the game with Middlesex at Lord's which begins today because of question marks over his attitude and fitness.

webTitle: Gloucestershire defy rain to stay on target for hat-trick

fields.headline: Gloucestershire defy rain to stay on target for hat-trick
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 148-8 (adjusted to 171 under Duckworth/Lewis)
Gloucestershire 174-4
Gloucestershire win by six wickets
fields.trailText:
Sussex 148-8 (adjusted to 171 under Duckworth/Lewis)
Gloucestershire 174-4
Gloucestershire win by six wickets
fields.body:
Gloucestershire went top of the First Division when they beat Sussex by six wickets here last night and now have only to beat Northamptonshire in their final fixture on Sunday week for an unprecedented hat-trick of one-day titles.

Gloucestershire, who have already won four consecutive Lord's finals, will be champions tonight if Somerset, the only county that can catch them, fail to overcome Lancashire at Old Trafford.

Set a target of 171 from 31 overs under the Duckworth/ Lewis method, they got there with 11 deliveries to spare. Kim Barnett and Tim Hancock built the platform with a first-wicket stand of 69 in 15 overs.

Barnett was caught at long-off for 29 but Hancock went on to make a 70-ball fifty before he was caught at long-on. It was Ian Harvey, though, with a 30-ball 43, including four fours and a pulled six over mid-wicket off Mark Robinson, who ran away with the match.

Earlier Sussex, who are now back in the relegation zone, scored 148 for eight. Not for the first time this season the contribution of Michael Bevan was pivotal. He made an unbeaten 82 from 87 deliveries, striking with great power and placement to score eight fours.

This was the eighth time this season he had passed fifty in the competition and it took his tally to 654 runs at an average of 138. He was also the first player in the country to reach 1,000 first-class runs.

It was hardly surprising, therefore, that a moderate Sussex side lost their form in both championship and limited-over cricket when Bevan de parted last month to play in three indoor one-day internationals against South Africa.

Their batting again looked vulnerable last night. They chose to bat but the regular fall of wickets and rain disrupted the impetus of their innings.

Chris Adams was caught behind for a duck off the third ball of the match and Gloucestershire, fresh from their victory over Lancashire at Bristol the evening before, broke through again in the fifth over when Richard Montgomerie was well caught, right-handed, by the diving Matt Windows at short backward square-leg.

Bevan, who found his best partner in the Dutchman Bas Zuiderent, then launched a counter-attack with a series of vivid drives and legside flicks. The match was reduced to 40, 34 and finally 31 overs.

This was the third of Sussex's five floodlit games to be hit by poor weather.

webTitle: Phoenix rises in time for Ashes

fields.headline: Phoenix rises in time for Ashes
fields.standfirst: England were drifting before Fletcher and Hussain. Now they are driven
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey on how England have learned their lessons, and now find themselves better placed than for many a year to face the old foe.
fields.body:
This has been a tumultuous summer for Nasser Hussain. Beaten but not in any way disgraced in South Africa last winter, his team has metamorphosed gradually from a technical and mental fragility to something approaching the case-hardened state that will be necessary to compete against Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Australia over the coming 12 months.

England have now won three of their last four home series, and five of their last eight Tests, losing once - to West Indies at Edgbaston - and are beginning to look the part. The crowd that gathered at the Oval on Monday to witness the last rites and exult was proof positive that in international sport it is success rather than characters that captures the imagination.

The signs were there in South Africa. Hussain and Duncan Fletcher, the new coach, stressed repeatedly that England were there to learn as much as to win. They wished to compete but they, particularly the coach, needed information: what was in the stockroom and what was lacking; who had heart and who did not; which techniques and temperaments stood up to close scrutiny; and who were the workers?

It was as much a process of elimination as anything, confirmation that for all the knee-jerk calls for overhauls and new blood in the aftermath of the defeat by New Zealand a year ago, it was not as straightforward as that. A point was proved: only seven of that touring party - Hussain, Mike Atherton, Alec Stewart, Michael Vaughan, Andy Caddick, Darren Gough and, to a small extent Andy Flintoff, survived into the summer.

Instead Hussain and Fletcher began to look elsewhere. Mark Ramprakash was tried as an opener, failed and was discarded, Nick Knight's technique did not stand the test, Flintoff's technique, fitness and commitment were found lacking, Ed Giddins' bowling lacked bite when the going got tough, Chris Schofield's legspin was not trusted and Robert Croft's offspin was a disaster.

But the selectors had found enough in Craig White's bowling in the one-day series in South Africa (when he replaced the injured Flintoff) to give him a central contract and then detected a new spirit in Dominic Cork. Hussain's broken finger, the triangular tournament and Fletcher's intuition and judgment saw the emergence of Marcus Trescothick, Graham Thorpe was reinstated and suddenly the side had a steely look to it.

Hussain must take a lot of credit. His appointment, in the wake of England's desperate showing in the World Cup, was not universally popular, not just with armchair critics. Some members of his side feared an intense self-centred cricketer running the show. The big test would come, they said, if and when Hussain's form deteriorated and the dark brooding moods held sway.

Almost as if it were pre-ordained, Hussain had a torrid time this summer, with 92 runs from 10 Test innings culminating in a pair at the Oval, but throughout has remained forceful, purposeful and dignified. If his instinct is to temper his celebrations by regretting his lack of contribution with the bat this summer, he should be told again and again that it is barely nine months since he was holding the side together by batting for longer than anyone ever had in Tests, and has since been a massively influential figure who has given everything. The manner in which, as the final wicket fell, he slumped to the ground was a picture of an obsessively focused man close to mental exhaustion. No one has earned a break more.

As for Fletcher, it is little more than a year ago that the England and Wales Cricket Board was devoting its energies to pursuing the then South African coach Bob Woolmer to succeed David Lloyd. Eventually, searching elsewhere, it spoke to Fletcher, a Zimbabwean coaching Glamorgan and Western Province, and gives thanks for the day it did. Fletcher is an accomplished coach, perceptive, intolerant of under-achievement, inspirational and wary, and keeps a low profile. He commands total respect and has forged the strongest of bonds with Hussain.

There is backbone to the side now, starting with Mike Atherton, who has been outstanding. Why did we know that, when it came to the crunch, at Lord's and at the Oval, he would be the one to produce the goods. His single-mindedness is a cliché but remains remarkable for all that.

Stewart continues to prove that he has been the finest allrounder in the world for years if only those in England would take notice and Vaughan has now played two match-winning innings in the last five of his eight Tests. The batting remains collapsible but, helped by a genuine player at seven, it is getting there.

The real revelation, though, has been the bowling. Central contracts have ensured that, if Gough and Caddick, in particular, are fit at the end of a Test, they are going to be fit for the start of the next. Fletcher has cranked Gough up another gear, rediscovering his away swinger that was so devastating to the West Indian left-handers. He bowls with pace, verve, belligerence and massive self-belief and is genuinely world-class.

So, too, is Caddick. The transformation came at Lord's when someone - Hussain, Fletcher or both - read him his fortune after an indifferent first innings. In the second he was brutal, bringing short-leg into the action, and has not looked back. Pakistan wickets will test his resolve but he has the confidence to overcome that.

Cork has been a perfect foil, picking off wickets and seizing the Lord's Test by the scruff when it seemed lost, while White has emerged as a genuinely fast, accurate employer of reverse swing.
